column2: For many, summer brings consideration of the advantages and disadvantages of renting or owning a vacation home.
LISBON, June 23--The Prime Minister of Portugal, Jose Pinheiro de Azevedo, suffered a severe heart attack today while he was campaigning for the presidency.

BODENMAIS, West Germany, June 23 Maoists and neo-Nazis ventured deep into the Bohemian Forest today to greet Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa and agreed on one matter: They disliked Mr. Kissinger.

Lawrence K. Grossman, the new president of the Public Broadcasting Service, yesterday challenged the view held by many public television officials that national or "network" programming is inimical to the obligation of stations to perform a local service.

Former Governor Jimmy Carter, fleshing out his key theme of promoting closer cooperation among industrial democracies, invited comparison yesterday with Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

The two rows of bony plates sticking out of the arched back of the Stegosau- rus, a species of dinosaur familiar to most small boys, could have functioned not only as armor, as is the conventional explanation, but as fins for a natural air-conditioning system, according to three Yale University scientists.

ALBANY, June 24 The Democratic members of the Assembly, believing themselves under severe election-year pressure to reduce public employee pension benefits, today rejected as too pro-union a pension proposal by their own leadership.

WASHINGTON, June 24 Both optimists and worriers could find support for their positions in the somewhat bewildering array of indicators reported this month on what the economy has been doing recently.

JOHANNESBURG, June 24 Sir de Villiers Graaff, opposition leader in the South African Parliament, said today that the country's white minority would be "mad" to ignore the black riots of the past week, which he attributed to the Government's persistence in a system of organized racial discrimination.

CLEVELAND, June 24 (AP) De Hart Hubbard, a track star during the 1920's who became the first black American to win an Olympic gold medal, died yesterday. He was 72 years old.
GENEVA, June 24 Nestle Alimentana S.A., the global food-processing company based in Switzerland, won a court battle today against a group of Swiss defenders of third-world causes.

ABOARD THE BARQUE EAGLE, June 24 Now it can be told. Here, somewhere north of the fabled expanse of the Bermuda Triangle, where ships and planes and people have been known to vanish without reason and without trace, the mystery is solved. The ships don't sink, the planes don't crash, the people don't drown.

BUENOS AIRES, June 24 Argentina's armed forces, three months after having overthrown President Isabel Martinez de Peron, are in a bitter struggle with left-wing extremists, many of whom have been killed.

WHEN J.P. Morgan relaxed at his Camp Uncas hideway in the Adirondacks, he was surrounded by twig-embellished chests and chairs. At Marjorie Merriweather Post's log mansion in those mountains, square dancers between reels paused on her bark and branch settees.

MIAMI, June 24 A Dade County probate judge declared here today that Roy M. Cohn had tricked the late Lewis S. Rosenstiel into signing a disputed codicil naming Mr. Cohn a trustee of the liquor magnate's $75 million estate.

George D. Emmons, a navigator on the 12-meter yacht Weatherly when she defeated the Australian yacht Gretel in 1962 off Newport, R.I., in the America's Cup races, died Tuesday in United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y. His age was 79.

The London subsidiary of the Bankers Trust Company of New York has arranged an $80 millin, five-year Eurodollar loan for the Korean Development Bank. South Korea's leading financial institution and the prime lender to its major industries.
Pilots of U.S. scheduled airlines decided yesterday to halt service to Canada today, spreading a shutdown caused by a dispute over the use of French in air-traffic control.

Bechtel Inc., the San Francisco-based construction and engineering giant, announced yesterday that it had signed a 20-year agreement with Saudi Arabia for management and engineering services for a $9 billion industrial project.

SILLOTH, England, June 24 (UPI) Debbie Massey of Bethlehem, Pa., gained the quarterfinal round of the British women's amateur golf championship today with 2up victory over Carole Radford of England and a 7-and6 triumph over Marie de Lorenzi of France.
Edward Birdwell, horn player and for the last five years assistant to the dean of the Aspen Music Festival and Music School, will become deputy director of Carnegie Hall on Sept. 1.

The New York State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, yesterday abandoned his effort to work out a compromise that would have let Maurice H. Nadjari retain substantial power as a special state prosecutor, thus ending any chance that Mr. Nadjari would survive in that post.

WASHINGTON, June 24 The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that it is constitutional for cities to use zoning ordinances, backed up by criminal penalties, to try to restrict the proliferation of movie theaters that show sexually oriented films.

WASHINGTON, June 24 The World Bank announced today that its soft-loan affiliate, the International Development Association, had reached the $10 billion mark in aid to the poorest of the less developed countries.

Here are the prospects for marine angling over the weekend. AREA A Capt. Andy's Marina at Margate, N.J., reports excellent fishing off shore, night and day, for bluefish. Weakfish have showed in Margate Bay and in Great Egg Inlet. Fluke fishing is also good. Surf fishing is poor at Surf City, N.J., but offshore boats are doing well with blues and fluke.

VALENCIA, Spain The American trade union movement, which shunned direct contact with Spanish labor through the dictatorial regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco, is reaching out to help encourage rebirth of free unionism in Spain now that his successors are permitting a modest relaxation in the iron restraints on which the Falangists relied to enforce "labor peace" for four decades.

LONDON, June 24 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that after two days of talks with Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa, "a process is in motion" to produce a negotiated solution and avoid a racial war in southern Africa.

Every day New York City churns out an unpleasant mass of waste. On the average it is made up of 24,500 tons of relatively solid garbage and other refuse; 1.4 million gallons of relatively liquid sludge, which is the residue of sewage treatment plants, and 225 million gallons of raw sewage, which has not been treated at all.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 24 The tall ships surrendered to modern times today, giving up their sailing race from Bermuda to Newport because of a dead calm and turning on their engines to assure an arrival here by Saturday.

Charls E. Walker, former Deputy Secretary of the Treasury in the Nixon Administration, told a group of New Jersey businessmen yesterday in Wayne that we are falling "away behind the rest of the world in per capita gross national product," because they've got their heads screwed on right on tax structures, particularly in Japan, Western Europe and even the United Kingdom."

A chiropractor with offices in Brooklyn and Manhattan was indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn grand jury on charges of fraudulently obtaining nearly $28,000 from Medicaid over a three-year period starting in 1973.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) A near majority of the Episcopal Church's bishops have issued a statement saying that they will co-sponsor church legislation to permit the ordination of women to the priesthood.
The worst albatross for visitors to New York City's celebration of the 18th-century beauties of America will be fittingly, no doubt that symbol of clutter of 20th century America, the automobile.
PPG Industries Inc. announced' yesterday that it planned to raise prices on various architectural metal products by 10 percent, effective July 1.

Victor Gotbaum, the leader of the city's municipal workers, warned yesterday that if there was no substantive agreement on a new labor contract by next Thursday, he would recommend a strike by all city workers.

Dr. Morey L. Appell, a psychologist and associate professor of educational psychology at Hunter College, died yesterday in his Greenwich, Conn., home. He was 59 years old.

A $45 million complex of apartments and community facilities in East Harlem scheduled for completion with Federal aid last winter stands vacant and vandalized, its final construction stage suspended as the Ford Administration seeks a way to salvage the development.

MOSCOW, June 24 (AP) The Black Sea resort of Sochi has proclaimed itself the Soviet Union's first "nosmoking city," banning cigarettes from its beaches, restaurants, offices, public and private transportation, schools and hospitals.

President Ford would be at least as strong a Republican Presidential nominee in the South and West as would Ronald Reagan, according to the latest national survey of voter attitudes by The New York Times and CBS News, but the survey also showed that if the election were held today Jimmy Carter, the apparent Democratic nominee, would swamp either man by about 2 to 1.

WASHINGTON, June 24 In a landmark ruling that strengthens states' rights and limits the power of the Federal Government, the Supreme Court struck down on a 5-to-4 vote today the laws that extended Federal minimum wage and maximum hour provisions to state and municipal employees.

NEWARK, June 24 (AP) Two bus operators' organizations went to court today in a bid to block the transfer by the state of 400 buses to Transport of New Jersey, the largest private bus line in the state.

Eugene Hollander, the nursing-home operator, asked a Federal court in Brooklyn yesterday to rule that hs had satisfied his sentence for a $197,000 Medicare fraud by paying $6,000 to the Government and by agreeing to pay the rest over nine months.

WASHINGTON, June 24 The Supreme Court ruled today that when the police have probable cause to make an arrest and they sight a suspect in the doorway of his home, they may pursue him into the house even if they have no arrest warrant.

New York City was held liable yesterday for a $2 million award to Fire Department firefighters for violation of a labor union contract.

WASHINGTON, June 24 Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation kidnapped a radical political figure within the last five years in an attempt to frighten the man and deter his political activity, a wellplaced bureau source disclosed today.
NEWARK, June 24 The president of the De Camp Bus Lines said today that the company would not restore its service on three intrastate routes tomorrow despite two court orders to do so.

When officials of Purolator Inc., the oil filter maker and courier service company, announced that earnings in the first half of 1976 would be 3 to 6 percent below those for the similar period of 1975, they did not expect the news to result in a stock market disaster.

Dr. Ernest T. Campbell has resigned unexpectedly as senior minister of Riverside Church, one of the nation's leading religious centers.
Sales by chain stores in May rose 7 percent nationally from the 1975 month, the smallest increase since the no-growth period of April 1975, Chain Store Age magazine reported yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 24 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim expressed "regrets" today that Angola's request for United Nations membership had been blocked yesterday in the Security Council.

Faced with the ultimate prospect of default, the New York Racing Association hopes to get back on the right financial track with some help from Albany.

Donald Braider, an author of books on artists and other subjects, died Tuesday at his home in Cooperstown, N.Y. He was 53 years old.

ALBANY, June 34 Bowing to bipartisan pressure from legislative leaders, Governor Carey agreed tonight to a supplemental budget of roughly $30 million half again as much as the maximum he had insisted on in an accord the leaders said later would permit the Legislature to adjourn this weekend.

What, he wonders, did Scott Fitzgerald, William Faulkner, Nathanael West, Aldous Huxley and James Agee do to Hollywood, when they had to work there? We are more accustomed to hearing about what Hollywood did to them, a morality tale in which Hollywood usually plays the part of venereal disease.

The nation's basic money supply declined $400 million and business loans, at leading New York City banks fell $56 million in the latest reporting periods, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.

ST. PAUL, Friday, June 25 President Ford won a key procedural victory over Ronald Reagan this morning, apparently assuring Mr. Ford all of Minnesota's 18 at-large delegates to the Republican National Convention.

Carnegie Hall was filled last night with jazz fans who came to hear Tony Bennett and the Bill Evans Trio open the Newport Jazz Festival's 23d annual season. The Supreme Court extended yesterday the scope of a task it began some time ago of redeeming the promise of the 13th Amendment for black Americans. The high court ruled that commercially operated private nonsectarian schools could not exclude students on the basis of race-a far-reaching decision that comes as a welcome relief.

TOKYO, Saturday, June 26 Muhammad Ali, the heavyweight boxing champion, and Antonio Inoki, the jut-jawed Japanese wrestler, fought to a draw in a 15-round bout that turned into a kicking contest here today.

Stocks turned mixed yesterday with the market repeating a familiar pattern once again. The Dow Jones industrial average faltered after rising above the 1,000-point level and trading volume declined.

Minor White, one of the most Important photographers of modern times, whose classic work with the camera put him in the company of photographic artists such as Ansel Adams, Edward Steichen and Alfred Stieglitz, died Thursday night at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 67 years old.

The Central Intelligence Agency is ending its association with all part-time correspondents affiliated with American news agencies abroad and will no longer hire them as agents, George Bush, Director of Central Intelligence, has told representatives of the National News Council.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 25 The Bermuda ocean race, which began a week ago 635-miles to the northwest off Newport, R.I., ended today when the yachts still at sea, 28 of a starting list of 161, were told by radio to start up their engines and come on into the island. Their crews had suffered enough having been becalmed under a hot sun on the ocean for most of the week.

Soybean prices continued to forge ahead yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade with the July delivery closing at $6.69, within striking distance of the $6.78 a bushel reached a few weeks ago during a sustained rise. In the current week this contract has risen 52 cents' a bushel.

The outside passed pawn, situated on a wing and usually remote from the defending king and from the main body of pawns, is a fiercesome weapon. It not only ties down the opponent's pieces in a defensive blockade to prevent its promotion but it also converts each exchange of pieces into a threat to clear them all off, when it would romp in without anything to hinder it.

WASHINGTON, June 28 The State Department has given tentative approval to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for the sale to Syria and Iraq of civilian versions of the C-130 military transports already approved for sale to Egypt, officials said today.

VICTORIA, the Seychelles, Tuesday, June 29 (Reuters) The Seychelles, a cluster of 92 islands in the Indian Ocean about 1,000 miles east of the African coast, became an independent republic early today.

New appropriations announced by the nation's investor-owned electric and natural gas utilities in 1976's first quarter dropped 67 percent from the year-earlier level, according to a report released yesterday by the Conference Board, a business-research organization.

WASHINGTON, June 28 In an attempt to make the House and the Administration accept a multibillion-dollar package of financial help for energy conservation, Senate Democrats are holding hostage legislation to extend the life of the Federal Energy Administration beyond midnight Wednesday.

George D. Aiken, a Republican Senator from Vermont for 34 years until his retirement in 1974, has published "Aiken: Senate Diary," out today, and in it he has some things to say about his former colleagues and other notables.

William E. Walsh, a former vie president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society and former president of the New York Rotary Club, died on Sunday in Sarasota, Fla., where he lived in retirement. He was 79 years old.

MADISON, Wis. Perhaps 1,000 years ago, a people settled into a valley between the tall-grass prairies and the short-grass prairies of North America and established a culture known to archeologists as Mill Creek. The people were among corn farmers who spread across the plains to the base of the Rockies. The Mill Creek corn farmers are of more than archeological interest. Their history could tell us of our own future.

MIAMI BEACH, June 28 The National Education Association, a 1.8-million-member teachers organization that has gradually increased its political involvement, will take the final step into partisan politics this year with the almost certain endorsement of Jimmy Carter for President.

Injection of a drug after surgery for cancer of the colon or rectum has doubled the cure rate in patients who would ordinarily face a three-in-four chance of dying of their disease, two Long Island physicians reported yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 28 About 300 black residents from New Cassel and Westbury marched to the County Executive Building today to protest what they said was the killing of a black man by three white Nassau County police officers on June 19.

WASHINGTON, June 28-By wide margins and amid some derisive remarks about New York City's sanitary and fiscal conditions, the House of Representatives defeated today efforts to bar the Concorde supersonic transport from landing at Kennedy and Dulles Airports.
Dow Jones Company and McGraw-Hill Inc. have settled a libel suit that arose from an article in Business Week magazine in April 1975, the two companies announced yesterday.
Shares of the Ampex Corporation, the once-troubled producer of magnetic recording equipment, closed at 8 on Friday, a gain of 1.
Robert H. MacMurphey, a retired book publishing executive, died at his New Canaan, Conn., home yesterday. He was 81 years old.

LOS ANGELES, June 28 (UPI) Ronald Reagan says President Ford's tough campaign tactics for the Republican Presidential nomination show "he'd rather win a convention than an election" and could destroy the party in doing so.

COLORADO SPRINGS, June 28 Looking no more nervous than any other freshmen starting college, Bonnie Schaefer, Jacqueline Ware, Mary Ann Oblak and 152 other women broke the sex barrier today at the nation's military academies by enrolling at the Air Force Academy.

Maurice H. Nadjari accused Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday of being hypocritical when he dismissed Mr. Nadjari as special anticorruption prosecutor last Friday.

Two top state and city officials said yesterday they would investigate charges of widespread discrimination in the rental of apartments in Manhattan and take steps to eliminate the problem if the charges were substantiated.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) The House passed a $5.3 billion transportation appropriations bill today in a form that brought the threat of a veto by President Ford. The vote was 376 to 21.

In an attempt to snap his team's prolonged batting slump and stem its slide downward in the Eastern Division race, Manager Darrell Johnson made sweeping lineup changes for the Boston Red Sox's opener of a three game home series against the Baltimore Orioles last night.

Addressing graduates of Queens College, Representative Elizabeth Holtzman yesterday assailed numerous elected officials for the imposition of tuition at the City University. The action, she said, was a "cosmetic gesture" made by the city's managers "to appease a hostile Federal Government."
MONTREAL, June 28 (UPI) Ready or not, organizers plunged ahead today toward the July 17 opening of the Summer Olympics following a confused weekend rehearsal at the main installations.

JERUSALEM, June 28 An institute devoted to the study and treatment of cancer and allied diseases, constructed at a cost of $15 million, was dedicated here last night by the 350,000-member Hadassah, the largest Zionist organization in the world.

Some teen-agers in the West and East Village spend their free time hanging out together in local parks and playgrounds. They have "very little structured activity and little guidance," according to a West Village artist, William Leicht.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Commerce Department said today that the composite index of leading indicators rose 1.4 percent in May, compared with a seven-tenths of 1 percent rise in April. Pasco Inc., an oil producer in liquidation, announced yesterday that it would pay its shareholders a liquidating dividend of $22 a share on its 4,531,240 shares outstanding.

Moss, chairman of a House investigative subcommittee, said today that the Federal Power Commission should require natural gas producers to submit copies of their tax returns to justify any price relief they get from the commission to offset loss of the depletion allowance.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 30 (AP) Doug Moe, who played at Erasmus Hall High School in Brooklyn, was an Atlantic Coast Conference all-star selection at the University of North Carolina and an assistant coach of the Denver Nuggets, was named head basketball coach of the San Antonio Spurs today.

Tuesday evening at the Newport Jazz Festival belonged to Freddle Hubbard. The trumpeter was in fine form early in the evening at the Herbie Hancock Retrospect, and then he made a late appearance with Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Blakey, who had featured Mr. Hubbard in his Messengers in the 1960's, kicked up a rhythmic firestorm behind the trumpeter, and the result was another superb performance.

EAST BERLIN, June 30 A two-day conference of European Communist leaders, marked by deep divisions over tactics and ideology, ended today with the issuing of a document endorsing the independence of each party to find its own path to Socialism.

Harold M. Shore, a public relations consultant for Jewish social agencies and fund-raising campaigns, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was recently hospitalized for treatment of a heart condition. Mr. Shore was 66 years old and lived at 100-11 67th Road in Forest Hills, Queens.

ALBANY, June 3 Morning sunlight brought a muted glow to the leaded stainedglass windows in the Assembly chamber today as lawmakers and their aides churned through the 19th straight hour of business, watching as their bizarre political slumber party deteriorated into a legislative version of "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?"

TORONTO, June 30 (UPI) Dan Maloney, the Detroit Red Wings' forward, was acquitted today of an assault charge stemming from a National Hockey League brawl here last year. He was the third player in N.H.L. history to face charges for an on-theice fight and the third to be cleared.

ACCENT ON YOUTH The "Bicentennial Salute to Broadway" in midtown today at noon will be rendered not by show business specialists but by nonprofessional young people, ranging in age from 8 to 20. Grace Plaza, Avenue of the Americas and 43d Street, in the nostaglie song-and-dance salute to American show business.

Severe thunderstorms swept areas of New Jersey, southern New York and eastern Connecticut yesterday with heavy winds that knocked down power lines and lightning that struck and killed one young man and injured a second.

Forty-nine day-care centers that were facing the loss of their public financing today because of New York City's fiscal crisis received a reprieve yesterday when a Federal judge temporarily blocked the cutoff of the aid.

WASHINGTON, June 30 Clarence M. Kelley, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who previously insisted in Congressional testimony and elsewhere that burglaries by bureau agents were halted in 1966, confirmed today that the bureau carried out in 1972 and 1973 "a limited number" of break-ins directed at radical domestic and terrorist groups.

DETROIT, June 30 Rain brought a halt to a brief slump of the New York Yankees and the sudden exhilaration of the Detroit Tigers tonight as the scheduled finale of their three-game series was washed out by a steady downpour. No date for a makeup game was announced.
Sidney R. Korshak was released yesterday from Michael Reese Hospital in Chicago after treatment for a gastro-intestinal disorder, a hospital official said.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 30 One of two besieged Palestinian camps here reportedly fell to right-wing Christian forces last night after eight days of fighting.

WASHINGTON, June 30 Jimmy Carter, meeting today with George Meany, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., to solicit the labor leader's advice on his choice of a Vice Presidential running mate, found Mr. Meany's organization still unwilling to endorse him for the Presidency.

This Bicentennial month will be marked for bridge players by two exhibition matches, Patriots against Redcoats. Roger G. Hall, board chairman of Hurok Concerts Inc., announced his resignation yesterday. His action is the latest in a series of developments that is expected to reshape not only Hurok Concerts, but also the New York-based world of American classical-music management.

AVALON, June 30 Their skin a deep red from the sun and wind and their joints aching from nearly two months of rowing, two former lifeguards have begun the final phase of a 1,400-mile journey from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to the Statue of Liberty.

Matthew J. Troy Jr., finance chairman of the City Council, said yesterday that he intended to plead guilty in Federal Court today to a charge of filing a fraudulent Federal income tax return for 1972.
AMSTERDAM, June 30 Andrei Amalrik, the Russian dissident author, tonight put off his scheduled departure from the Soviet Union when new obstacles were put in his way by Soviet authorities.

WASHINGTON, June 30 Manufacturers' inventories rose by $1 billion in May, the largest monthly increase since the economic recovery began, the Commerce Department reported today.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 30 Dr. Cristos D. Papakyriakopoulos, a senior research mathematician and lecturer at Princeton University, died Tuesday at the Helene F. Fuld Medical Center in Trenton. He was 62 years old.
Stock prices pushed ahead yesterday on stepped-up volume as the broad market outperformed the blue-chip Dow Jones industrials.

WASHINGTON, June 30 Ford Administration officials said today that they had refused political asylum last week to two Lithuanians who in 1970 hijacked a Soviet airliner to Turkey because the United States could not appear to slacken in its opposition to international piracy.
Two major domestic copper companies announced yesterday price increases of 4 cents a pound in what appeared to be the third major round of copper ...

The marriage of Faith Severance Hackl of Princeton, N.J., widow of George F. Hackl Jr., to James P. Stewart, also of Princeton, took place there yesterday afternoon. Dean Ernest Gordon performed the Protestant ceremony in the Princeton University Chapel.

Nick Fotiu, a 24-year-old Staten Islander, has become the first native New Yorker to sign with the New York Rangers. The signing of the 6-foot-2-inch, 200-pound "enforcer" to a two-year pact was announced yesterday by the Rangers' general manager-coach. John Ferguson, who apparently is continuing his quest to add muscle to the club.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, June 30 The Henley Royal Regatta opens tomorrow, with 15 American colleges, prep schools and clubs making up more than half the foreign entry. In 1839 the first regatta was staged on the stretch of the Thames that flows through this idyllic town, and ever since, oarsmen have been making an annual pilgrimage here.

ALBANY, June 30 The State Legislature ended its 1976 regular session this morning in a 19-hour marathon that included the enactment of a reduced pension system for future public employees and failure to agree on a package of court reorganization amendments.

Freedom House, a 35-year-old group monitoring liberties around the world, charged yesterday that reports by two groups of experts brought together by UNESCO had proposed new government controls over news media in developing nations, starting in Latin America.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Only five hours before a midnight deadline, President Ford signed a bill today that will protect the paychecks of American workers from increased income tax withholding for two more months.
WARSAW, June 30 (UPI) Two demonstrators were killed and 75 policemen were injured last week in rioting that forced the Polish Government to cancel food-price increases, Polish television said today.

Shad Polier, the civil rights lawyer who won early prominence as part of the defense team in the landmark Scottsboro case 45 years ago, died yesterday at his home, 175 East 64th Street. He was 70 years old.
The United States Custom House on Bowling Green, an opulent monument to New York's role in sea trade, has been scrubbed and restored until it glows like a pearl.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 30 Into this city's spacious harbor, jammed with the world's largest sailing ships and hundreds of others not so large, came an innocuous vessel before dawn today, tacking among the giants.
ATLANTA, June 30 A three judge Federal panel in Alabama has ruled that the state's minimum height and weight requirements for police personnel illegally discriminate against women.

EAST BERLIN, June 30 A two-day conference of European Communist leaders, marked by deep divisions over tactics and ideology, ended today with the issuing of a document endorsing the independence of each party to find its own path to Socialism.

OTTAWA, June 30 (UPI) Environment Minister Jean Marchand, a key aide to Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's since the days they entered federal politics, today resigned his cabinet post in disagreement with the way Canada's recent air strike was ended.
Three weeks ago Sus McCready bought a stack of guidebooks to national parks, planning a cross-country trip she and her husband were to begin today. Two days later, she bought a coffin.

What is Olivia de Havilland doing these days? To listen to her tell it, she is playing a supporting role to a girl she describes as a "ravishing 19-year-old." She and Gisele Galante, her daughter by her second husband, Pierre Galante, live in Paris and she describes her main function as answering the telephone and taking messages when her daughter's many beaux call.

WASHINGTON, June 30 With his nomination assured, Jimmy Carter still occasionally fences with the reporters traveling with him who, use these occasions to try to plumb his character. But the encounters often leave the reporters just as puzzled about his personality as beforehand.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 It took all of Chris Evert's noted patience and mental strength to prevail over the heavy serves and dipping volleys of Martina Navratilova in the semifinals at Wimbledon today.
Ivan Franklin Baker, a former senior vice president and treasurer of the Westinghouse Company died Tuesday at Muhlenberg Hospital near his home in Westfield, N.J., He was 89.

After a daylong series of snags, delays and false starts. New York City and its labor unions agreed yesterday on a "memorandum of interim understanding," lifting the threat of a strike and clearing the way for Federal loans that would avert default.

Elizabeth Taylor did a nice thing for Jimmy Carter at the Waldorf-Astoria Tuesday night. The movie queen, trailing clouds of black chiffon and rhinestones, created so much excitement that the allbut-officially nominated Democratic Presidential candidate didn't have to explain why he couldn't shake 2,000 hands at a reception in his honor.

WASHINGTON, June 30 Clarence M. Kelley, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who previously insisted in Congressional testimony and elsewhere that burglaries by bureau agents were halted in 1966, confirmed today that the bureau carried out in 1972 and 1973 "a limited number" of break-ins directed at radical domestic and terrorist groups.

TRENTON, Friday, July 2 The New Jersey Legislature wearily engaged in its second consecutive marathon session this morning as it sought to find the $378 million necessary to balance the state school budget and get summer school programs back in operation.

As City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. was formally charged yesterday with filing false income tax returns, the city's Corporation Counsel ruled that he would not automatically lose his City Council seat.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 1 Sweet Emaline, handled by Barbara Walters of Barrington Hills, Ill., beat five rivals in a jump-off and won the preliminary jumper touches and time class today at the opening session of the Lake Placid Horse Show.

ALBANY, July 1 Two dozen fountains sprayed huge sheets of misty water across the vast reaches of the Albany Mall today as Governor Carey and a retinue of top state officials dedicated the Cultural Education Center and pronounced the plaza itself completed after 14 years of planning and construction.

WASHINGTON, July 1 In a project sponsored jointly by the Interior Department, Cornell University and the states involved, 28 peregrine falcons will be released this summer into wilderness areas of six states, including New York and New Jersey, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service announced today.

ALBANY, July 1 Governor Carey, with the Capitol to himself and the luxury of the last word, surveyed the freshly departed Legislature today and pronounced himself "pleased and gratified" by its performance.

The possibility of a mass exodus of stockbrokers to Nev Jersey to escape stock-transfer taxes imposed in New York appeared yesterday to have ended in the wake of a tax break of $42 million a year granted to Wall Street brokers.

The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that a fully electronic system linking all stock markets might, in the long run, be in the interest of investors but maintained that it could cost as much as $20 million to build, take four to six years to complete and possibly lead to the demise of the exchange itself.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 (Reuters) A powerful bomb exploded on the doorstep of the South African Consul's home here early today, causing an estimated $20,000 in damage and blowing out windows in nearby houses.

The supersonic Concorde has not so far given Air France a financial lift, according to Gilbert Perol, director general of the staterun French airline. In Paris yesterday Mr. Perol said that the Concorde would have an operating loss of about $42 million this year if flights to New York and Tokyo were not approved. Concorde flights have been barred by the New York Port Authority and are awaiting decision in Tokyo.

Twenty years after joining Esquire as a classified ad salesman fresh out of Yale, David M. O'Brasky has become its publisher. He has his work cut out for him.

WASHINGTON, July 2-Congress began today a two-week recess for the Fourth of July and the Democratic National Convention, with a number of major bills still to be acted on before final adjournment.
On April 19, 1775, the shot heard round the world was fired at Lexington. It was July 3, 1776, when King George heard it in London.

IT IS a common human practice to answer questions without truly asking them and the American Bicentennial is merely the latest instance. Everyone knows what the Bicentennial celebrates: the 200th anniversary of the adoption, by the Continental Congress, of the Declaration of Independance. But no one asks what the Bicentennial is because no one asks what the Declaration was.

While the United States may be accredited home of the supercookout, barbecuing is one of the more popular methods of cooking throughout the world. The name itself is said to have originated with French corsairs who sailed the Spanish Main, and who built gigantic spits over which they roasted animals whole, from beard to tail de barbe a queue.
LIMA, Peru, July 2 (Reuters) Five people, including four convicts, were killed in riots touched off by the Peruvian Government's new economic policies, authorities said here today.
Samuel Spector, a financier and industrialist, died Wednesday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 77 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 The San Francisco Examiner said today that it had agreed to pay a $600,000 libel settlement to the Synanon Foundation Inc., the rehabilitation community, and to its founder and chairman, Chuck Dederich.

Bishop James E. McManus, a retired Auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York who once led a dramatic opposition to the Governor of Puerto Rico, died Thursday at the Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J. He was 69 years old.

LOS ANGELES, July 2 (UPI) The trial of William and Emily Harris began a four-day holiday recess today, still without a jury after two weeks. A prospective juror was dismissed yesterday when she argued she was too tenderhearted to render judgment on anyone.

The Atlantic Richfield Company, in a major diversification move outside the oil industry, said yesterday it was seeking 100 percent ownership of the Anaconda Company, the large but ailing copper producer that has been wooed by a succession of corporate suitors this year.

HENLE-ON-THAMES, July 2 Records fell as temperatures rose on the second day of the Henley Royal Regatta. For the first time in the 140-year history of Henley, gentlemen were allowed to remove their coats, but not their ties, in the stewards enclosure, where the temperature hit 96 degees after the luncheon interval.
Federal mediators met yesterday with union and hospital officials in the continuing attempt to avoid a strike by 40,000 workers in New York City's voluntary hospitals next Wednesday.

Studebaker-Worthington Inc. announced yesterday that it was revising the terms of its offer to acquire 730,295 shares of publicly held stock of the Turbodyne Corporation. Stude baker said that it would pay $19.50 a share, or $3.50 a share more than it originally offered, for a total of $14.24 million. Studebaker currently owns 82 percent of Turbodyne.

Thomas D. ("for Democrat," he always said) Garry, known as the "Voice of the Sewers" who helped stampede the 1940 Democratic convention into nominating Franklin D. Roosevelt for a third term; died Thursday in Chicago at the age of 93.

CLEVELAND, July 2 Ruffled only by a powerfully hit homer into the upper deck by George Hendrick, Catfish Hunter served as a "stopper" for the Yankees tonight, scattering six hits as New York defeated the Indians, 7-1, before a crowd estimated at 35,000 at Cleveland Stadium.

The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, leader in the specialty segment of the steel industry, announced yesterday it would raise prices for stainless steal, cold-rolled sheet and strip products, effective Aug. 2.
Lewis Bergman, former editor of The New York Times Magazine, is joining the Conference Board next month as editor-in-chief of its monthly general business magazine, the Conference Board Record.

WASHINGTON, July 2 A historic note was struck in the inventors' world this week when basic patents were granted for a secret method of speech transmis sion used by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, Prime Minister Winston Churchill and other al lied leaders in World War II.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 2 (AP) A Morris County jury has cleared a restaurant of negligence in connection with a fatal accident involving a man who had been drinking at the restaurant.

GLOUCESTER, Va., July 2 (AP) Virginia's seafood industry has suffered another blow with the discovery that Kepone pesticide contamination has spread to bluefish in the lower Chesapeake Bay.
Harry Roth, a book illustrator and muralist, died Wednesday in Benedictine Hospital, Kingston, N.Y., after suffering a heart attack in his home in Woodstock, N.Y. He was 73 years old.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 (UPI) Gerald Zelmanowitz, a Mafia informer, came out of hiding to sue the Federal Government over his tax problems, and yesterday he won at least a partial victory.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 2 Lebanese Christian forces today overran the outer defenses of the besieged Tell Zaatar Palestinian camp here and said they had the camp well under control.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) President Ford said today that he had ordered the Army Corps of Engineers to delay for 60 days expanding its authority to regulate dredge and fill operations in the nation's wetlands and waterways.

WASHINGTON, July 2 Representative Robert L.F. Sikes is likely to lose the chairmanship of his Military Appropriations Subcommittee as a result of findings by the House ethics committee that he was guilty of misconduct, one source in the Democratic leadership said today.

One began as a tobacco shop and is a tobacco shop today. Another, originally a cabinetmaker, now is an undertaker, A tanner after seven generations of family ownership currently produces industrial belting. Two were initiated by that universal man, Benjamin Franklin.

About half the approximately 600 inmates now on Death Row could face execution as a result of the Supreme Court's death penalty decisions, lawyers who argued on behalf of those inmates said yesterday.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 2 Night Hawk, one of the favorites for the title, projected himself into contention for the junior jumper championship today, by winning the first jumpoff at the Lake Placid Horse Show.

MILWAUKEE, July 2 (AP) Fuzzy Zoeller fired his second successive 66 for a 12under-par 132 total and a stroke lead over Dave Hill after the second round of the $130,000 Greater Milwaukee open golf tournament.

Operation Sail is pouring millions of dollars into the tills of New York City businesses and bringing a small surge of spending to an economy that has been wallowing in the doldrums, but the celebration apparently is not producing the tidal wave of prosperity some promoters and businessmen had hoped for.

James S. Adams, an industrialist, investment banker and active supporter of humanitarian endeavors, died Thursday at Palm Beach, Fla., where he had lived for the last year. He was 78 years old and had been a longtime resident of New York City.
TRENTON, July 2 A time capsule that is to be loaded with current memorabilia for the enjoyment and amusement of Jerseyans in 2076 was displayed here today.

Five well-dressed gunmen invaded the sales suite of a diamond company in the Empire State Building yesterday and, after binding the owner and seven employees with ropes and handcuffs, walked out with more than $600,000 in diamonds, other jewels and cash.
WASHINGTON, July 2 In a somber and dramatic session, the Supreme Court ruled by a vote of 7 to 2 today that the death penalty is not inherently cruel or unusual.

In a major speech in London, Secretary of State Kissinger undertook last week a redefinition of his foreign policy, which has become a major issue in the Presidential campaign. It was a redefinition that attempted to respond both to recent criticisms by the likely Democratic candidate, Jimmy Carter, and to heavy assault from the Republican Presidential challenger, Ronald Reagan.

Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young have generally been thought of as a volatile combination of four disparate individuals who very occasionally (such as last summer) come together as an entity. But more recently the foursome has divided into two halves.

TRENTON, July 2 Few officials in New Jersey were surprised this morning when the Democratic majorities in both houses of the Legislature, their nerves frazzled after two straight days and nights of agonizing, adjourned for the weekend without breaking the tax deadlock that has kept the state's public schools closed.

PLAINS, Ga., July 2 Jimmy Carter heard today a report from a trusted lieutenant who has been screening and interviewing possible Vice-Presidential running mates for him, and began to pare the list to three or four names.
Most of New York City's major retailers will be open Monday for the first time on the legal holiday for the Fourth of July.
TEL AVIV, July 2(AP) Israeli troops opened fire on Palestinian rioters today in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan Rives, killing one person and wounding about 30, Arab sources said.

The Consolidated Edison Company announced yesterday that it had filed with the Public Service Commission revised electric rates to recover about $21.3 million of increased annual operating costs resulting from higher New York City real-estate taxes that went into effect Thursday.

TRENTON, July 2 The New Jersey Legislature adjourned for the weekend at 1 P.M. today after a second consecutive allnight session in the Assembly produced high drama and jagged nerves, but no new tax measure to finance fully the state's public schools, which have been closed since Wednesday by order of the State Supreme Court.

NEW DELHI, July 2 (Reuters) Leaders of the Mizo nationalist guerrilla movement, which has been fighting Indian security forces for 10 years, have agreed to collect all their men and hand over their arms and ammunition, a Government statement said today.

TOKYO, July 2 The death penalty, the ultimate punishment assessed by societies from the beginning of recorded history, is dying a slow lingering death itself, a victim of changing times, altered priorities and terminal disuse.

The six years of operation of the National Environmental Policy Act, the legal foundation of much of the nation's effort to improve the "quality of life," have been generally free of problems some critics predicted, a Presidential advisory panel has found.

KAMPALA, Uganda, July 2 (AP) Diplomats negotiated with pro-Palestinian hijackers today over the fate of 110 passengers and crewmen of an Air France plane held as hostages at Entebbe airport. Most of those held are Israelis.

Superb technology has been combined with high drama in the saga of Viking I this week. As it orbits Mars, hundreds of millions of miles from earth, the spacecraft has been taking and transmitting the most detailed pictures of the red planet ever seen.

After protests from civil rights and lawyers' groups, the Police Department has agreed to relax somewhat its strict limitations on demonstrations in the Madison Square Garden area during the Democratic National Convention opening July 12.

Following is a weekly listing of the unaudited net asset value applicable to the capital shares of dual-purpose investment companies at close of business Friday. Also shown are closing listed market prices or best over-the-counter dealer-to-dealer asked prices for the capital shares of each company with the percentage difference (discount or premium) between the net asset value and the asked prices of the capital shares.

If it rains tomorrow, a lot of local hostesses may be carried away in straitjackets. Fifty people or more on a wet terrace or hanging out of windows in the rain are more than they can bear to think about. The Government program aimed at immunizing every American against swine influenza before the end of this year seems to be running out of steam. With each passing day, in fact, greater concern is evident over possible adverse effects from the vaccine than from the influenza itself.
BOSTON, July 2 Three bomb blasts early today destroyed an airliner at Logan International Airport, wrecked two National Guard trucks at a city armory and severely damaged a suburban courthouse.
ABC News will replace the executive producer of the "Evening News With Harry Reasoner" next fall, when Barbara Walters joins the newscast as co-anchor with Mr. Reasoner.

The Newport Jazz Festival's midnight jam sessions have tended to be rambling affairs in the past loosely organized, as jam sessions should be, but often drab and uninspired, which they should not be. This year's jam session, held in the post-midnight hours on Friday morning at Radio City Music Hall, was a very different matter.

The Mormon Tabernacle Choir, a group of 350 singers from Salt Lake City, visited New York this week for the fourth time in the choir's 129-year history and sang a concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night.

WASHINGTON, July 2 President Ford called on all Americans today to repledge themselves to the principles of the Declaration of Independence, which he called "the Polaris of our political order the fixed star of freedom."'
Tubby the Tuba brought the Newport Jazz Festival to the youngest generation and vice versa at New York University's Loeb Center yesterday afternoon.

Three-quarters of the bluecollar and clerical Civil Service workers laid off in New York City's 1975 fiscal crisis found their way back onto the municipal payroll by the beginning of this year, according to the first detailed survey of the effects of the city's large-scale dismissals that began a year ago.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) President Ford vetoed his 50th bill today, rejecting a $3.3 billion military construction measure.

WASHINGTON, July 2 William P. Clements Jr., the millionaire Texas oil driller who became Deputy Secretary of Defense, had a showdown this week across a Pentagon coffee table with Hyman G. Rickover, the outspoken, politically powerful admiral. Mr. Clements apparently won.

In a last-minute turnabout in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday Bernard Bergman, the nursing-home operator, obtained a postponement of his sentence for bribery and agreed to pay back whatever a court-appointed accountant found he owed for Medicaid frauds.
The $100,000 added American Derby will headline the first thoroughbred Sunday racing program ever held at Arlington Park.

LISBON, July 2 Portugal's future prime minister Mario Soares, said today that the principal tasks facing his government would be to restore the authority of the state, to reach an understanding with labor and to revitalize the moribund economy.
WASHINGTON, July 2 The number of Americans with jobs fell in June and the national unemployment rate rose to 7.5 percent from 7.3 percent in May, the Labor Department reported today.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. FORRESTAL, off New York, July 2 The 53 ships of the International Naval Review, stretching for 30 miles, rendezvoused at dawn in the gray-blue Atlantic today and set course for New York, 223 miles away.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2 Chris Evert has won the All-England tennis title for the second time. In a nailbiting final that raged over 2 hours on center court, the 20-year-old No. 1 seeded player rallied to take three games running and the match from archrival Evonne Goolagong, 6-3, 4-6, 8-6, for the first American title at this sunniest of Wimbledons.
WASHINGTON, July 2 Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 9-day and 180-day maturities.
Until recently, it seems, few investors realized that Elgin National Industries was no longer primarily a wristwatch company.

In the 200th year of the Republic and the 78th game of the baseball season, Jerry Koosman fired some skyrockets over New York last night when he pitched the Mets to their eighth straight victory by stopping the Chicago Cubs, 2-l, on three hits and 12 strikeouts.

NEWPORT, R.I, July 2 (AP) Alain Colas of France, the 1972 winner of the singlehanded trans-Atlantic race, has been dropped from second to third in this year's standing for violating rules of the Royal Western Yacht Club.
TRENTON, July 2 The state's school shutdown almost scuttled the plans of the Franklin Township High School band to participate in the Bicentennial parade in Philadelphia July 4.

BUENOS AIRES, July 2 A bomb exploded today in a crowded dining room at the intelligence department of the Argentine Federal Police, killing at least 18 persons, mostly police officials. About 40 persons were injured.
WASHINGTON, July 2 The number of Americans with jobs fell in June and the national unemployment rate rose to 7.5 percent from 7.3 percent in May, the Labor Department reported today.

Frances Howard Goldwyn, the widow of Samuel Goldwyn, who was one of the last of the pioneer. Hollywood producers at his death two years ago at 91, died yesterday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 73 years old.

Presiding Bishop John M. Allin of the Episcopal Church has declared his unequivocal opposition to the ordination of women to the priesthood. The controversial issue is expectd to come up for heated debate at the church's triennial general convention in Minneapolis Sept. 11-23.

Back in the 1960's, the vicar of an Episcopal parish in a small North Carolina town decided to come to New York City for graduate training in pastoral work.

JERUSALEM, July 2 Israel advised France today of the terms under which it would be prepared to release an unspecified number of imprisoned Arab guerrillas in exchange for hostages held in Uganda by hijackers of a French airliner. ,
PORT LOUIS, Mauritius, July 2, (Reuters) Heads of state in the Organization of African Unity met today amid a major quarrel among members and confusion caused by reports of a coup in the Sudan.
SHAWNEE MISSION, Kan., July 2 (UPI) The N.C.A.A. committee on infractions announced today that the University of Hawaii had been reprimanded and censured for violations of N.C.A.A. rules.
PARIS July 2 (AP) The entire leadership of the Hoa Hao Buddhist sect and tens of thousands of followers have been arrested in Vietnam, the daughter of its leader said today.

Stock prices moved up yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market. The Amex market-value index closed at 105.17, up 0.39, and the NASDAQ industrial index ended at 96.92, up 0.84.

Frank Mosco, a 56-year-old community leader on Manhattan's Lower East Side, said yesterday that he had taken a leave of absence as chairman of Community Planning Board 3. Dr. Thomas L. Norton, dean emeritus of the College of Business and Public Administration at New York University, died yesterday at the home of his daughter in Old Greenwich, Conn. He was 76 years old.

PASADENA, Calif., July 7 (UPI) Scientists postponed tonight for the secoond time the Mars landing of the Viking 1 space mission because the alternate site was found to be rougher than had been expected.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, July 7 Clarence M. Kelley, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, acknowledged in court today that the bureau issued a nationwide alert about possible violence by American Indians over the July 4 holiday without proof that such events would occur.
Many black New Yorkers found other things to do during the Bicentennial celebrations, while some joined in the festivities with certain reservations.

The managing director of the International Monetary Fund, H. Johannes Witteveen, has called upon the leading industrialized nations to reduce the size of their budget deficits and slow their rate of monetary expansion over the next two years.
If there were a Richter scale of shocks at the bridge table, the opening bid by South on the diagramed deal would have struck West with a force right at the top of the scale.

A tornado staged another rare spectacle in New York Harbor just before noon yesterday. The black, twisting cone touched down in an industrial area near the waterfronts of Bayonne and Jersey City, whipping walls and roof from four buildings, tipping over trailers and cars and downing utility lines. Three persons were reportedly slightly injured.

WASHINGTON, July 7 The likelihood of a delay in the scheduled July 1977 opening of the Alaska oil pipeline has increased in recent weeks because of problems with the pipeline company's records of quality-control radiographs of welds in the 800-mile line, authoritative Government sources said today.
The Rev. Dr. Charles A. Kellogg, minister of the Old South Haven Presbyterian Church of Brookhaven, L.I., died June 28. He was 50 years old.

There are many layers of meaning in Antony Tudor's ballet "Shadowplay," which had its first performances of the season Tuesday night and yesterday afternoon with American Ballet Theater at the State Theater.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 7 The United States led Bermuda, two races to one, in the International Luders-16 Class team match for the Aberfeldy Trophy today after the second and third races of the five-race series were sailed off Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

LANRODEC, France, July 4 At the sound of a distant thunderclap or the sight of a lightning flash, the people in this parched region of Brittany look to the sky, hoping that the rains will come to end the worst drought France has suffered in more than a century.

Margot Murphy McConnell, who originated the food column in The New York Times in 194l under the pen name Jane Holt, died Tuesday of a heart ailment in a hospital in London, where she was on vacation. She was 70 years old and lived at 64 East 94th Street.
Bill Swiacki, remembered by a generation of football fans for his catch of a forward pass, was found dead yesterday at his home in Sturbridge, Mass. He was 53 years old.
It took some extensive traveling through Peru and additional hunting in the city, but Barbara Brady and Miguel Prado are satisfied.

MOSCOW, July 7 Two Soviet astronauts piloted their Soyuz 21 spacecraft to a safe docking today with the orbiting Salyut 5 space station, then boarded the station for what some Western experts believe may be a stay of up to three months.

DETROIT, July 7 The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation said today they had raised the prices of replacement parts for their cars and trucks. The American Mo tors Corporation said it was going to raise prices of parts later this summer, but the General Motors Corporation said it planned no increase.

The Jefferson Starship brought its songs of miracles, rabbits and revolution to Central Park's Great Lawn yesterday. It was the fourth annual free concert there by the San Francisco rock group, courtesy once again not only of the band but also of WNEW, which presented the program, and RCA Records, which contributed appreciably toward it.
Daniel P. Moynihan urged the United States yesterday to join with other industrial nations in combating international terrorism.

Though urged by Republican mayors around the country to sign it, President Ford has vetoed the $3.95 billion public works employment bill and denounced it as an effort by the Democratic majority in Congress to enact "empty promises and giveaway programs." The bill would lead, Mr. Ford asserts, to "larger deficits, higher taxes, higher inflation and, ultimately, higher unemployment."

After receiving evaluation reports from two underwriting companies, the Richmond Corporation yesterday rejected the $250 million tender offer of the Continental Group. Richmond's board said the evaluation reports confirmed its previous opinion expressed after the offer was made last May that the proposal was inadequate.

WEST BERLIN, July 6 (Reuters) The United States film "Buffalo Bill and the Indians, or Sitting Bull's History Lesson" won the Golden Bear award at the Berlin Festival, despite an earlier protest by the director, Robert Altman, that he did not want the picture considered for a prize.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, which is revamping its operations under new management, has turned a profit on its massive supermarket business for the second successive quarter. Its report yesterday for the fiscal first quarter ended May 29 showed net income at $6.3 million, or 25 cents a share, in contrast to a year-earlier deficit of $4.7 million.

Especially toward the end of a short life, Mozart had little to be cheery about, but the bulk of his music is nonetheless characterized by the emotional restraint and the unshatterable poise that the 18th century valued greatly in its art.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) A White House spokesman today denied a report that Rogers C.B. Morton would be replaced as President Ford's campaign manager before the Republican National Convention.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 7 Patricia Hearst's sentencing for armed bank robbery and use of firearms to commit a felony was delayed today until about mid-October.
In the six-team Eastern Division of the National League, the Chicago Cubs are fifth, 19 games back of Philadelphia. They have a 34-46 won-lost record and the worst earned-run average in the league.

PRIDE AND PREJUDICE Lord Taylor is obviously proud of the city's landmark buildings, judging by its window display today through July 21 of oil paintings by Letizia Pitigliani. The artist's own civic pride is reflected in her realistic depiction of such historic edifices as the Tweed Courthouse, the Chrysler Building, Grand Central Terminal, the Empire State Building and other structures.

The city's effort to reduce expenditures so it can live within its three-year emergency financial plan came under further attack yesterday from the New York State official assigned to monitor the cost-cutting operation.
The RCA Corporation is borrowing a page from automobile dealers in conducting what is reportedly the first national program to grant trade-in allowances on used color televison sets.

TRENTON, Thursday, July 8 The Democratic majority in the New Jersey Assembly put together the right combination of bills last night to obtain passage of an income tax measure. The vote was 41 to 36, the minimum total needed.

In a contest in which even a half-dozen delegates could be crucial, President Ford appears to have a dozen or more "hidden" supporters among nominally uncommitted New York state delegates of the Republican National Convention.

LHASA At the points where the old foot tracks that wended through the wastes of Asia to Lhasa brought the traveler to first sight of the holy city of Tibet, cairns stood, raised by the pebbles placed in thanksgiving by pilgrims through the ages. Now the car coming from the airport stops for that first sight only if the traveler has thought to ask, but this first...

NEWARK, July 7 (AP) Affidavits filed in Federal District Court here today alleged that West Point cadets sold stolen military equipment, cheated on exams and impersonated Government officials, but were never punished for honor-code violations.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 7 (UPI) Two police decoys testified today that Representative Allan T. Howe, Democrat of Utah, brought up the subject of sex after pulling up next to their parked car in Salt Lake City's red-light district last month.

A tornado staged another rare spectacle in New York Harbor just before noon yesterday. The black, twisting code touched down in an industrial area near the waterfronts of Bayonne and Jersey City, whipping walls and roof from four buildings, tipping over trailers and cars and downing utility lines. Three persons were reportedly slightly injured.

WEST POINT, N.Y., July 7 A new class of cadets at the United States Military Academy, including the first contingent of women, indicated firm and virtually unanimous support today for the honor code and system.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 7 The Cambridge City Council voted tonight to establish a three-month "good faith" moratorium and study period for an experimental type of genetic research proposed by Harvard University, which is situated in this city.

The South African Government has beaten an unprecedented retreat on the language issue that was the immediate cause of the recent Soweto disturbances. Pupils in schools for blacks will no longer face the legal requirement that they be taught in Afrikaans, the language of the Afrikaners who form the majority of South Africa's white population.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 7 Kevin Bacon, a member of the Australian Olympic team, rode Melody Maker to victory in the first open jumper class today at the Lake Placid horse show.

NEWARK, July 7 The Newark Human Rights Commission said today in a long-awaited report that there were serious shortcomings in the treatment of the city's Spanish-speaking population, most of it Puerto Rican, and proposed 24 recommendations for correcting them.
ATLANTA, July 7 Does Dean Rusk have a younger brother?
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) The Food And Drug Administration today recalled because of contamination with a mold, more than 19,000 jars of peanut butter distributed on the East Coast.

In the six years that Lynn Geddes has been operating his Universal Academy for Music, which has its headquarters in Princeton, N.J., it has become a big business. This summer, more than 900 high school students from across the country are enrolled in the two choruses, two bands and orchestra that went off to Europe this week after rehearsing for a few days and giving a pair of concerts at Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, July 7 The Securities and Exchange Commission put forward today its long-awaited recommendations governing the conditions under which stockholders' proposals may reach a vote at stockholder meetings.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) President Ford vetoed today an appropriations bill for the National Fire Prevention and Control Administration, saying that it contained a provision that would enhance the power of Congress at the expense of the President's.

United States District Judge Orrin G. Judd, who ordered the cleanup of the Willowbook State School for the Mentally Retarded, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Aspen, Colo., where he was attending a judicial seminar. He was 69 years old.
MONTE CARLO, July 7 The United States Tennis Association did an about-face today when it decided against withdrawing from the Davis Cup international tennis competition.
By the time it's over the great cola war will have made the legendary HertzAvis advertising tiff seem like a lover's quarrel.

ALBANY, July 7 In a first trickle of what promises to be a wave of bill approvals and vetoes, Governor Carey announced today that he had signed legislation making it easier for the police to shut down brothels and making it legal for dignitaries at the Democratic National Convention in New York City later this month to have bodyguards with firearms.

The Juvenile, which has been won by such notable thoroughbreds as Equipoise, Nashua and Bold Ruler, had its 100th running at Aqueduct yesterday. But despite its glamorous past, the 5 1-2-furlong fixture attracted only five starters and four betting interests.
WASHINGTON, July 7 The United States said today that Soviet authorities in recent months had sharply reduced the level of microwave radiation beamed at the American Embassy in Moscow.

New York State's Commissioner of Housing and Community Renewal, resigned yesterday because of her dissatisfaction with the compromise plan to end the bitter 13-month dispute between the state and most residents of the giant Coop City apartment project.
PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., July 7 Processing of the 560 athletes and officials of the United States Olympic team started today on the Plattsburgh campus of the State University of New York.

The shares of Budget Industries a financial holding company, registered a 10 percent gain last Thursday and an 8.9 percent gain on Tuesday of this week. Both advances were among the best of the day on the New York Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission adopted standard plugs and sockets nationwide for telephones today to ease purchase and installation of telephone equipment by consumers.

David Eisenhower is writing an "intimate character study" of his grandfather entitled, "Going Home to Glory: Dwight D. Eisenhower." Random House has acquired the rights to the book, which a spokesman for the publisher says will examine not so much how but why power flowed to the general so suddenly and in such quantity.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 7 (AP) Earthquake-triggered landslides in the Indonesian part of New Guinea buried nearly 6,000 persons, the authorities reported today. Reports reaching Jakarta did not say whether rescue teams had managed to free some of the victims.

Matthew J. Troy Jr., who last week pleaded guilty to a Federal charge of income-tax evasion, was applauded by some of his colleagues in the New York City Council as he took his seat yesterday at the head of the Council's Finance Committee.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 7 (AP) The bodies of two more possible victims of an Amazon jungle gunfight were discovered today.

A West Side branch of the New York Public Library was shut down yesterday by its employees who, citing a contract provision, said it was too hot and humid to work. The move surprised community residents, many of whom had recently fought to keep the library open and had saved the jobs of those who work there.

FALMOUTH, Me., July 7 Russell E. Train, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, described the Maine Audubon Society's new headquarters building here today as an effort "of real significance for the energy future of the United States."
A New Jersey-based medical laboratory that had planned to open a plant in Queens that it said would ultimately provide 1,000 new jobs now intends to abandon the project.

TRENTON, July 7 The first sign of public unrest over the court-ordered school shutdown appeared at the State House today when parents and students from Ridgewool showed up to lobby for a solution to the school financing problem.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) Fifty-four Indians who said they were trying to tour the Bureau of Indian Affairs building were arrested today on charges of disorderly conduct, bureau and police spokesmen said.

Simon Schuster, one of the country's biggest book publishing companies, signed a lease yesterday for 115,000 square feet of space in Rockefeller Center that will permit it to bring together its scattered New York City workforce and continue the expansion that has added 100 employees in the last year.
EAST BERLIN, July 7 (Reuters) The Soviet Union today called on its East European partners to further tighten economic links by setting common production goals for the 1980's.

NEWARK, July 7 (AP) Affidavits filed in Federal District Court here today alleged that West Point cadets sold stolen military equipment, cheated on exams and impersonated Government officials, but were never punished for honor-code violations.

Stocks moved up on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market yesterday. The Amex market value index closed at 105.30, up 0.04, and the NASDAQ industrial index ended at 96.89, up 0.15.

The International Brotherhood of Teamsters and its president, Frank R. Fitzsimmons, have been charged with attempting to "control, dominate and monopolize" interstate motor transportation in the United States in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.

ESSEN, West Germany, July 7 (AP) Gustav Heinemann, former President of West Germany, died today, six days after being admitted to a hospital with a circulatory ailment, a hospital spokesman announced. He was 76.
PARIS, July 7 (Reuters) Paris newspaper owners and printers' unions today settled their dispute over technical modernization that has kept the industry here in turmoil for more than a year.

HOUSTON, July 7 Staked to 12 runs on a 20-hit attack. Jerry Koosman easily halted the brief three-game slide of the New York Mets tonight by turning back the Houston Astros, 12-4. The Met lefthander picked up his ninth victory against six losses in eight innings of work. Ken Sanders mopped up.

Morton Levine, ousted as an executor of the estate of the late artist Mark Rothko, and held liable for $6 million in damages by Surrogate Millard L. TRENTON, July 7 The Democratic majority in the New Jersey Assembly put together the right combination of bills tonight to obtain passage of an income tax measure. The vote was 41 to 36, the minimum total needed.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 7 Thirty eight wild horses have now been found dead in the Orr Springs sector of the Dugway Proving Grounds, Army and Bureau of Land Management officials said today. Animal experts are unable to identify what felled the horses, but indicated that "the Orr Springs waters seems directly implicated."

After jumping the new daily limit of 30 cents a bushel yesterday early in the session in most months, soybean futures contracts dropped sharply amid a wave of profit taking. The July contract, which rose as high as $7.57 a bushel during the day, closed at $7.07. Off from $7.27.
PEKING, July 7 (Reuters) China prepared elaborate funeral ceremonies today to honor Chu Teh. Its most famous soldier and elder statesman.
