The cynical calculation of Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau that the International Olympic Committee was a paper tiger has proved correct. On the ground it had "no other alternative," the executive board of the committee has bowed to Canada's decision to bar the Republic of China team that comes from Taiwan.
The 37th Democratic National Convention opened last night in Madison Square Garden in a blare of upbeat music accompanied by thunderous attacks on the Republicans.

An explosive mixture of unexpected demand, reduced supply and politics has fueled a 50 percent rise in soybean prices in recent weeks and the advance has not yet run its course, according to Middle West market specialists.

At 8:52 o'clock last night, the Democrats heard for the first time in the 1976 convention what most Americans recognize as the great quadrennial rallying cry of American national politics: "Will the delegates please clear the aisles?"
PHILADELPHIA, July 12 Baseball's owners and players reached agreement today on a four-year pact that for the first time gives the players freedom of movement.

Janet Laib Amgott, daughter of Mrs. Isadore Levin of Palm Beach Fla., and Fast Hampton, L.I., and the late Walter Laib, was married yesterday afternoon, to James W. Byrnes Jr., son of Mrs. Martin Kinsella of Newport, R.I., and the late Mr. Byrnes.

BATAVIA, N.Y. July 12 (UPI) William Marquardt set off two months ago on an aroundthe-world bicycle trip to show people a gentler form of travel than the automobile. Sunday night, his bike was hit by a car and he died instantly.

LONDON, July 12 (Reuters) Britain said today that the recent trial of foreign mercenaries in Angola had not been fair and expressed shock and dismay at the execution of four of the convicted men on Saturday.
The thunderous reception that Representative Barbara Jordan received last night at the Democratic National Convention was the final proof. She is, no doubt, a hero of the party.

CORONA DEL MAR, Calif., July 12 A quarter-acre test module is ready for launching at sea here to determine the feasibility of a chain of huge offshore "kelp plantations" that would produce abundant quantities of methane gas for fuel and nutrients for food crops and livestock.

Dr. Maurice Trotta, retired professor of industrial relations and business management at the College of Business and Public Administration of New York University, died Sunday in Newton (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 3 Rocky Terrace, Sparta, N.J.
Publishers of magazines for male homosexuals, heartened by steady circulation growth, are looking at national advertisers with varying degrees of optimism or pessimism.

DETROIT, July 12 (AP) The General Motors Corporation and many of its big-city dealers are engaged in a growing confrontation over whether the manufacturer or the dealer should supply radios for new G.M. cars.

Marion MacKenzie Mailler, a former trustee of Vassar College, died on Sunday in the Cornwall (N.Y.) Hospital, of which she was the first woman trustee. The widow of Lee B. Mailler, who was Republican majority leader in the State Assembly, she was 69 years old and lived at 16 Grandview Avenue, Cornwall-on-Hudson.
Beatrice Mathieu, the first and only Paris fashion correspondent for The New Yorker magazine, died early yesterday in her sleep at her home, 870 United Nations Plaza. She was 71 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 12 The International Monetary Fund disclosed today that it had lent more money to its member countries in the first six months of this year than in any previous full year of the fund's history.

A 23-year-old reporter for The Anderson (S.C.) Independent and Daily Mail, on her first visit here, had only praise yesterday for the taxi driver who returned the camera equipment she left in his cab in the confusion of her arrival.

TIME OUT Starting today in the business sector of lower Manhattan, visitors and office workers can look forward to a midday series of city-sponsored entertainments, ranging from ethnic diversions to jazz, ballet and mime theater. The midweek events are scheduled for three sites in the area, with all performances starting at 12:30 P.M. The programs will end on Sept. 22.
PARKERSBURG, W. Va., July 12 (UPI) Two California women were injured seriously today when their plane crashed on the final leg of the coast-to-coast Powder Puff Derby.

Wheat, corn and soybean prices declined yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as bewildered longs those who own commodity contracts sold heavily to even out their positions before the Government released its wheat and corn crop report after the close of trading.
Jimmy Carter made peace yesterday with a group of 30 black Democrats that included several who had bitterly opposed him up to the meeting.

Barbara Walters will be the only member of a network news anchor team not taking part in the coverage of either the Democratic or Republican National Conventions. This is because she is in contractual limbo until her present contract with NBC ends and her new one with ABC begins on Sept. 9. She will, however, be an observer at both convention sites from the A.B.C. News hospitality booth.
MONTREAL, July 12 Lastditch efforts to keep Taiwan in the Olympic Games began taking shape today on a broad political front.

HONG KONG, July 12 In a major move to improve relations with its Southeast Asian neighbors, newly reunified Vietnam has agreed to establish diplomatic ties with the Philippines and to receive a Thai delegation next month to discuss normalization of relations, it was announced today.
ATTICA, N.Y., July 12 (AP) Attica prison, where the quelling of revolt in 1971 left 43 people dead, was under tight security today following new violence that injured eight guards and one prisoner.
WASHINGTON, July 12 The United States has sent a frigate and a Navy patrol plane to Kenya in a symbolic show of support for the East African nation in its dispute with neighboring Uganda.

CAIRO, Tuesday, July 13 The 20-nation Arab League began a new attempt here yesterday to find a way of ending the Lebanese civil war, and Egypt offered to send tanks but not troops to strengthen the league's peace-keeping force in the Beirut area.

Arm in arm, Lynette Gittens and Bill Mc Ewen and Teresa Lunsford and Ray Stevens did a wiggly sort of dance to "When the Democrats ... Come Marchin' In," on the stage of the New York Hilton Hotel yesterday.

JERUSALEM, July 12 The Israeli units that rescued hijacking hostages from the Entebbe airport a week ago took with them a Mercedes limousine carrying an Israeli officer with blackened face impersonating President Idi Amin of Uganda and two Land-Rovers full of men dressed as Palestinian bodyguards, according to Israeli sources.

MINEOLA, July 12 An award of a 9.5-percent wage increase for 3,300 members of the Nassau County Patrolmen's Benevolent Association was upheld unanimously today by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

Pepsi-Cola yesterday extended its "Pepsi Challenge" advertising to New York and Los Angeles, bolstering it with independent national research that alleges to show "more Coca-Cola drinkers prefer the taste of Pepsi-Cola than the taste of Coca-Cola."
In a strange turn of events, the hospital workers strike has become a "militant struggle for binding arbitration," in the words of Moe Foner, the union's executive secretary.
Dora Burling Roesch, who was active in Methodist affairs, died Saturday at her home in Huntington Bay, L.I. She was 88 years old.
MONTVILLE TOWNSHIP This Morris County community's library, a former two-room schoolhouse and one-time jail, has added 2,400 square feet with $45,000 and the use of five connecting trailers.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 12 (AP) A City Court judge today denied defense motions that the sex-solicitation charge against Representive Allan T. Howe be dismissed on grounds of alleged entrapment and misconduct by the prosecution.

HELMSTEDT, West Germany, Along a short stretch of the border just south of here the East Germans have begun to dismantle the land mines they planted and to remove other border fortifications they had set up to seal off their territory.
MONTAUK, L.I. One of the most exciting ways to catch striped bass is with a surface swimming plug cast from shore or boat.

UNIONDALE, L.I., July 12 The New York Sets broke a three-match losing streak in World Team Tennis tonight, defeating the Pittsburgh Triangles, 27-20, before 3,360 at the Nassau Evonne Goolagong beat Billie Jean King, 7-5, in women's sinbles.

Grown-ups who are selfconscious about playing with children's toys need have no reservations about toying with the miniature wooden cars, tricycles, windmills, carts and animals that Nick Lecakes makes specifically for this purpose.

Outside Madison Square Garden, a sidewalk vendor delighted in the attention paid to her stock of lapel buttons bearing nothing but a strikingly familiar set of grinning teeth. They were, said the vendor, "really unique."

After a nine-month separation, Andrei Aszody of Bucharest had a bedside reunion with his three-year-old son, Andrei Jr., at Beth Israel Hospital yesterday. Mr. Aszody was met at Kennedy International Airport by his wife, Magda, a pediatrician who brought their son here for treatment of T-cell leukemia, a rare f orm of blood cancer.

Representative Herman Badillo yesterday won the endorsement of Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon of Puerto Rico in his campaign for election to a third term from the 21st Congressional District in the Bronx.

The world of music is sometimes thought of as a barren plain on which numerous armed camps regard one another with undisguised hostility. Classicalmusic devotees dismiss most popular music as beneath contempt, and the populists scorn the classicists as hopeless elitists.
Joan Mack, principal fund raiser for WNET/Channel 13's public television productions, died of cancer on Sunday at her home in East Hampton, L.I. She was 46 years old.

DETROIT, July 12 The American Motors Corporation said today that because of declining small car sales it lost $3.9 million in the quarter ended June 30. It forecast it would also end its current fiscal year on Sept. 30, with a deficit.
Propelled by the lingering effects of last week's positive economic news, the stock market pushed its way yesterday to both a 41-month high and a 1976 record.

Robert S. Strauss, chairman of the National Democratic Committee, had pledged that the party's 37th national convention would run strictly according to schedule. But like every other part convention, it got started late, United Press International reported.
On the golf course, decisions come easy to Judy Rankin.

John H. Forsman, a retired printing industry executive and a prominent amateur golfer, died yesterday at Stamford Hospital, Stamford, Conn. He was 81 years old and a resident of the New York Athletic Club, 180 Central Park South.

His name is George Foster, a gentle name that shelters the notoriety he deserves. Of all the hitters in tonight's All-Star Game, George Foster of the Cincinnati Reds has been the most productive in the triple crown categories this season. He leads the major leagues with 72 runs batted in. He shares fourth in the major leagues with 17 home runs. He's the National League's sixth leading batter with a .327 average. He's not unappreciated.

BOMBAY, India-A Government ban on scenes of violence, excessive sex and drinking, imposed last spring, has cut sharply into movie production here, leaving the fate of more than 400 films in various stages of production uncertain.
After an absence of 38 years, the Abbey Theater, Ireland's national theater, will spend six weeks in the United States, beginning Nov. 8, to celebrate the Bicentennial.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 12 Miguel (Mike) Roche may not reach the final of the Olympic 3,000-meter steeplechase, but he seems sure to set an Olympic record. He may become the only man ever to run an Olympic steeplechase with a broken wrist.

Bower of the Pelham Country Club, and Mrs. Robert Young of the Aspetuck Valley Country Club, Weston, Conn., tied for the medal in the 32d Women's Tri-County golf tournament today. Each carded par-equaling 35, 37-72's at the Hampshire Country Club.

Dr. Joseph C. Horan, who retired 15 years ago as medical director of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died yesterday morning in New York Hospital after an illness of several months. He lived at 565 Park Avenue and was 85 years old.

WHITE PLAINS, July 19-- The mystery of a Thomas Paine tombstone discovered nearly 100 miles north of the Revolutionary author's original burial place in New Rochelle was apparently resolved today. The tombstone was a token of admiration ordered by a local resident one century ago.

TRENTON, July 19.--New Jersey's Congressional delegation will be briefed Thursday on the state's proposal for locating the National Solar Energy Research Institute in vacant office and laboratory space at Fort Monmouth.
Homer Wood, a lawyer and West Coast newspaper publisher, died Sunday in Porterville, Calif. He was 96 years old.
What is to be made of the people beeper--the electronic paging device housed in a little black box that hangs on a person's belt or nestles in a purse?

JOHANNESBURG, July 19 (AP)--Six blacks have been killed in tribal clashes in the eastern Transvaal, and a South African soldier and two black guerrillas died in weekend clashes in South-West Africa, Government officials said today.

Gold futures prices have dropped sharply in the aftermath of last week's auction by the International Monetary Fund and yesterday the decline continued, taking prices to the lowest levels in 18 months. The I.M.F. plans another sale on Sept 15.

MONTREAL, July 19--How does an Olympic gymnast improve on a perfect score? Nadia Comaneci gave a stunning demonstration tonight when the unflappable 14-year-old Rumanian registered two perfect marks during a performance that sent The Forum into a frenzy usually reserved for Stanley Cup hockey games.

A 39-year-old Consolidated Edison repairman who nearly drowned a few days ago during a swim off Orchard Beach in the Bronx yesterday rescued a 64-year-old man from the strong currents of the East River off the utility's plant in Astoria, Queens.
Rorer-Amchem Inc., of Fort Washington, Pa., announced yesterday that it had entered into an agreement in principle to merge a subsidiary into the Union Carbide Corporation
Paul Balser, a retired high school principal died July 12 of a heart atack while playing golf at Heritage Village Golf Club, Southbury, Conn. He was 67 years old and lived in Holliswood, Queens.

WASHINGTON, July 19-- Three New York State Congressmen were among the most traveled of the 535 members of the House and Senate in 1975, encircling the globe, usually at taxpayer's expense, according to a report published today.

The chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation proposed yesterday that savings realized from the latest plan to "stretch out" city debt obligations be used to help finance New York City's proposed new convention center.

Now that fortune has begun at long last to smile on the Russell, Harris, Levenson advertising agency, its three partners can also smile. And Edward T. Russell, the president, can look back to May and June without cringing and say, "We really had some sweating-bullets days." The partners can begin paying themselves again, and the bookkeeper can go back to a five-day week from the two-day weeks of the silent spring.

ASPEN, Colo.--Multinational corporations provide only a handful of jobs in the developing countries and possibly displace more workers than they hire, according to Constantine V. Vaitsos, chief of the Science and Technology, Policy Group of the Andean Pact.

LISBON, July 19--Mario Soares, Portugal's Prime Minister-designate, said today that his Government would seek a more active role in the Atlantic alliance and integration into "all of the European institutions."

WASHINGTON, July 19--Senator Lloyd Bentsen is responsible for inserting into the current tax bill at least 10 provisions that benefit just a few companies each. Precisely how many Bentsen proposals the bill contains is not easily determined.
TOKYO, July 19 (AP)-- Prosecutors investigating the Lockheed payoffs arrested an executive and a driver for Lockheed's former sales agent in Japan today on charges of destroying evidence.

TRUMBULL, Conn., July 19 (UPI)--A Trumbull man whose life was threatened after he killed two members of the Hell's Angels motorcycle club during a barroom shootout was killed early today by a shotgun blast, the police said.
If there's a Ford in your future this fall, it may well be on your back.
Sam Shain, founder in 1957 of the International Motion Picture Exhibitor, a trade journal that ceased publishing two years ago, died Saturday at Doctors Hospital in Miami. He was 75 years old.
The National Ballet of Canada returns tonight to the Metropolitan Opera House for the fifth time since 1973 and for the first time since Alexander Grant became its artistic director.

WASHINGTON, July 19-- Pledging "all-out support." the A.F.L.-C.I.O. abandoned its neutral political posture today and endorsed the Democratic ticket of Jimmy Carter for President and Walter F. Mondale for Vice President.
Foreign investment in United States manufacturing plants in the first half of 1976 jumped by 60 percent over last year's levels, according to a survey by the Conference Board.
CHARLESTON, W.Va., July 19 (AP)--Thousands of coal miners went on strike today in West Virginia, angered by what they called unfair Federal court intervention in union affairs.

PITTSBURGH, July 19 (UPI) --The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reached a contract agreement today with a union representing 12,500 nonstriking salaried employees and held around-the-clock negotiations with bargainers for 41,000 striking electrical workers.
A study was begun yesterday by the New York City Health Department to find out how many deaths, if any, might have been caused by the 11-day hospital strike that ended last Saturday.
SAN JUAN, P.R., July 19 (AP) --Dr. Jose M. Gallardo, Acting Governor of Puerto Rico for 10 months during World War II, died last night at his home after a brief illness. He was 78 years old.

A five-month study by the Department of Consumer Affairs in New York City has found that one in five eye examinations given by the optometric establishments that were surveyed resulted in unnecessary prescriptions for eyeglasses, according to Elinor Guggenheimer, the city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, July 19--Senator Lloyd Bentsen is responsible for inserting into the current tax bill at least 10 provisions that benefit just a few companies each. Precisely how many Bentsen proposals the bill contains is not easily determined.

WASHINGTON, July 19-- President Ford called today for the creation of a permanent special prosecutor's office to investigate wrongdoing by Government officials. He also said that it would be "up to the American people" to decide whether his pardon of President Nixon would be a campaign issue.

MOSCOW, July 19 (UPI)-- Two Soviet astronauts who have been orbiting earth in a space laboratory for nearly two weeks have turned from rearing guppies to growing plants, the press agency Tass said today.

MONTREAL, July 19--The five interlocking Olympic rings symbolizing world brotherhood suffered another major blow today when 17 nations with 465 athletes officially left the Olympic Village or made final plans to do so.

An offer to transfer up to 85 acres of city-owned land on Staten Island to the state for the development of a 200-acre state park in the Clay Pit Pond Wetlands to preserve wildlife and plant life there was announced yesterday.

The partnership of Fernando Bujones and the Japanese ballerina, Yoko Moroshita, is one of considerable interest. Not merely because Mr. Bujones is one of America's leading dancers, but even more because in Miss Moroshita we are really seeing our first extended glimpse of a Japanese ballerina developed in Japan. This, frankly, is something exotic.
CAIRO, July 19--Egypt has signed a mutual defense agreement with the Sudan, the Egyptian Government press agency said here tonight.

A 39-year-old Consolidated Edison repairman who nearly drowned a few days ago during a swim off Orchard Beach in the Bronx yesterday rescued a 64-year-old man from the strong currents of the East River off the utility's plant in Astoria, Queens.

The water quality in the rivers and bays surrounding New York City declined steadily between 1969 and 1975 because of what city officials have described as a "temporary increase" in raw-sewage discharges.

Two of Wall Street's bestknown theories on forecasting stock prices appear to be on a collision course. One has just flashed a signal that higher prices are ahead. The other soon may flash a warning signal that the market is headed downward.
A printing press caught fire at The New York Times last night about two hours before the scheduled run of today's first edition.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) --A Pentagon expert said today the Household Goods Forwarders Association of America was trying to push through Congress a special interest bill to keep the Government from saving millions each year on overseas shipment of servicemen's belongings.
PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (UPI)--Harold E. Stassen, running for the Republican Presidential nomination for the sixth time, sent a letter today to party delegates seeking their support.
ALBANY, July 19 (UPI)--The State Labor Department said today that 48,346 persons filed new claims for unemployment compensation during the week ended July 9, down 206 from the previous week.

Melvin M. Aboff of Huntington Bay, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., philanthropist and owner of Aboffs chain of paint stores, drowned Sunday afternoon in Fairchild's Cove off Lloyd Neck, L.I., while swimming.
YONKERS, July 19--With some of America's top trotting and pacing events on its agenda, Yonkers Raceway tonight opened a 78-program meeting with speculation ...

As television coverage of the summer Olympics began Saturday afternoon, the picture was stunning. Montreal was seen from the air in wide panoramic shots while an announcer delivered a thumbnail history of the city. Attractive graphics were used to present the logos of the Games and ABC Sports.

WASHINGTON, July 19-- The Justice Department is investigating the possibility that funds belonging to the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Recreational Association were converted to the use of J. Edgar Hoover, the late F.B.I. director, and other senior bureau officials.

One of the biggest roars of applause of the entire Democratic convention went to Walter Mondale when in his acceptance speech he declared that "we reject....the idea that this nation must sit by passively while terrorists maim and murder innocent men, women and children."

PITTSBURGH, July 19--Dr. Samuel P. Harbison, admissions director of the University of Pittsburgh medical school, where he was a professor of surgery and former associate dean, died today in his home. He was 67 years old.

PASADENA, Calif., July 19-- The exploration of Mars by camera, soil scoop and life-detection instruments is scheduled to begin early tomorrow when the Viking 1 landing craft should be settling gently on a broad arid plain of the planet.
BUCHAREST, Rumania-- "We are stifling in silence," said one of Rumania's bestknown novelists. "I have no means of making my living."

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)--Legislation to make the hijacking of a bus a Federal offense with penalties comparable with those for airplane hijacking was introduced today by Representative Peter A. Peyser, Republican of Westchester.

This year's Mostly Mozart Festival is taking advantage of its more intimate surroundings in Tully Hall in a number of ways. Chamber music, of course, is getting extra attention, and a special series of six weekly piano recitals got under way on Sunday night with the joint appearance of Claude Frank and his wife, Lilian Kallir.

ASPEN, Colo.--One of William E. Colby's less exhilarating moments as Director of Central Intelligence was having to call a news conference to demand deletion from the Senate report on assassination plots of a dozen names, including such underworld figures as Sam Giancana and John Rosselli.

PARAGOMINAS, Brazil, July 14--In scenes vividly reminiscent of the taming of the American West, large landowner, squatters and Indians are pitted against each other in violent clashes as Brazil burns, hacks and plows its way through the Amazon jungles, an area two-thirds the size of the continental United States.

Governor Carey's legal staff said yesterday it planned to review the case of Roy W. Tate, a Long Island Rail Road engineer who was dismissed in 1973 after the passenger train he was operating hit a standing freight train at the Ronkonkoma station.

BETHESDA, Md., July 19-- Directors of breast cancer detection projects around the country defended today the continued use of an X-ray examination called mammography to screen ostensibly healthy women below the age of 50 years for hidden breast cancer.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 19 (AP)--A strike of several hundred carpenters continued into its sixth day in four upstate cities today with negotiations stalled.
DENPASAR, Indonesia, July 19 (AP)--The toll in the earthquake in Bali five days ago has risen to more than 500 people killed and 3,400 injured, the Governor's office reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) --The riverboat Delta Queen moved closer to five more years of life today with a House vote to extend her exemption from Federal laws that bar most wooden passenger vessels.

The New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that it had levied a $10,000 fine against one of its specialist firms for permitting the price of a listed stock to plunge nearly 50 percent in two hours without moving to halt trading because the market had become disorderly.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) --The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, T. David Mathews, said that an impasse continued over potential liability to manufacturers of vaccine for the proposed nationwide immunization program against swine flu.

PARIS, July 19--European television, after decades of staid if not stodgy presentation of the news, is rapidly developing--with a smile here and a smirk there and a nuance of inflection--its own newscasting personalities.

MUSCAT, Oman, July 19 (Reuters)--The Omani Government announced today that Britain would withdraw next March from air bases has used on Masira Island and at the southern town of Salala. The installations are Britain's last in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, July 19-- Jimmy Carter might not have won the Democratic Presidential nomination if the new campaign law had not imposed the first limits in American political history on the size of campain contributions.

MONTREAL, July, 19--John Naber won an Olympic gold medal in swimming tonight and broke a world record. Fifty-five minutes later, he almost won another gold medal (Bruce Furniss did) and almost broke another world record (Furniss did that, too).

A pair of former Niagara University roommates and basketball teammates were reunited yesterday when Frank Layden joined Hubie Brown as the assistant coach of the Atlanta Hawks of the National Basketball Association.

MONTREAL, July 19 (AP) --Women's basketball made its debut as an Olympic Games event today, with the United States losing the first game to Japan, 84-71, and with the Soviet Union unleashing a 7-foot-2-inch, 281pound center.

The United Technologies Corporation, the nation's largest producer of aircraft engines and elevators, reported yesterday profit increases of 29.2 percent for this year's second quarter and 26.9 percent for the first six months, reflecting a rise in sales of 52 percent for the quarter and 47 percent for the half.

MANILA, July 19 (Reuter)-- Eugene Torre of the Philippines today clinched an unexpected victory in a double round-robin chess tournament here by drawing his fifth-round match with the world champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, in 22 moves.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, July 19 (UPI)--Two Americans were slain yesterday by four Spanishspeaking pirates who boarded their crippled sailing sloop off the coast of Colombia, according to the Coast Guard. Two other Americans survived the early morning attack.

QIRYAT SHEMONA, Israel, July 19--Israel allowed shoppers from war-torn Lebanon through its formidable security fence today to shop in this border town, which has been intermittently shelled by guerrillas from Lebanese territory.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, July 19 (UPI)--Two Americans were slain yesterday by four Spanishspeaking pirates who boarded their crippled sailing sloop off the coast of Colombia, according to the Coast Guard. Two other Americans survived the early morning attack.

WASHINGTON, July 19--Atleast five foreign mutual funds have made preliminary approaches to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to sell their shares in this country, officials of the agency's investment management division said today.

PARIS, July 19--European television, after decades of staid if not stodgy presentation of the news, is rapidly developing--with a smile here and a smirk there and a nuance of inflection--its own newscasting personalities.

Walter W. Heller, a former economic adviser to President John F. Kennedy and President Lyndon B. Johnson, predicted yesterday a long sustained economic recovery in the United States without a serious resurgence of inflation.

At this critical time when Giulio Andreotti is striving to construct a Government capable of halting Italy's slide toward economic collapse, one major service that country's partners can perform is to refrain from public admonition and threats. It is even more important for allied governments to eschew such hectoring now than it was during the election campaign that brought further gains for the Italian Communist Party in the June balloting.

ROME, July 19 (AP)--The outgoing Italian Prime Minister, Aldo Moro, today accused the United States, West Germany, France and Britain of acting in an "improper way" when they reportedly agreed to deny aid to any Italian cabinet that included Communist members.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) --The Comptroller of the Currency proposed a regulation today that would prevent bank presidents and other high-ranking bank officials from making commissions on the sale of credit life insurance.

MORRISTOWN, July 19--In a highly unusual move, a Superior Court judge ordered today the release of the name of a confidential police informant whose tip was used by three detectives to arrest falsely a Wharton man on bookmaking charges in 1970.

Three Cavendish Club experts, Mike Moss, Amos Kaminski and Tom Smith, teamed with a Philadelphian star, Ken Cohen, and captured the Fun City regional knockout team title at the New York Hilton Hotel Sunday night.

LOS ANGELES, July 19-- Everyone in the Reagan campaign but Ronald Reagan himself stepped forward today to deny reports that they are losing hope in the cliff-hanging struggle with President Ford. Mr. Reagan, who is said to be reading, resting and telephoning Republican convention delegates from his Santa Barbara ranch, kept his public silence.

Pat Zachry, who spent six seasons in the minor leagues before he made the Cincinnati training-camp roster this spring, held the hard-hitting Pirates to five hits last night as the Reds scored a 4-2 victory in Pittsburgh's Three Rivers Stadium.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 19 (UPI) --The Nassau County Consumer Affairs Commissioner, James E. Picken, said today that inspectors from his office, in response to complaints, had found 65 cans of Star-Kist tuna that were short-weighted by up to 3/8 of an ounce.

MADERA, Calif., July 19-- Law enforcement officials investigating the kidnapping last Thursday from nearby Chowchilla of 26 summer school students and their bus driver said today they believed they knew the identities of the abductors. They said they expected to make at least one arrest very soon.

MONTREAL, July 19--The long history of Olympic controversy took a bizarre turn today when a star Soviet athlete was disqualified after he had been caught using an illegal electronic device in his epee in the fencing event of the modern pentathlon.

MONTREAL, July 19 (UPI) --The International Olympic Committee, in a move to stop future governmental influence in its affairs, passed a rule today giving the committee on-the-spot power to expel nations that break I.O.C. rules. The rule, headed "supreme authority." would apply to countries withdrawing from competition on political grounds.
WASHINGTON, July 19-- Housing starts rose moderately in June as the long-sluggish sector of apartment house building continued its slow rebound, the Commerce Department reported today.
HAVANA, July 19 (Reuters) --President Agostinho Neto of Angola will visit Cuba soon at the invitation of Prime Minister Fidel Castro, it was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) --White House officials said today that President Ford had installed two former New York television experts, Don Penny and Daniel Fitzgerald, as his new television advisers.
TAMPICO, Mexico, July 19 (UPI)--Thousands of persons today fled the flooding Panuco and Tamesi rivers, swollen by more than 13 days of rain that has taken a heavy toll of life and property.
The Mets lost Dave Kingman, the major leagues' leading slugger, for at least six weeks when the outfielder tore a ligament in his left thumb trying for a diving catch last night at Shea Stadium.

Major league baseball's owners have voted to ratify the four-year agreement with the Players Association that was reached during last week's All-Star break, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn announced yesterday.
PEKING, July 19 (Reuters)-- Wall posters have been pasted up in Nanking strongly attacking provincial leaders, travelers arriving here reported today.

PASADENA, Calif., July 19-- Radio astronomers in Maryland, California, Australia and the Soviet Union have banded together to form an observing system as wide as the earth. It is capable of determining the angular width of objects as narrow as a human hair 100 miles away.

BRUSSELS, July 19 (UPI)-- Lack of interest in gold pushed its price down almost $4 an ounce today to its lowest level in 31 months. Dealers forecast it would drop even further by the end of the month.

VIENTIANE, Laos, July 19 (Agence France-Presse)--The Government has invited the Thai Foreign Minister, Pichai Rattakul, to visit Laos, a move that is expected to help bring about the normalization of relations that have been frozen for nearly a year.
With so many genuine and difficult problems confronting the nation, it would be most unfortunate if the 1976 Presidential campaign should degenerate into an ideological slugfest.

The American eel, Anguilla rostrata, largely shunned by residents of the United States, is reaching the dining tables of Europe, where its cousin, Anguilla anguilla, has been a gourmet food for centuries.
HARTFORD, July 19--The Democratic state chairman in Connecticut, William A. O'Neill, won re-election by a wide margin tonight despite the determination of Gov--Ella T. Grasso to remove him.

The General Telephone Electronics Corporation, the second largest telephone company, reported yesterday that its earnings in the six months ended June 30 rose to $180.9 ended June 30 rose to $194.1 million from $168.7 million on a sales increase of 13 percent to $3.2 billion from $2.8 billion.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) --The Public Broadcasting Service announced today it had received a grant of $1.55 million to help public television stations put into use their planned satellite interconnection system.

PASADENA, Calif., July 19-- The exploration of Mars by camera, soil scoop and life-detection instruments is scheduled to begin early tomorrow when the Viking 1 landing craft should be settling gently on a broad arid plain of the planet.

CHICAGO, July 19 (Reuters) --The Midwest Stock Exchange said today its board of governors had approved a plan to create 200 new options trading memberships and give each of its 435 members the right to purchase options trading privileges.

WASHINGTON, July 19--A four-month, $150,000 investigation has narrowed the search but has not yet found the person who made an unauthorized disclosure of the report of the House Select Committee on Intelligence, a House investigator testified today.
A spate of selling on inflation fears brought prices lower on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter markets yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) --If the Jimmy Carter family moves to Washington after the November elections, 8-year-old Amy Carter may be sent to the oldest public school in the District of Columbia.

BIEL, Switzerland, July 17 --Robert Huebner of West Germany and Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, shared the lead with 3 points each after five rounds of the Interzonal Tournament. However, they are sure to be overtaken by four other contenders upon the completion of adjourned games.
An expatriate New Yorker has sent the city $5,000 of her own retirement money in gratitude for some old-age welfare and as a boost to the city in "coming out of the red."

PARIS, July 19--The future King of France, Louis Philippe, Duke of Orleans, was 24 years old when he and his two younger brothers, the Duke of Montpensier and the Count of Beaujolais, with their manservant Beaudoin, visited the United States in 1797.

The Blue Cross Association said yesterday that the "recent sharply rising cancer death rate" in this country and rising costs of health care had spurred it to take a first step toward providing coverage for screening tests to diagnose malignant tumors at an earlier stage among its nearly 90 million subscribers.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 19 (UPI)--Representative Allan Howe went on trial today on charges of soliciting as a result of allegedly offering $20 to two policewomen posing as prostitutes. City Judge Raymond S. Uno ordered the questioning of 50 prospective jurors conducted in his chambers "due to the nature of the case."

Msgr. Henry J. Watterson, pastor emeritus of Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church, Westfield, N.J., died Friday at the age of 101 in a nursing home in Scotch Plains, N.J. He had retired in 1968 after serving as pastor for 55 years.

CLOUDLAND Tonight through Aug. 1, high on the 65th floor at Rockefeller Center, the sophisticated splendor of the Rainbow Room will house dance music by Bobby Rosengarden and his band, with vocals by Maxine Sullivan of latter-day "Loch Lomond" fame. A reviewer for The New York Times has written that the music by Mr. Rosengarden, the maestro drummer, "represents the ultimate polishing of the Swing Era ideal."

WASHINGTON, July 19--A former top United States representative to the United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea has charged the Ford Administration with "a failure of leadership" in those negotiations and with having violated American treaty obligations.

TRENTON, July 19--The State Department of Labor and Industry sued two South Jersey poultry farmers today, charging them with exploitation of nine workers by housing them in converted chicken coops and illegally deducting excesive rent from their pay.

BOSTON, July 19 (UPI)-- Darrell Johnson, who led the Boston Red Sox to the American League pennant last year, was dismissed as manager today. Don Zimmer, third-base coach, was named to take over for the rest of the season.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., July 19 (AP)--George Geschwendt was convicted of six counts of firstdegree murder today in the killing of a suburban Philadelphia family last March. The verdicts were returned by the Bucks County Common Pleas Court. He faces a sentence of either death or life in prison.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (Reuters)--The United States is preparing a formal offer to sell 21 F-5E jet fighters to Singapore, informed Government sources said today.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI)--President Ford announced today that he was nominating Juanita Ashcraft, a former assisant appointments secretary to former Gov. Ronald Reagan, of California, as Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for manpower and reserve affairs.

WASHINGTON, July 19-- Pledging "all-out support," the A.F.L.-C.I.O. abandoned its neutral political posture today and endorsed the Democratic ticket of Jimmy Carter for President and Walter F. Mondale for Vice President.

The New York Health Department has named 10 more food businesses for failing a health code inspection and warned that closing orders could result if violations persisted upon a final visit by its inspectors. The names of the establishments and the actions cited follow:

WASHINGTON, July 19-- Ronald Reagan has the support of 1,140 delegates to the Republican National Convention, or 10 more than a majority, the executive vice chairman of his campaign, John P. Sears, said today.
PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 19--The Giants, admitted Ray Wietecha today, "were in limbo the last few years."
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) --The United States announced today the signing of an agreement in principle with the Soviet Union designed to curtail Russian undercutting of United States shipping charges.
Robert Morse, former news bureau chief for Life magazine, was drowned Friday near his home in Poros, Greece, according to word reaching his brother in Oregon. He was 54 years old.

The North River sewage-treatment plant probably will not provide the kind of treatment that was intended--if it is ever built at all.
VANCOUVER, British Columbia, July 19 (UPI)--Three members of a Canadian antiwhaling protest mission, Greenpeace confronted Soviet harpoonists 1,400 miles southwest of San Francisco today and won.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)--Two upsets marked the opening round of the $125,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament today.

At least nine persons have called in about winning tickets in the belated drawing Friday that completed last Octobers' lottery, John Quinn, director of the New York State Lottery, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- President Ford, apparently yielding to intense political pressure, nominated today Patrick J. Delaney, the son of a powerful New York Congressman, to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CHICAGO, July 20--The Chicago White Sox played Scott Joplin's ragtime music and gave away copies of E.L. Doctorow's novel "Ragtime," tonight. Their opponents, the New York Yankees, quickly caught the spirit of the Bill Veeck promotion and enjoyed a raggedy time.
The Bristol-Myers Company reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the second quarter and first half of 1976.

MADERA, Calif., July 20-- The 25-foot tractor trailer in which 26 pupils and their bus driver were held captive after their kidnapping last Thursday was extracted today from the Alameda County quarry, 100 miles northwest of here, and taken to the country crime laboratory.

Jimmy Carter, like Senator George McGovern four years ago, won the Democratic Party's Presidential nomination with no help from George Meany and most of his colleagues in the organized labor movement. But there the similarity ends.
Heavy volume and sharp price changes marked trading on most of the nation's commodity futures exchanges yesterday.
Stan Malless, president of the United States Tennis Association, voiced pessimism yesterday about the future of international Davis Cup competition.

DEARBORN, Mich. July 20-- Ken Bannon, the head of the United Automobile Workers Ford Department, said today that a key issue in the bargaining with the Ford Motor Company was that of finding a way to protect workers from the loss of jobs through imports and outside contractors.
Citing its fiscal situation, New York City yesterday cut off public funds for 49 daycare centers serving more than 3,000 children.
PARIS, July 19--During the economic crisis of the last three years, France has been the only major industrial Democracy where wage rises have outpaced price increases.
Faced with a court injunction, protesting parents and community representatives yesterday left the offices of Community School Board 5 in Harlem, where they had conducted a sit-in since June 7.
CINCINNATI, July 20--The New York Mets traded Del Unser and Wayne Garrett to the Montreal Expos tonight for Pepe Mangual, an outfielder, and Jim Dwyer, a left-handed-hitting outfielder.
More New York City prostitutes were sentenced to jail terms in the last 30 days than in any comparable period so far this year, according to Police Department statistics released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- Russell B. Long, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, promised today to give the panel a new opportunity to vote for or against each of 73 provisions of the pending tax bill, most of which benefit just one company or industry.
TRENTON, July 20--The State Economic Development Authority approved today $11 million in business expansion loans, including one that Governor Byrne said could "revitalize" the city of Passaic.

The Suffolk County Legislature unexpectedly rejected late yesterday a proposal under which work would have been halted on the county's controversial $1.5 billion Southwest Sewer District so that it could be redesigned in scope.

LOS ANGELES, July 20--A 1974 newspaper describing the ordeal of the Hearst family two days after their daughter, Patricia, was kidnapped, was smuggled into a jury room in a maximum security courtroom where William and Emily Harris, members of the revolutionary group that abducted the publishing heiress, are now on trial.

CINCINNATI, July 20-- Will the injury to Dave Kingman stymie the weak attack of the New York Mets? Will the Mets' pitching staff start to press to make up for fewer runs? Will the loss of Kingman for the next six weeks put a crimp in the Mets' will to win?
WASHINGTON, July 20--President Ford gained substantial delegate strength today to pull within 18 votes of the total needed to gain a first-ballot nomination at the Repub lican National Convention.
MOSCOW, July 20 (AP)--The Soviet Union published a decree today that permits Government officials to deal directly with foreign journalists.
HOUSTON, July 20 (AP)-- America's Viking 1 space robot landed on Mars today seven years to the day after two Apollo astronauts stepped from their spacecraft and put man's footprints on the moon.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday reinstated perjury indictments obtained by Maurice H. Nadjari against Judge Paul P. Rao Sr. of United States Customs Court; his son, Paul Jr., and another lawyer, Salvatore Nigrone.
SAN DIEGO, July 20 (UPI)-- A Marine drill sergeant was found guilty yesterday of dereliction of duty in the pugil-stick death of Pvt. Lynn McClure, a 20-year-old recruit fatally beaten in training.

WASHINGTON, (UPI)--The United State Department of Agriculture says meat processors who sell combinations of products such as ham and soy protein must now tell consumers how much meat the foods contain.
VATICAN CITY, July 20 (AP)-- The Vatican, which has said that modern art is one of Pope Paul VI's favorites, is showing a special exhibition of American spiritual works.
The 1,200-room McAlpin Hotel on Herald Square was sold yesterday to a group of builder-developers and a member concern of the New York Stock Exchange for conversion to rental apartments.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday reinstated perjury indictments obtained by Maurice H. Nadjari against Judge Paul P. Rao Sr. of United States Customs Court; his son, Paul Jr., and another lawyer, Salvatore Nigrone.

PASADENA, Calif., July 20-- An explorer from Earth, the robot craft Viking 1, made the first successful landing on Mars today, and transmitted spectacular photographs of a rocky, wind-scoured desert plain, the site for the first direct search for life on another world.

Two Republicans, acting separately, have challenged the petitions filed by Representative Peter A. Peyser for a place on the Sept. 14 primary ballot in an effort to bar him from opposing Senator James L. Buckley, Conservative-Republican, for the Republican nomination for Senator.
Kenneth L. Brody, assistant administrator of the city's Human Resources Administration, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Teaneck, N.J. He was 45 years old.
VARNA, Bulgaria, July 20 (Reuters) -- Three American dancers and one Canadian have reached the final round of a 27-country international ballet competition in this Black Sea resort.

TOKYO, July 20--The Tokyo High Court reversed a lower court verdict today and gave a former reporter of a major Japanese newspaper a suspended four-month prison sentence on charges of illegally obtaining secret Foreign Ministry documents.
PARIS, July 20--When a clerk tried to open the vault of the Societe Generale bank in Nice yesterday, he found that the door was welded shut--from the inside.

WASHINGTON, July 20--The first publicly financed Presidential election in American history was formally set in motion today with approval of a Treasury Department grant of $21,820,000 to the Democratic candidates, Jimmy Carter and Walter F. Mondale.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)--President and Mrs. Ford staged their main Bicentennial event tonight with an American music concert under a tent in the Rose Garden.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has purchased two buildings from the Naw Lincoln School on 82d Street off Fifth Avenue to house administrative and curatorial offices while it completes its building program in Central Park.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) --Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, told the House Ethics Committee today that he had lent a copy of a Congressional report critical of intelligence activities to the Central Intelligence Agency and had let a news agency reporter look at a few pages of the report.
TRENTON, July 20-- Governor Byrne re-emphasized today his interest in the process by which electricity is generated with previously wasted steam.

MONTEREY, Calif., July 20 (AP)--Broadcasters should fight to preserve freedom of the press "not for themselves, but for the people we serve," the chairman of the National Association of Broadcasters said yesterday.

The technology seems to be taken for granted by everybody except some of the artists who experiment with the medium and define its ingredients in various video environments. But occasionally broadcasting explodes with the extraordinary event, and the phenomenon of pure technology is given a fresh impact. This week is providing two outstanding examples: the Viking I pictures being sent from Mars and the pictorial coverage of the Summer Olympics in Montreal.
NEW DELHI, July 20 (UPI)-- A Portuguese ambassador joined New Delhi's diplomatic community yesterday for the first time in two decades.

A fireworks display over Central Park's Sheep Meadow will highlight the New York Philharmonic's concert on Tuesday night. Aug. 3, when the orchestra's 12th season of free programs in the city's parks opens. Andre Kostelanetz will conduct the first week of the three-week series, followed by Thomas Schippers and Erich Leinsdorf.
HACKENSACK, July 20-- Representatives of the motion picture industry rallied today behind New Jersey's effort to re-establish itself as a filmmaking center.

The presidents of 53 postal unions voted here today for a nationwide job action by Aug. 20 unless the United States Postal Service declared a moratorium on service cutbacks that the union leaders said were crippling mail service, United Press International reported.

JOHANNESBURG, July 20-- At least one black man was reported killed tonight when police reinforcements were rushed to the coal-mining center of Witbank, 75 miles east of here, which was in the grip of the most serious rioting since the widespread anti-Government upheavals last month.

WASHINGTON, July 20--Key members of the Senate Government Operations Committee agreed informally today to go along with President Ford's proposal for creation of a permanent special prosecutor's office to investigate wrongdoing by Federal officials.

LONDON, July 20--Unfavorable economic news, political warfare on the Government's left and right, and trade union anger at proposed cuts in public spending drove the British Cabinet into a series of emergency meetings today and caused turmoil in Parliament.
LONDON, July 20--The turmoil that has been swirling through many nations' currencies has now swept into gold, long a major component, along with the dollar, of the world's monetary reserves.

For a violinist, the lure of a conducting career must be especially powerful. Conductors, after all, seem to go on forever, and are considered merely in the ripening stage at an age when most violinists have had to retire. That, of course, says something about the relative difficulty of conducting and playing the violin.
Thomas J. Brady, who retired in 1961 as a New York City stock broker, died Monday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 81 years old, and had moved to Scottsdale on his retirement.
PITTSBURGH, July 20 (AP) --Three electrical workers unions staging a nationwide strike against the Westinghouse Electric Corporation agreed today to new three-year contracts.

The BankAmerica Corporation in San Francisco and Citicorp in New York, the nation's two largest bank holding companies, reported yesterday that their second-quarter operationg earnings climbed to record levels.

"Ship me somewheres east of Suez," sang Rudyard Kipling's soldier in the high noon of the British Empire. There is no place to ship him now. The last units of the British Army' are being withdrawn from Oman, completing the dismantling of the once elaborate military structure in the Middle East.

PLAINS, Ga. July 20--Jimmy Carter sharply disagreed today with President Ford's 1974 pardon of President Nixon before what the Democratic nominee termed Mr. Nixon's "inevitable conviction" in an "open trial."

The police yesterday were investigating the complaints of 25 people who said they had been the victims of robberies and assaults during, a jazz-rock concert Monday night at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park's Wollman arena.

Charging that untreated sewage from New York City has endangered Long Island's beaches and residential communities, the Town of Hempstead filed suit in State Supreme Court in Mineola, L.I., yesterday to ask for an end to the alleged dumping of effluents and to demand $10 million in damages reportedly resulting from sludge that coated nearly 90 miles of South Shore beaches last month.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 20 (Reuters)--A nightclub and a restaurant in Salisbury's city center were attacked with hand grenades tonight.
Cows, in truth, are not beasts of beauty. But that has not deterred the Queens Museum from gathering a herd of them--in pigment, porcelain, wood and stone-- for a show called "Cows."
WASHINGTON, July 20--The Nuclear Regulatory Commission was urged today to block further shipments of uranium fuel to India to combat the spread of nuclear weapons.

Trans World Airlines Inc. reported yesterday a preliminary corporate net profit of $24.4 million for June, a profit of $30.2 million for the second quarter and a loss of $15.6 million for the first half of the year.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 20--Yugoslav authorities made it known today they planned to release on Friday an American citizen imprisoned a year ago on espionage charges.
Sarah Chokla Gross, an editor and reviewer of children's books, died yesterday at South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside, L.I. She was 69 years old and lived in East Rockaway, L.I.

Playgirl magazine, the publication that offers male nudity to its women readers, is doing something else that is unusual. It is going after subscribers through daily newspaper ads and, according to Ira E. Ritter, its 27year-old executive vice president, it is doing extremely well, even in such places as Des Moines, Denver, Sacramento, and Kansas City.

The doubts expressed in Washington yesterday that New York City will be able to survive fiscally after expiration of the Federal loan program in June 1978, plus persisting uncertainties about the financial plan that is supposed to produce a balanced municipal budget by that time, more than justify Municipal Assistance Corporation Chairman Felix G. Rohatyn's efforts to "stretch out" $1.8 billion in M.A.C. bonds.
BANGKOK, Thailand, July 20 --The United States completed its military withdrawal from Thailand today, ending a 26year military presence here.
MONTREAL, July 20--It was a day like all other days today at the Olympic swimming pool. The American men and East German women won all the gold medals and all in world-record time.
Earnings of the Union Carbide Corporation rebounded in the second quarter with a 19.8 percent increase from the yearearlier level, following an 11 percent decline in the first quarter.
Albin A. Barthelson, a graphic arts designer, died Saturday of injuries received in un automobile accident. He was 51 years old and lived in Englewood, N.J.

Myer B Marcus, chairman of the board of Food Fair Stores and an innovator in food merchandising, died yesterday at the Albert Linstein Medical Center in Philadelphia, Pa. He was 68 and lived in BalaCynwyd, Pa.

ATTICA, N.Y., July 20--The chief of a State Commission of Correction team sent into the Attica prison last week following the most recent outbreak of violence there described conditions within the facility today as "just as bad, perhaps worse" than in September 1971, just before an inmate rebellion that resulted in the deaths of 43 persons.

PASADENA, CALIF., July 20--When President Ford telephoned today to congratulate the Viking flight team, just as the Viking 1 landing craft was transmitting its first panoramic view of the landscape at Chryse, he asked the Project Manager, James Martin, what type of camera had sent back the first photographs from the surface of Mars.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 20-- About 20,000 cannery workers in northern California walked off their jobs today in a contract dispute in the middle of the state's fruit and vegetable harvesting season.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)--Jimmy Connors and Arthur Ashe scored firstround victories tonight in the $125,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament. Vijay Amitraj of India was beaten by Mike Cahill of Wisconsin, 6-4, 7-6.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- Russell B. Long, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, promised today to give the panel a new opportunity to vote for or against each of 73 provisions of the pending tax bill, most of which benefit just one company or industry.

The Federal judge in charge of overseeing professional basketball's antitrust lawsuit said yesterday that negotiations between the National Basketball Association and its players had reached an impasse, endangering the merger between the N.B.A. and the American Basketball Association.

A Spanish couple traveling in the upper Middle West whose child was bitten by an animal dialed a toll-free number and within minutes were able to speak in their own language to a doctor who could treat the child.

PASADENA, Calif., July 20-- The first definitive analysis of the Martian atmosphere has disclosed the presence of a small component of nitrogen. Until now the absence of any evidence of that gas stood as a major obstacle to speculation that life might exist on the planet.

Dear Pensioner: This is to advise you that as of January 1, 1976, pensioners will no longer be covered for all Welfare benefits; this includes hospitalization, medical, surgical, major medical, dental, optical and mortuary coverages. This decision was regretfully reached by the Trustees because of the excessive unemployment and the severe depression in the construction industry. Sincerely yours, Administrator, Local No. 1"

PASADENA, Calif., July 20-- An explorer from Earth, the robot craft Viking 1, made the first successful landing on Mars today and transmitted spectacular photographs of a rocky, wind-scoured desert plain, the site for the first direct search for life on another world.

NEW BRUNSWICK,July 20 --St. Peter's Hospital here has made a substantial commitment to advance radiation therapy for cancer patients by purchasing a linear accelerator, which emits high-energy electron and X-ray beams for treating tumors.

Posing as a city employee, an unemployed Bronx woman was said by the police last night to have bilked "500 people out of more than $100,000" by collecting rents in advance for apartments that were never provided.

CHAPPAQUA. N.Y.--For Melissa, 20, Sarah, 18, and Andy Young, 16, home is not just a neat, smallish white house in suburban Westchester with a cat that can open the refrigerator door. It is a combination of Noah's Ark, the Bronx Zoo and Jungle World and a serious, continuing education in animal behavior and the sanctity of living things.

State Comptroller Arthur Levitt released another of his critiques of government agencies yesterday, using his impersonal, numbers-studded style to deliver what some politicians took as a significant message: Don't mess with the master.
The Canadians are coming! Indeed they have come. The National Ballet of Canada, with its resident guru, Rudolf Nureyev, arrived at the Metropolitan Opera House last night for a three-week stay.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- Congressional investigators have issued a blistering indictment of the Food and Drug Administration, pharmaceutical makers, doctors and research scientists, charging them with exposing humans to unnecessary risks in testing new drugs.

MONTREAL, July 20-- Even if Nadia Comaneci of Rumania fails to produce a fourth perfect score in the remaining two days of the women's Olympic gynamastics competition, her performance here is certain to carry considerable impact, particularly in the United States.

Dr. J. Robert Buchanan, dean of Cornell University Medical College here since 1969, was named yesterday to be president of Chicago's Michael Reese Hospital and Medical Center beginning Jan. 1. The hospital has a teaching relationship to the University of Chicago medical school similar to that of New York Hospital to Cornell.
A Manhattan man was shot and killed last night in a Lexington Avenue bar half an hour after he and six other mourners had attended a wake for a friend at a funeral home across the street.

MUSIC IN THE AIR Summer in New York means music in the streets. PreWorld War II jazz will be performed by Richard Sudhalter, cornetist; Bucky Pizzarelli guitarist; Major Holley, bassist, and Bobby Rosengarden, drummer, today from 4:30 to 6 P.M. in Exxon Park. The park is really the little plaza behind the Exxon Building, which is on the Avenue of the Americas between 49th and 50th Streets. The rain date is tomorrow.

JOHANNESBURG, July 20-- At least one black man was reported killed tonight when police reinforcements were rushed to the coal-mining center of Witbank, 75 miles east of here, which was in the grip of the most serious rioting since the widespread anti-Government upheavals last month.

LOS ANGELES, July 20--A too-bountiful sun has generated a huge surplus of fruit and other crops in California this summer, and the glut of fruit was aggravated today when the Teamsters Union struck the state's 78 canneries.

WHITE PLAINS, July 20-- Westchester County, responding to increasing utility costs, moved today to "withdraw as a whole from the Consolidated Edison system" as soon as an adequate alternatve source of power can be found.

Reports said about 3,000 black youths had poured out of black townships and attacked people and buildings in areas occupied by Indians and people of mixed descent.

Except for the police helicopter circling overhead and the five-spray salute from a fireboat, it might have been almost any group of revelers who jammed the decks of a Circle Line party boat for last night's three-hour cruise.
PARIS, July 20--When a clerk tried to open the vault of the Societe Generale bank in Nice yesterday, he found that the door was welded shut--from the inside.
LOUISVILLE. Ky., July 20 (AP)--"It's downright disgusting." scientist J. Richard Keefe said after Viking 1 began sending back vivid photographs from the planet Mars. "I'm rather steamed about it."

MONTREAL, July 20 (AP) -The United States picked up another gold medal in the Olympics today when 29year-old Don Haldeman of Souderton, Pa., won the trap shooting championship. But a United States eight-oared crew failed for the first time in Olympic history to reach the rowing final.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 20--A securities salesman who allegedly swindled 20 investors out of more than $103,000 through the sale of bogus silver future options was charged with grand larceny today.

Ivan Morris, a linguist, writer, translator, critic and former chairman of the department of East Asian languages and cultures at Columbia University, died of a heart attack on Monday night in Bologna, Italy. He was 50 years old and lived at 173 Riverside Drive.
VICTORIA, British Columbia, July 20 (AP)--Race Passage, a 44-foot sloop, was declared over-all winner today of the 2,308-mile Victoria-to-Maui yacht race.

WASHINGTON, July 20--The chairman of a House economic subcommittee warned today that he foresaw "serious problems" affecting New York City's economic recovery, after the Federal loan program ended in July 1978.

The cost of feeding a family of four in New York City has remained "fairly stable" for the last month even though last week it increased 2 percent above the previous week's level, the Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday.

GUARDPOST OUELLETTE, Demilitarized Zone, South Korea, July 20--Pfc. Thomas Tucker and the other men of this isolated lookout donned their flak jackets, grabbed their M-16's and put on their steel helmets as usual.

CAIRO, July 15--Experts from New York and Cairo musuems, examining the jewelry of the ancient Egyptian King Tutankhamen, have found that many stones that were earlier reported to be costly lapis lazuli and turquoise are in fact pieces of colored glass.

MONTREAL, July 20-- Black athletes on the United States Olympic team expressed sympathy today for the African countries pulling out of the Games but indicated that they would not join the exodus or otherwise rock the boat.
Citing its fiscal situation, New York City yesterday cut off public funds for 49 daycare centers serving more than 3,000 children.
BUENOS AIRES, July 20-- The Argentine Army announced today that security forces had killed the leader of the principal leftist guerrilla group in the country and several of his aides.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. is pushing Ronald Reagan for the Republican Vice-Presidential nomination--but not too hard.
PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 20--The veterans have been in camp a week now and Dave Jennings's right leg is tired.

Considering the overwhelming popularity of this French import, it's no wonder that a subindustry is developing around it to overcome the minor problems it initiates.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., July 20--It costs as much as $80,000 to acquire and prepare a powerboat for the Benihana Grand Prix offshore race, which will be run here tomorrow in the waters between Asbury Park and Barnegat Light for prizes totaling nearly $16,000. Dr. Maurice H. Herzmark, a Washington orthopedic surgeon, died yesterday at George Washington University Hospital in the capital, where he lived. He was 70 years old.

HARTFORD, July 20--Gov. Elia T. Grasso of Connecticut, who tried and failed last night to remove William A. O'Neill as Democratic state chairman, now finds herself isolated from both the legislature and the party. And, political leaders say, her failure has opened the way for extensive changes in personnel at the highest levels of the party organization.
Stock prices moved lower yesterday for the sixth session in a row as most precious metal issues--which generally climb when the rest of the market slumps--joined the downtrend.
WASHINGTON, July 20--The nation's economy grew in this year's second quarter at less than half the rapid pace of the first quarter, the Commerce Department estimated today.
A federally financed mayoral task force has found that New York City is not adequately prepared to deal with fire, police and natural emergencies.

After heated debate and seven ballots, Democrats in Connecticut's Fourth Congressional District early this morning selected Charles B. Tisdale of Bridgeport to oppose the Republican incumbent, Representative Stewart B. McKinney. United Press International reported.
A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday denied a motion by a senior at the Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point to enjoin the Academy from dismissing or suspending him.

LONDON, July 20 (Reuters) --Martha Graham and her dancers were acclaimed last night at the Royal Opera House, home of the Royal Ballet, where her 50-year-old company is making its first appearance for a two-week season.

Randy Jones of the San Diego Padres admits he does not have much of a fastcall. But he does have two devious pitches, a slider and a sinker. He also works fast, a rarity in these days of baseball players who are conscious of television cameras.

PASADENA, Calif., July 20-- The first definitive analysis of the Martian atmosphere has provided long-sought clues to the planet's history, including the possibility that enough water is hidden beneath its surface to cover the planet one mile deep.

Prices once again moved lower on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market. The Amex market value index closed at 104.42, down 0.78, while the NASDAQ industrial index ended at 97.08. off 0.51.

In what it termed "a landmark agreement," the American Jewish Committee announced yesterday that the Pennsylvania Human Relations Commission and the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company, in Philadelphia, had agreed that the insurance company would "broaden the involvement of Jews in the management of the concern."

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) --The Director of the F.B.I., Clarence M. Kelley, today appointed Richard G. Held as associate director, the secondhighest position in the bureau. He will replace Nicholas P. Callahan, who was dismissed last Friday in the course of a Justice Department investigation of alleged financial improprieties and other misdeeds involving bureau officials.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 20--A proposed Latin American and Caribbean news agency, or group of agencies, was approved today by a committee at a regional communications conference here sponsored by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

WARSAW, July 20 (AP)-- Thirteen workers have been sentenced to prison terms ranging from three to ten years for their part in riots last month that forced the Polish Government to withdraw food-price increases.
HOUSTON, July 20--John B. Connally says that he would consider accepting the Republican Vice-Presidential nomination only if he was assured that he could play a large role in the administration.

The Buffalo Bills, at least, are taking O.J. Simpson at his word--they have dropped him and the four pages he took up from their yearbook.
A subway token clerk, a conductor and four other men were accused yesterday of stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars in cash and tokens in subway station robberies over the last six years.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 20-- Efforts to get Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization to negotiate an end to their hostilities in Lebanon hung in the balance today as some P.L.O. leaders reportedly balked at the timing, and conditions of the proposed talks.

American space scientists and engineers yesterday registered another superb and historic achievement.

The Scottish National Orchestra Chorus, which is making its first United States tour as a contribution to our Bicentennial observance, gave a concert at St. Bartholomew's Church on Monday night. This was the group's only "solo" appearance. Otherwise, it is devoting itself to concerts with orchestras, including the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the Cleveland Orchestra and the Chicago Symphony.

More than 100 New York Republican delegates are scheduled for a session of light elbow bending and gentle arm twisting at the White House tomorrow as President Ford step-up pressure on the New York delegation, which is largely, but not completely, committed to him.

Precisely bisected by the line between Brooklyn and Queens there is a piece of land that used to show on city maps as "Eldert Street." The street was mapped but never built. Instead it is a nondescript no man's land of 20,000 square feet alongside the 86,000-square-foot whitebrick home of Lahm Knitting Mill Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- The Aviation Consumer Action Project, one of Ralph Nader's many offspring, has opened a campaign to cut ticket prices on the Eastern Air Lines shuttle linking Boston, New York and Washington.

MONTREAL, July 20--The United States men's basketball team survived a 35-point performance from a New Yorker, Butch Lee, and outlasted Puerto Rico, 95-94, today in a furious game that was not settled until the final seconds.
PARIS, July 20--Paris is getting nervous about crime in its subway system.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 20 (AP)--A group of young Burmese military officers tried to kill President Ne Win and two senior officials in an attempted coup earlier this month, the Rangoon radio said today.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- Congressional investigators have issued a blistering indictment of the Food and Drug Administration, pharmaceutical makers, doctors and research scientists, charging them with exposing humans to unnecessary risks in testing new drugs.
MONTREAL, July 20-- Egypt and Morocco withdrew from the strife-torn Olympic Games today, joining a boycott that now encompasses virtually the entire African continent.

When the Consolidated Edison Company omitted its customary 45-cent-a-share quarterly dividend in April 1974, it dropped a bombshell in the investment community and jarred the utility stocks, generally. It marked the first dividend omission by Con Ed since 1885.

PARIS--King Juan Carlos's choice as his first personally selected Prime Minister, Adolfo Suarez Gonzalez, might conceivably be likened to General de Gaulle's selection of his first Prime Minister, Michel Debra. Mr. Debre, known for advocacy of French rule in Algeria, was brutally forced by de Gaulle to lead a governmental policy designed to shed such rule.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 20 (UPI)--A chestnut colt sired by the 1973 Triple Crown winner. Secretariat, sold for $1.5 million tonight at the Keeneland race course summer yearling sale, setting a world record. The colt, out of Charming Alibi, was purchased by Canadians from the consignment of Nelson Bunker Hunt's Bluegrass Farm.

NEWARK, July 20 (AP)-- New Jersey had 7 percent more crime in 1975 than in 1974, with the greatest increase occurring in rural areas, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said in a report released today.
