Viking 1 is down on the Chryse Planitia, the Golden Plain. Alas for Shakespeare, that plain does not much resemble "An eye like Mars, to threaten and command." From the photographs, it looks more like Arizona with a hangover. Are we perhaps jaded?

Mirabai, who is performing in Reno Sweeney this week, has changed her image and improved as a singer and songwriter without really altering her style. When she began performing around town several years ago she was a willowy, long-haired folk singer with a strident, somewhat uncertain voice and a repertory of starryeyed songs. Now her hair is shorter and she dresses in a more stylish manner.

LOS ANGELES, July 21 A Superior Court judge refused yesterday to seal permanently the will of William Randolph Hearst because he said that would be tantamount to denying the public the right to know what was done in probate court.

MONTREAL, July 21 The American men continued to race away from the rest of the world in Olympic swimming today. They swept the medals in the 100-meter butterfly with Matt Vogel, Joe Bottom and Gary Hall. Then they won the 800-meter freestyle relay for the seventh straight United States gold medal in four days in the Olympic pool.

The Conference Board said yesterday that its index of consumer confidence which fell sharply in March and April, recovered moderately in May and June. In the latest period the index rose to 86.7 (1969-1970 equals 100), up 4.5 points from the March-April reading but down 6.6 points from January and February.

SAN, JOSE, Costa Rica, July 21 (AP) A proposal that Latin American and Caribbean governments determine what information should be distributed by satellite in their regions was approved here today at a United Nations-sponsored conference.
OCEANPORT, July 21 The veteran horseplayers at Monmouth Race Track responded today to Wanda Oughton as they probably would not have to a movie goddess.
The Boys Club of New York has put its 4,300 acres of Catskills wilderness up for sale. The land is the site of Camp Harriman, and the problem is that fewer and fewer boys go camping there every year.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) Speaker Carl Albert today named 15 members of a commission on administrative review that grew out of reforms that Demorats initiated to blunt the effects of sex-scandal allegations involving some members of the House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) Thousands of 1975 Ford, Chrysler and General Motors automobiles are polluting the air because dealers and drivers have misadjusted their carburetors, some apparently deliberately, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

Earle Combs, a member of baseball's Hall of Fame who was the leadoff man in the New York Yankee "Murderers' Row" batting order that featured Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig, died yesterday in Richmond, Ky., after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

After losing about 75 cents a bushel in the last four trading sessions, soybeans reversed their downtrend and moved up in price yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Traders called it a technical rally after the sharp decline.

DUBLIN, July 21 The British Ambassador to Ireland, Christopher T.E. Ewart-Biggs, was killed today when a land mine was detonated beneath his moving car, about 150 yards from his official residence on the southern outskirts of Dublin.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 21 (Reuters) Nearly half the 5,000 people who had been missing and feared killed in last month's earthquake and landslides in the remote Indonesian province of Irian Jaya have returned to their villages after fleeing info the jungles for safety, Antara news agency said today.
LONDON, July 21 Christopher T.E. Ewart-Biggs, the British Ambassador to Dublin, who was killed there today just two weeks after taking up the post, had lived in fear of violance before.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., July 21 You are going 70 miles an hour in the ocean off the New Jersey shore; you cannot see much because of fog and haze and you are racing a speedboat full of engines and gasoline. What do you do? You keep going, hoping for the best, relying on bouncing compasses and intuition.

In what officials called potentially the most important air-route decision in years, the Civil Aeronautics Board recommended yesterday that 11 additional metropolitan areas in the United States be permitted direct airline service to Europe.
They rummaged around in the spare room of musical history at the Mostly Mozart Festival on Tuesday night, and for a couple of hours the dust and cobwebs flew at Alice Tully Hall.

GENEVA, July 21 Developing countries are wary of a United States plan for an international trade code that would permit restrictions on imports causing injury to domestic industries without provoking retaliatory measures.
The Yankees, weary of traveling but not of winning, began a brief stay at Yankee Stadium last night and kept right on winning.
WASHINGTON, July 21 Ar thur F. Burns, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today he thought that the recent decline in the price of gold was "on balance a good thing."
The Marine Midland Bank announced a top-level management reorganization yesterday, apparently in preparation for naming a new president.

The chancellor of the City University of New York, following weeks of protests from Brooklyn and Queens Colleges that they were being cheated in budget allocations for this year, has decided to give more money to most of the senior colleges and the greater part of that to the two borough colleges.
Thousands of items, ranging from toilet paper (10 rolls for $1) to a large bar with rail ($350), went on sale yesterday "as is" at the 1,300-room Royal Manhattan Hotel.
Rick Waits, a left-hander, held the California Angels to seven hits and Charlie Spikes drove in three runs as the Cleveland Indians beat Nolan Ryan, 6-2, last night in Municipal Stadium.

WASHINGTON, July 21 The Mississippi delegation to the Republican National Convention, long regarded as a bulwark of Ronald Reagan's candidacy, was reported today to be on the verge of a decisive shift to President Ford.

The New York City Health Department has cited 14 more food businesses for failing a health-code inspection and warned that closing orders would result if violations persisted upon a final visit by its inspectors. The names of the establishments and the actions taken follow:
Texaco, the country's second largest oil company, announced yesterday that it had raised the price of gasoline by 1 cent a gallon, effective immediately.

The latest request by Consolidated Edison for an increase in electric rates was vehemently opposed yesterday at a hearing by six public officials who described the bid variously as "unnecessary," "arrogant," "unjustified" and "intolerable."
An artist, a lawyer and a stockbroker were accused yesterday in Manhattan of conspiring to deal in cocaine.

Roger E. Spear Sr., who for 50 years was identified with investment advisory operations centered in Babson Park, Mass., and who was the author of a widely syndicated newspaper column dealing with investment problems, died last Friday at his home in Weston, Mass. He was 77 years old.

Lucien S. Schmit, a cellist who first performed publicly at the age of 7 in Paris and who became a member of the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra at 13, died in Manhasset (L.I.) Hospital on Tuesday after a stroke. Mr. Schmit was 78 years old and lived at 78 Bourndale Road South, Manhasset.
WASHINGTON, July 21 The Treasury auctioned oneyear bills today at an average yield of 5.887 percent.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) John B. Connally is the top choice for Vice President of Republican delegates who named a candidate for the second spot, mainly because of strong support from those who favor Ronald Reagan for President.
PLAINS, Ga., July 21 Jimmy Carter, the Democratic Presidential nominee, will interrupt his working vacation at his home here tomorrow to fly to New York for the day.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 2l The three-part Junior regatta, which was a special series within the 78th Annual Larchmont Race Week, ended without enough wind for sailing on Long Island Sound today and prize winners were decided on the basis of Monday's and yesterday's races.

WASHINGTON, July 21 Elliot L. Richardson, a leading Republican moderate, asserted today that if conservatives dominate the party's convention, ticket and campaign, "the inevitable result will be to blow the election."

JOHANNESBURG, July 21 The Government acceded to pressure from the black community today and agreed to the immediate reopening of schools in the black townships near Johannesburg and Pretoria. They have been closed since the outbreak of anti-Government rioting last month.

More dead fish were reported yesterday in the New Jersey surf from Long Branch to Barnegat, and marine scientists expressed concern that the off shore fish kill, first noticed two weeks ago, had spread from Sandy Hook to Atlantic City.

The stock market plodded sluggishly along yesterday to post its first general advance in the last seven sessions. The Dow Jones industrial average closed with a gain of 1.15 at 989.44 after running ahead as much as 5.49 points earlier in the afternoon.

TRENTON, July 21 A spokesman for major oil companies said today that the companies were preparing to bid on leases for oil and natural gas off New Jersey and Delaware shores despite pending legal action aimed at stopping the lease sale scheduled for Aug. 17.

WASHINGTON, July 21 Herbert G.A. Woolley, who organized the training of frogmen in World War II, died Monday in Honolulu after a brief illness. Mr. Woolley, who was 80 years old, lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

Robert W. Kenny, who became Attorney General of California and also served as a judge even though he never finished law school, died Tuesday at Scripps Memorial Hospital in La Jolla, Calif. He Was 74 years old.
TRENTON, July 21 In an effort to rescue his sagging legislative program, Governor Byrne met today with Democratic leaders in his office.

LONDON, July 21 Prime Minister James Callaghan told a hushed House of Commons today that the killing of Ambassador Ewart-Biggs was "illustrative of the fact that hundreds of innocent men and women have been slaughtered on the altar of Ireland."
PITTSBURGH, July 21 (AP) Westinghouse plants struck by blue-collar workers began to reopen today as a new threeyear pact brought some employees back for the overnight shift.

NEW DELHI, July 21 With the exchange of Ambassadors and the resumption of passenger flights, India and Pakistan formally re-established normal relations today.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 21 The New York Jets found themselves today without a running back who had played a full game with the team. Steve Davis unexpectedly left trainine camp last night.

Mikhail A. Menshikov, the Soviet Ambassador in Washington during the Eisenhower and Kennedy administrations, has died in Moscow, the Soviet press reported yesterday. He was 73 years old.

THE Northrop Corporation, the diversified aerospace manufacturer that has been involved in payments scandals, reported yesterday a 78.2 percent increase in second-quarter earnings from the year-earlier level. Its backlog on June 30 of $2.47 billion was up 145 percent from a year ago.
Mayor Beame appointed seven new judges yesterday, including John Leone, the brother of Borough President Sebastian Leone of Brooklyn.

President Ford's nominee to head the White House Office of Science and Technology, which was recently established after three years of oblivion, will be H. Guyford Stever, director of the National Science Foundation for the last four years.

The addition of the Soviet Union's first aircraft carrier, the 40,000-ton Kiev, to the naval squadron in the Mediterranean Sea will mean a significant strengthening of that squadron's capabilities, according to United States Navy sources.

NICE, France, July 21 (AP) Amazement over the $12 million bank robbery here increased today as investigators disclosed that the thieves who had burrowed in from a sewer made an underground getaway by van and inflatable rafts.

In the largest single block of Federal mass transit grants ever awarded, Secretary of Transportation William T. Coleman Jr., announced yesterday the approval of $340 million in aid to seven cities, including $66.2 million for New York City.

DUBLIN, July 21 The British Ambassador to Ireland, Christopher T.E. Ewart-Biggs, was killed today when a land mine was detonated beneath his moving car, about 150 yards from his official residence on the southern outskirts of Dublin.
MONTREAL, July 22 Finals in the women's long jump and the men's 20- kilometer walk will highlight the start of track and field competition tomorrow at the Olympic Games.

Three of New York City's largest retailers--Macy's, Korvette and Alexander's--which collectively transact a billion dollars in annual sales in the area--are mapping plans for the first large-scale Sunday openings of department stores in the city and in the metropolitan area, starting possibly as early as Aug. 29.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 22 Jack Kiefer, the defender, made a rush at the lead in the second round of the 56th New Jersey State Golf Association open championship today but could not quite overtake Art Silvestrone Sr., who hung on by a stroke at the halfway point of this 72-hole tournament.

Edward W. Durner, who retired in 1968 as an assistant vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, New York, died Wednesday in Bayshore Community Hospital, Holmdel, N.J., after a lingering illness. His age was 73.

ALBANY, July 22 Governor Carey today signed a bill that "attempts," he said, to provide consumers with safeguards in dealing with health spas, dancing schools and other self-improvement merchandisers.

ST. TROPEZ, France Brigitte Bardot was paid a million francs (almost $200,000) for wearing tight pants this summer in a television commercial, but most St. Tropez regulars don't look for such a monetary incentive. They are pouring themselves into skinny pants because it's fashionable.
In creating the influenza virus, nature unleashed one of the most tickle, enigmatic and persistent microbes known to attack man or beast.

From its first visit here three years ago, the National Ballet of Canada has always presented four different dancers in the role of Princess Aurora in Rudolf Nureyev's production of "The Sleeping Beauty."

MONTREAL, July 22 A pair of American shooters gave sexual equality a shot in the arm today as a man and woman shared the victory stand to protest the method used to break ties in the three-position, small-bore rifle event.
A small Renoir painting that was stolen from the Brooklyn Museum 19 months ago was returned undamaged to the museum in the afternoon mail on Wednesday.

NEWARK, July 22 The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners today announced an experiment to determine the value, in terms of energy conservation and utility costs, of reducing electricity rates at night to encourage the use of power consumption over a 24-hour period and lower the costly peak-time demand during daylight hours.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) Second-Seeded Jimmy Connors trounced Roger Taylor of Britain, 6-1, 6-1, today in the third round of the $125,000 Washington Star tennis tournament.

TRENTON, July 22 Even before the final tally of the Congressional votes to override President Ford's veto of the public-works bill today, New Jersey was busy putting together applications for $310 million of the money.
Both Senate and House have now overridden President Ford's veto of the $3.95 billion public works employment bill, with plenty of room to spare beyond the required two-thirds majority.

LISBON, July 22 Bomb attacks against the offices of the Mozambique airline and an unofficial consulate of Angola within 24 hours of each other have jeopardized Portugal's already tenuous relations with its two former colonies.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 22 The Democratic Party's designation of a black man to run for Congress from Fairfield County's affluent Gold Coast was challenged here today by a young white liberal in what promises to be a bitter primary fight.

FEDERAL judges, who know what they don't like in the way of art, are raising an offbench flap in Baltimore over a sculpture commissioned for their courthouse by the Federal Government. Concerned that the large-scale environmental work, by the New York artist George Sugarman, might serve dissidents as "a platform for speaking or hurling objects," or a place to "secrete bombs or other explosive objects," the judges want the project scrapped.

SHINHOPPLE, N.Y., July 22 Al Carpenter, who rents and sells canoes for a living, looked sadly at the East Branch of the Delaware River and the two fishermen who were struggling to carry their canoe over some rocks peeking out of low water.

Late last November, Rahsaan Roland Kirk, the blind and amazingly versatile jazz musician who often plays two or three saxophones simultaneously, felt dizzy after supper in his home in East Orange, N.J. He went upstairs to lie down.

Representative Elizabeth Holtzman, Democrat of Brooklyn, charged yesterday that state inspectors had made "apparently false declarations" that hid abuses in the Summer Food Service Program for needy New York City children.

WASHINGTON, July 22 The House of Representatives overrode President Ford's veto and enacted into law today a $4 billion public works bill that has the primary aim of creating jobs. The Senate overrode the veto yesterday.
Willian Beaumont Scatchard, a retired Smith College music professor, died Saturday at a Lexington, Mass., nursing home. She was 84 years old.

PASADENA, Calif., July 22 An apparent malfunction in the Viking I landing craft's soilcollection scoop was reported tonight by James S. Martin Jr., the project manager. If it is not "understood and solved in short order," he said, the problem could delay plans to begin gathering soil on Mars for biological examination next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, July 22 The New York State Democratic Congressional delegation which, with one fleeting exception, has not been represented in a top leadership position in the House of Representatives since the Civil War, today nominated Representative Shirley A. Chisholm of Brooklyn to be chairman of the House Democratic Caucus.

A bill that both houses of the New York State Legislature passed in a mistaken version in the final hours of the legislative session was signed into law yesterday by Governor Carey, to the relief of those who feared that the inadvertent error might have prompted a veto.

TRENTON, July 22 The State Assembly passed a three bill package this evening that would place $225 million in bond referendums for water, housing and institutional needs before the voters for approval in November.

The Board of Estimate last night approved a proposed $40 million, 146-acre amusement park for Staten Island after six contentious hours of public hearings in which residents' objections were pitted against the city administration's need to stir new economic activity.

The executive medical director of the New York City Health Department's medical program said yesterday that a fifth of the city's "Medicaid mills" either were involved in Medicaid fraud or provided substandard medical care.
Rains came for the third day to the Midwest growing areas, and the longs traders who owned contracts abandoned their positions as fast as they could.
WINDSOR, Ontario, July 22 (AP) George Burns didn't seem to believe his fiveunder-par 65 would hold up. It nearly didn't.
MONTREAL, July 22 You wouldn't believe what happened tonight in Olympic swimming.

WASHINGTON, July 22 The Army, in what could develop into a major step toward standardization of weapons among the Atlantic allies, reluctantly and unexpectedly delayed today its selection of a new main battle tank.

Thomas G. Labrecque, a banker who was deeply involved in the New York City debt restructuring last year, has been named to the management committee of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, parent of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

PARIS, July 22 France sought today to prevent a further withering in the international value of the franc by raising the discount rate of the Bank of France from 8 percent to 9 percent, a move intended to make it dramatically more attractive to keep money in France.
WASHINGTON, July 22 Members of the Newspaper Guild at The Washington Post have voted, 445 to 315, to retain the Guild as their bargaining agent, the National Labor Relations Board said today.
Marie Baldridge, a teacher of English and psychologist, died Tuesday at Sloan-Kettering Memorial Hospital. She was 75 years old and lived at 41 Fifth Avenue.

The Board of Estimate last night approved a proposed $40 million, 146-acre amusement park for Staten Island after six contentious hours of public hearings in which residents' objections were pitted against the city administration's need to stir new economic activity.

Frankie Crocker, program director of radio station WBLSFM, was indicted in Newark yesterday for allegedly making false statements before a Federal grand jury last September when it was investigating allegations of criminal conduct in the recording industry.
GIDI PASS, Sinai, July 19 Gracious living has come to Sinai.
LONDON, July 22 (UPI) Sir Mortimer Wheeler, a pioneer of modern scientific archeology, died today at a friend's home at Leatherhead, 18 miles southwest of London. He was 85 years old.

PARIS, July 22 The output graphs in Economics Ministries across Western Europe are all showing a comforting upward curve. Bankers and businessmen are talking a little more optimistically about future profits. Slowly, the high jobless rates have been coming down.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration warned doctors today that the nation's most widely used tranquilizers Valium, Librium, Miltown and others may cause cleft lip and other birth defects if taken in early pregnancy.
Cape May, N.J., is a Victorian-era seashore resort where families can spend a relatively inexpensive but busy weekend and even find quartz "diamonds" lying on the beach in the bargain.
The agreement last week to settle the strike against voluntary hospitals through arbitration in no way eases the growing health services emergency in New York.
THE OUTDOOR CONCERT season is at its peak this weekend with performances in skating rinks, ball parks, sculpture gardens and parks even in a band shell.

Through the late 1920's, the depressed 30's and the war-stricken 40's, movie palaces loomed over the New York landscape like transplanted Taj Mahals or Versailles. They were built to entertain the masses, and they did--incomparably. To their ornate interiors--marble columns, pseudo-Greek and Roman and Egyptian sculpture, cupids frolicking in murals on the ceilings--came millions of moviegoers.
GIDI PASS, Sinai, July 19 Gracious living has come to Sinai.

MONTREAL, July 22 Nadia Comaneci of Rumania and Nelli Kim of the Soviet Union split the four individual gold medals in women's gymnastics tonight, but Olga Korbut proved she still was first in the hearts of most fans at these Olympics.

PARIS, July 22 Radical groups from several countries and of various persuasions are increasingly able to coordinate their acts of terrorism and threaten the lives of hundreds of people in a single operation. At the same time the identities of individual terrorists and their organizations, training areas, patterns of activity and support are becoming increasingly known to intelligence specialists around the world.

A Quaker couple who have been doing relief work in Laos for the last year and a half said yesterday that the small warravaged country was hungry and that the new Communist Government was not "overly popular" with many inhabitants.

The American Jewish Congress said yesterday that it had filed a complaint with the State Division of Human Rights against Citibank and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company charging them with serving as "enforcers" of the Arab boycott against Israel, in violation of a recently enacted state law.

LEVITTOWN, L.I., July 22 A special committee appointed to review 11 books that had been removed from the junior and senior high school libraries in the Island Trees school district appears to be divided on whether the books should be returned to the shelves, a school source said today.

Pat Nixon is scheduled to be discharged from the hospital in Long Beach, Calif., today. She suffered a stroke 15 days ago that left part of her left side paralyzed and affected her speech. She has responded well to therapy at the hospital, according to doctors, and will continue the therapy at her San Clemente home. A hospital aide said doctors had predicted "full or near-total" recovery from the stroke in three or four months.

STUYVESANT, N.Y., July 22 (AP) A $3.2 billion, 2,400 megawatt power plant may be built on a site in this Columbia County town, about a half-mile from the Hudson River, New York State Electric and Gas Company officials announced yesterday.
The recent shift in coastal winds from the traditional southwest to northeast may bring improved marine angling from New Jersey to Cape Cod this weekend.

The Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday that total output of electricity in the 48 contiguous states for the week ended July 17 had hit a new weekly high of 42.46 billion kilowatt hours. The previous high was the 41.79 billion k.w.h. set in the week ended Sept. 1, 1973.

Mayor Beame will play a major role, Governor Carey a lesser role and Patrick J. Cunningham, the Democratic state chairman, not much of a role at all in the Carter-forPresident campaign in New York State, according to those involved in shaping the plans.

When Conrail, the federally financed Northeast railroad, recently unveiled its new corporate symbol a stylized "C" on a double track some railroad men quipped that it looked like the "C" had hit an obstacle and was toppling over.

BUENOS AIRES, July 22 President Jorge Rafael Videla, head of Argentina's military junta, met today with bishops of the Roman Catholic Church here to discuss political violence in which five priests have been killed in a little more than two weeks.

WASHINGTON, July 22 The White House rejected today Ronald Reagan's com- plaint of "heavy-handed" campaign tactics by asserting that President Ford had ordered Cabinet officers to spurn any attempts by delegates to the Republican National Convention to trade their votes for Government jobs or favors.

Since that day, I have been nuts about horses, and that is why my favorite thing to do on a New York weekend is to glide through the bridle paths of Central Park on the back of Gay Emily.

WASHINGTON, July 22 The Treasury Department added its weight today to the forces that are putting pressure on the Senate Finance Committee to eliminate many of the narrowinterest provisions from the pending tax bill.

BOSTON, July 22 (AP) The eighth biennial convention of the Lutheran Church in America, today adopted a resolution calling for unconditional amnesty for Vietnam War resisters and pardon for those convicted of related offenses.

KIGALI, Rwanda, July 22 (UPI) This landlocked East African country appears on the brink of economic collapse. It has only enough gasoline for five days because its supplies, which normally come from Kenya through Rwanda's northern neighbor, Uganda, are not getting through.

The B.F. Goodrich Company, one of the four major rubber companies on strike since April 21 reported yesterday a 74 percent decline in second-quarter profits to $3.4 million, or 20 cents a share from a restated $13.1 million, or 88 cents a share, a year earlier.
MEDFORD LAKES, N.J., July 22 (AP) Thirteen policemen and 12 other persons were injured and 10 persons were arrested early today when a melee broke out in the parking lot of a bar here.

It is very early in the morning. The sky is making the transition from pre-dawn black to the soft glow of sunrise. Two young lovers are walking along a pebbly beach, stooping every now and then to pick up clam shells that were washed ashore. Near the beach is a marshy area that is beginning to come alive with the sounds of nature waking up.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 22 (AP) A man with a toy gun took more than $5,000 from a bank here late this morning, but was captured a short time later behind a nearby apartment building, the police said, adding that all the money was recovered.

One of the best ways to learn how to have a beautiful vegetable garden is to read the backs of seed packets. These will tell you when and how deep to plant the seeds, how much to thin out the young plants, and inform you about water needs and potential pests in fact, just about everything except when to harvest your crops.
A small boy in one of William Saroyan's stories finds himself in the public library for the first time. He looks around in awe: "All them books," he says, "and something written in each one!"

Leanora Blossom Goodman, chairman of the I.B. Goodman Company, a jewelry manufacturing company of New York and Cincinnati, died Wednesday while visiting relatives in Indianapolis, Mrs. Goodman, who lived in New York City, was 65 years old.
CAIRO, July 22 President Anwar el-Sadat resumed his criticism of Syria tonight and demanded that Syrian troops withdraw from Lebanon.
Four American sharpshooters, Robert Jordan, Arthur Robinson and Norman Kay of Philadelphia, and Edgar Kaplan of New York, took leisurely aim yesterday in Philadelphia and made every shot tell.

The storms that were expected to make a shambles of labor management relations in the first half of 1976 never materialized, but the second half is off to a turbulent start. Secretary of Labor W. J. Usery Jr., the Federal Government's most expert industrial troubleshooter, has had to put on repeatedly the mediator's hat he thought he was hanging up for good when he entered the Cabinet early this year.

WASHINGTON, July 22 Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Queens Democrat, raised conflict-of-interest questions today about the nomination of Stanley E. Shirk, a retired accountant, as Comptroller of the Currency.

LONDON, July 22 Britain announced today that it was going to cut Government spending next year by 1 billion in an effort to protect the pound, reduce the nation's budget defi- cit and sustain its fragile eco- nomic recovery.

REDWOOD CITY, Calif., July 22 Law enforcement officials said today that they were seeking Fred Newhall Woods of Portola Valley and two of his friends for questioning in the kidnapping last Thursday of 26 schoolchildren and their bus driver near Chowchilla, 100 miles east of here.

JOHANNESBURG, July 22 South Africa, a country built on gold, is facing one of its most serious economic crises since World War II as a result of the fall in the metal's price.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 Fred Newhall Woods, who is being sought for questioning in the investigation of the kidnapping of 26 schoolchildren and their bus driver in Chowchilla, is the scion of a prominent California family and has been described by acquaintances as a loner with a fascination for old cars, which he collected on a vast estate his family has owned for generations.

Paul O'Dwyer, President of the New York City Council, made public yesterday a list of 54 trade union leaders and members supporting him for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator and said many more were prepared to endorse him.

THA BO, Thailand, July 22 A group of former officers of the South Vietnamese Army who had been in Vientiane, Laos, for seven months, awaiting Hanoi's permission to return to Saigon, fled secretly to Thailand early today because they felt they had nowhere else to go.

Anyone who has comfortable shoes and a cast-iron stomach can spend an entire summer weekend in New York, blissfully, fatteningly walking and nibbling his or her way from one ethnic nosh to another. Following are a few personal favorites. Some of these meccas are open both Saturday and Sunday, others on Saturday only, but all are guaranteed to restore flagging spirits weary from the workaday routine.
In the heat of a July afternoon, the events of last winter's snowfall remain vivid. School had been canceled. Eric and his friend Greg, both 12, were sledding in Riverside Park.

WASHINGTON Within the Department of Housing and Urban Development a detailed re-evaluation of the "new towns" program is in progress. This is the program under which the Government has guaranteed $280 million in loans since 1970 to help build large new residential and commercial clusters throughout the nation.
SRINAGAR, July 20 The Vale of Kashmir, for the first time in nearly three decades of Indian and Pakistani independence, presents a surface as calm as that of its mirrorlike Himalayan lakes.
WASHINGTON, July 22 New orders flowing to manufacturers of durable goods rose substantially again in June, the Commerce Department reported today.

MONTREAL, July 22 The Soviet Union suffered another in a series of embarrassments at the Olympic Games today. Its worldchampionship water polo team forfeited a game, indicated it might withdraw from the competition, then decided not to when threatened with disciplinary action.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) A Federal district judge has ruled that the Department of Health, Education and Welfare wrongfully withheld at least $1.3 billion in payments sought by 13 states for social services programs.

Jimmy Carter told a group of leading corporate executives yesterday that, if he was elected President, he would move cautiously on tax reform and would retain the credit on foreign taxes paid by American companies.

MONTREAL, July 22 Organized sports imposed stiff new sanctions on South Africa today because of that country's racial policies.

LONDON, July 22 (Reuters) The British Foreign Office was pressed today to deal with diplomats who park illegally in London and then claim diplomatic immunity to avoid paying fines.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 (AP) Franklin Mieuli, owner of the Golden State Warriors, said today that he and Joseph Alioto, former San Francisco Mayor, were purchasing controlling interest in the San Francisco 49ers of the National Football League. The price was not disclosed.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 22 (AP)-A leftist leader announced today the creation of a civil administration for Moslem-controlled territory of Lebanon.

CHICAGO, July 22 The football season opens here tomorrow night, ready or not. Ara Parseghian, the retired Notre Dame coach, has in 16 days put together the annual edition of the College All-Stars, and they will take on the National Football League champions, the Pittsburgh Steelers, at Soldier Field before a crowd of about 45,000 10,000 fewer than capacity.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 22 The 78th Larchmont Race Week reverted to its normal course today as a small fleet of 144 raced over 11.4, 10.2 and 9.2 mile courses.

The United States men continued their dominance in swimming at the Olympic Games in Montreal yesterday with two more gold-medal victories, both in world-record time. They have won all of the nine events thus far.

KINGSTON, Ontario, July 22 Warned by both his Canadian girlfriend and his team doctor to "win or else," Bob Whitehurst gave the United States a first-place finish today in the 470 Class of the Olympic yachting competition.

WASHINGTON, July 22 The House of Representatives overrode President Ford's veto and enacted into law today a $4 billion public works bill that has the primary aim of creating jobs. The Senate overrode the veto yesterday.
All you need to keep in step with fashion these days is a bit of string. A pair of shoelaces will do. Or a length of wool yarn, the kind used to tie packages or ponytails.
Dr. Ruth Weisinger, associate professor of pediatrics at Mount Sinai Medical School died yesterday at her home in Creskill, N.J., after a long illness. She was 49 years old.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation, the leading domestic copper producer, had a 57 percent decline in second-quarter earnings despite a 15.1 percent sales rise to $453.7 million, the company reported.

REDWOOD CITY, Calif., July 22 Alameda County officials issued a national all-points bulletin late today for the arrest of three young men for questioning in the kidnapping last Thursday of 26 schoolchildren and their bus driver near Chow- chilla, 100 miles cast of here.

A modest rally in the last hour of trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday turned the popular Dow Jones average of 30 blue chips from a minus of 0.57 to close at 991.08 for a gain of 1.64 points.
VERNON, Vt., July 22 (AP) A Federal court has ruled that the order granting the Vermont Yankee Nuclear Power plant its operating license must be returned to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.
Dramatizing his intense pursuit of Republican National Convention delegates, President Ford was host to more than 100 New York delegates at the White House last evening.

Sometimes it really does happen, Sometimes the fairy tale comes true. You're standing in the wings; you come out for a number, and the audience responds; it chuckles, it gurgles, then--with a kind of lemming magic--it stands up and applauds. You may not know what you have done, but you know you have done it right.

On Friday nights if the traffic is jammed on the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Drive, John Howard will steer his Peugeot from his residence on East 69th Street up Third Avenue to 124th Street across the Triborough Bridge and the Major Deegan Expressway.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration warned doctors today that the nation's most widely used tranquilizers Valium, Librium, Miltown and others may cause cleft lip and other birth defects if taken in early pregnancy.

By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. Responding to pressure from Assemblyman Leonard P. Stavisky, the New York City Board of Education voted on Wednesday night to withdraw "without prejudice" a resolution that would have authorized pay increases totaling $445,000 for 252 board employees.
ROCHESTER, July 22 When Margery F. Gootnick started practicing law here in 1952, being a woman lawyer was not considered "socially acceptable," she recalled today.

DESCRIBING Tanglewood is simple. It's place where a quartre of a million people go each summer to hear the Boston Symphony Orchestra. Yes, and "Don Giovanni" is simply an opera about a rake, and the Mona Lisa is a picture of a girl with a crooked smile. The bare-bones facts, though unassailable, always leave out the flesh and blood of truth.

PASADENA, Calif., July 22 An apparent malfunction in the Viking 1 landing craft's soilcollection scoop was reported tonight by James S. Martin Jr., the project manager. If it is not "understood and solved in short order," he said, the problem could delay plans to begin gathering soil on Mars for initial examinations for living organisms set for next Wednesday.

LOS ANGELES, July 22 Legal battles erupted today at the trial of William and Emily Harris over an inquiry into possible jury tampering and the admissibility into evidence of a crucial tape the prosecution wants the jury to hear as its case closes.

PRINCETON, July 22 The reins of spiritual and administrative authority in the New Jersey Area of the United Methodist Church were informally transferred here today in an aura of good fellowship and warmth.

Bobby Rosengarden, the drummer, has been a ubiquitous figure for the last three weeks. During the Newport Jazz Festival, he drummed in Pee Wee Erwin's band at the Jersey Jazz picnic at Waterloo Village, with the World's Greatest Jazz Band on the festival's Hudson River boat ride and with the New York Jazz Repertory Company in its survey of the music of Duke Ellington.
Some time ago, Malcolm Forbes decided he was spending much of his time enveloped in a compartment of steel, so he bought a motorcycle. It was an event that changed his life.

Martha Velez, Who used to belt out blues-rock in a neo-Joplin style, is now singing reggae. Her latest album, "Escape From Babylon," was produced by Bob Marley and features his band, the Wailers. Her traveling band is no match for Jamaica's finest reggae ensemble, but it is a lean, energetic, well-balanced group, with an especially tasteful guitarist and a crisp rhythm section.

The United States men continued their dominance in swimming at the Olympic Games in Montreal yesterday with two more gold-medal victories, both in world-record time. They have won all of the nine events thus far.

Pan American World Airways reported yesterday that secondquarter business had improved sharply over the previous year but complained that revenues were depressed by Government refusal to allow sufficient fare increases.

Nydia Stewart and Sal Galatioto were surprised by what they found when they went to work at the Children's Center on 104th Street and Fifth Avenue which they had heard was an unruly place where violent children assault each other and staff members.

Camping just beyond the sprawl of metropolitan areas can take many forms. For example, at the Ward Pound Ridge Reservation in northern Westchester, an hour and a half from midtown Manhattan, the emphasis is on a variety of services camping in lean-tos, picnics, hiking, nature study in an unusually spacious environment.

WASHINGTON, July 22 The White House rejected today Ronald Reagan's complaint of "heavy-handed" campaign tactics by asserting that President Ford had ordered Cabinet officers to spurn any attempts by delegates to the Republican National Convention to trade their votes for Government jobs or favors.

LONDON, July 22 Britain announced today that it was going to cut Government spending next year by 1 billion in an effort to protect the pound, reduce the nation's budget deficit and sustain its fragile economic recovery.

Mother wears them, father wears them, teen-age brothers and sisters probably wear them, so do movie stars, athletes and legions of ordinary folk. The sunglass may just be the uniform of the American eye.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 23 A Yugoslav-born American accused of economic espionage was freed today after nearly a year in prison and flown to the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 23 Nathaniel Goldfinger, an economist who was research director of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations for 13 years, died last night at his home in Silver Spring, Md.
The Most Rev. Henry J. O'Brien, the first Roman Catholic archbishop of Hartford, died yesterday in St. Francis Hospital in Hartford after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

ATLANTA, July 23 (AP) Calling swine flu vaccines safe and effective weapons for a nationwide inoculation program a Federal committee urged today that "plans for vaccinating all age groups of the popu lation should continue."

STONED The Ryoanji Temple Stone Garden, a copy of the 500-year-old original Zen temple in Kyoto, Japan, and the Roji Garden and the Tallman Memorial Dwarf Plant Garden will all be reopened to the public at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 23 Red Cross representatives managed to enter a besieged Palestinian camp here today for the first time to try to arrange the evacuation of more than 1,000 wounded. They said the next move was up to the combatants.

Shawn Woods Frothingham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Frothingham 3d of Rye, N.Y., was married there last evening to Clifford Garland Crain, son of Mr. and Mrs. John G.L. Crain of Torrance, Calif. The Rev. Donald W. Poole, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

ROME, July 23 It is three years since Pope Paul VI opened the gallery of modern art in the Vatican Museum, where more than 600 works mainly on religious or philosophical themes are shown in a wing of their own not far from the rooms that house works by Raphael and Michelangelo.
BRUSSELS, July 23 (UPI) The dollar made firm gains on all major European money markets today, forcing the Belgian central bank and the Bank of France to intervene in efforts to buoy their currencies.

MORRISTOWN, July 23 The American Freedom Train, a sensory blitz of American history and American kitsch, rolled today into this, its 100th town, and despite gray skies and some times heavy rain it drew large and enthusiastic crowds.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 23 Jack Kiefer intends to go out on the Professional Golfers' Association tour "sometimes this fall." At age 36, he might be one of the oldest tour rookies in P.G.A. history.

The National Basketball Association owners voted approval of a settlement yesterday dealing with the future signing of rookies. The agreement will now allow Federal Judge Robert L. Carter to approve resolution of the Oscar Robertson antitrust lawsuit against the N.B.A. and pave the way for the proposed merger with the American Basketball Association.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose in light trading yesterday by 0.08 to 104.65, as measured by the exchange's market value index.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the industry leader, reported yesterday a 40.5 percent drop in secondquarter earnings despite a 5.6 percent sales rise.

WASHINGTON, July 23 The largest pension fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, beset by a ruling by the Internal Revenue Service, appealed today to the Securities and Exchange Commission to exempt it from having to register as an investment company.

Leaders of both houses of the Legislature raised the prospect yesterday that a portion of the new public employee pension bill, passed just last month but already proving unexpectedly troublesome, might be revised in a reconvened Albany session nest week.

MADERA, Calif., July 23 One of three men sought in the kidnapping last week of 26 schoolchildren and their bus driver surrendered today, hours after a high-level official in the case reported that a note demanding $5 million ransom for the victims had been found.

Anyone launching Portugal's first democratic government in half a century could count on good will from democratic countries, especially those of Western Europe and North America. But there is unusual respect for Mario Soares for his long, courageous fight against the repressive regimes of Antonio de Oliveira Salazar and Marcello Caetano, and thus a special eagerness to help him establish Portugal firmly on the democratic path.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 23--Red Cross representatives managed to enter a besieged Palestinian camp here today for the first time to try to arrange the evacuation of more than 1,000 wounded. They said the next move was up to the combatants.
The stock market yesterday seemed to combine the summer doldrums and the inertia of a rainy day as it wound up the day in much the same manner that it began.
"The South Bronx? Whatever life could there be in that part of the world! Are there real live people up there?"
A 30-year-old prisoner was slain last night in the Justice Department's new Metropolitan Correctional Center, a spokesman for the center reported.

PARIS, July 23 Marina Sulzberger, the wife of C.L. Sulzberger, the foreign-affairs columnist of The New York Times, died of an embolism in the American Hospital here today, eight days after undergoing an operation. She was 57 years old.

LOS ANGELES, July 23 Patricia Hearst is to appear in Superior Court here Monday to receive a new trial date on the same assault, robbery and kidnapping charges for which her former companions in the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army, William and Emily Harris, are now on trial.

MONTREAL, July 23 Get ready for another Olympic walkout, of sorts, courtesy of the Montreal taxi drivers' union. It's scheduled for next Tuesday when the cabbies plan to tie up traffic in and near the Olympic Village in a demonstration called "Operation Turtle."

COLUMBIA, C., July 23 (UPI) Maude Busch Byrnes, widow of James F. Byrnes, former Supreme Court Justice and Secretary of State, died today in a local hospital after a long illness. She was 93 years old.

Federal officials yesterday directed the State Department of Education to withhold, starting in August, all advance payments to sponsors of the Summer Food Service Program for needy children in New York City unless the state can certify that the sponsors are in full compliance with regulations.

Nearly 500 members of the staff of Morrisania Hospital in the South Bronx have been reporting to work and drawing full salary a total of about $600,000, so far despite the fact that the hospital was shut down three weeks ago and there is nothing for them to do.

PASADENA, Calif., July 23 Viking 1 project officials expressed growing confidence today that they understood the problem with the spacecraft's balky soil-sampling arm and should be able to correct it in time to scoop up Martian soil for scientific analysis next Wednesday.

RICHMOND, Va., July 23 (AP) A Federal appeals court, saying it was walking a thin line between "two conflicting persuasions," today upheld the right of two newspaper reporters to refuse to testify in a West Virginia court proceeding.
The Parsippany-Troy Hills Office on Aging sponsors an "Aging Talent Bank" designed to make use of the skills of older people.

WASHINGTON, July 23 The financially troubled Government Employees Insurance Company reported new figures at a special stockholders' meeting here today that supported hopes that an 18-month period of large underwriting losses that has threatened its solvency might end by fall.
TOKYO--Women and men alike carry them along this city's winding back lanes. Children swing them off to school.

A 41-year-old tennis player who was ranked nationally two years ago in the men's 35-and-over division won a women's tennis tournament in La Jolla, Calif., last week.
MULBERRY, Fla. For 49 years, Roxanne Cooper has lived on top of a reclaimed phosphate mine, where the mineral was clawed from the earth, first by men with mules, later by great machines.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 23 (AP) Rhodesian blacks would be drafted into the armed services for the first time under legislation introduced today. Prime Minister Ian D. Smith also said that his white minority Government would ease some public restrictions on blacks, but he has rejected three major racial reforms.

Abigail Booth, coordinator of the Bicentennial Inventory of American Paintings at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, was married yesterday afternoon to William H. Gerdts of New York, professor of art history at Brooklyn College and the Graduate Center of the City University of New York.
SERRA DOS CARAJAS, Brazil The old DC-3 glided past the Amazon rain forests and touched down on a gravel airstrip that felt as smooth as a metal runway.

TOKYO, July 23 The Tokyo district prosecutor's office indicted today Hiroshi Ito, a former managing director of the Marubeni Corporation, on charges of committing perjury in testifying before the Japanese Diet on the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation payoff scandal.

A New Jersey appeals court yesterday revoked a judicial "gag order" that prevented public discussion of the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter triple-murder case by the defendants, their lawyers and the prosecution.

TRENTON, July 23 Passaic school officials conferred today with a representative of the State Office of Equal Educational Opportunity to discuss a timetable for integrating the city's seven elementary schools.

Five years ago the united opposition of an entire borough might have led the Board of Estimate to reject an entrepreneur's development plan. But last Thursday, the Board of Estimate approved a land-lease proposal that will clear the way for detailed planning of a privately owned recreation park on Staten Island despite intense local opposition.

Soybeans advanced 20 cents yesterday, but first they took a plunge yesterday and then took a leap, managing to confuse many onlookers. In the morning the price dropped the 20 cents a bushel daily limit for some contracts and then at the close they were 20 cents higher on the day, or a change of 40 cents, enough to cause some consternation among longs and shorts.
ANAHEIM, Calif., July 23 (AP) The California Angels' manager, Dick Williams, was dismissed today and replaced by Coach Norm Sherry, Gene Autry, the team's owner, announced.

The Dutch choreographer Hans van Manen is most curiously musical. He has an instinct for music, a feel, a sense, a sensibility for it. Which is probably why he is one of the most interesting choreographers around.

George Foster, another one of those "buttons" that Manager Sparky Anderson of the Cincinnati Reds pushes to put the Big Red Machine in high gear, broke a 1-1 tie with a two-run single in the eighth inning last night in Atlanta to give the Reds a 3-1 victory over the Braves.
MONTREAL, July 23 (UPI) A 65-year-old trapshooter from Monaco was tossed out of the Olympic Games for flunking the drug test, the medical commission of the International Olympic Committee said today.

HILTON HEAD ISLANDS, S.C., July 23 Senator Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, arrived here today for some campaigning and long planning session on how his staff and campaign can best be "integrated" with those of Jimmy Carter.

WASHINGTON, July 23 The State Department today denied charges by Ambassador Silberman that certain officials had tried to undercut his efforts in the Toth case or that anyone had recommended that he be reprimanded.
ALBANY, July 23 Governor Carey today vetoed a bill passed by the Legislature that would have limited the authority of the New York City Board of Education to close school buildings.
WASHINGTON, July 23 A wildcat strike by coal miners that began last week in West Virginia spread across the Appalachian coal fields today, bringing the number of strikers to 25,000.
Two men were held up yesterday by a pair of gunmen. The victims turned out to be F.B.I. agents and the gunmen ended up at Lenox Hill Hospital in critical condition with gunshot wounds.

TRENTON, July, 23 The tenant tax-rebate bill, Which is holding up implementation of the state income tax, as now amended would tend to discriminate against families that rent houses of flats in small apartment houses.

WASHINGTON, July 23 President Ford moved today within close range of the 1,130 delegates needed to secure the Republican Presidential nomination, a tally by The New York Times showed, while his campaign leaders asserted that he already had more than enough.
OTTAWA, July 23 (AP) The Government issued regulations today forbidding the use of the French language in Canadian air-traffic control except at certain Quebec airports.

SAN SALVADOR, July 22 (Reuters) Honduras and El Salvador agreed tonight to cease hostilities along their common frontier, the scene of sporadic clashes over the last week, it was officially announced here.
The Getty Oil Company, which has announced discussions that could lead to a merger with the Skelly Oil Company, has purchased relatively few shares of Skelly this year.

WEST BERLIN, July 23 Mayor Klaus Schutz faced with a motion of no confidence following a number of political scandals in this city, the latest the escape of four women terrorists from jail, won a significent success today when the city parliament defeated an opposition censure attempt.
The women playing cards in what used to be part of the emergency room at Morrisania Hospital did not want to talk at all.

NEW HAVEN, July 23 The mystery of what a former Connecticut Governor and Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court wanted hidden in a black bread box for 50 years will remain a mystery a little while longer.

A security guard was shot in the neck last evening in the Times Square area as he and another guard became the targets of an attempted holdup while collecting receipts from Broadway theaters, the police reported.
A $165 million pulp and newsprint manufacturing complex jointly owned by American and Japanese interests will be built at Longview, Wash., the North Pacific Paper Company said yesterday.

Dr. Wayne Dennis, a wellknown child psychologist, anthropologist, author and professor emeritus of Brooklyn College, died Wednesday in McGuire's Veterans Hospital, Richmond, of injuries received in an auto collision last May 25. Dr. Dennis, who lived at Doswell, Va., was 70 years old.
WICHITA, Kan., July 23 (AP) Dr. Milton Besser, a journalism professor and former diplomatic reporter for The Associated Press, died last night of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.
Eliot Feld's ballet "At Midnight" has always had its self-evident virtues, but these virtues are more outstanding when they are helped along by dancers who understand them.

The Common Carrier Bureau of the Federal Communications Commission yesterday authorized the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to initiate service on Comstar, its domestic satellite system. The Bell System is partners with the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation in the Communications Satellite System.

CHICAGO, July 23 The game between the Pittsburgh Steelers and the College All Stars was terminated late in the third quarter tonight as thousands of fans came out of the stands onto the field during a downpour of rain. Both goal posts were torn down and nine minutes after officials had ordered both teams into their locker rooms the announcement came that the game would not resume.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 23 (Reuters) Turkey sent an oil exploration vessel to the Aegean Sea today, risking a naval confrontation with Greece which has conflicting claims to the mineral riches of the sea bed.
SPRINGFIELD, Mo., July 23 (UPI) A woman committing suicide by running her car in a closed garage inadvertently killed an elderly couple living next door.
MONTREAL, July 23 Judges in women's gymnastics were under considerably more pressure than in any previous Olympics, several members of the international panel disclosed today.
Today's backyard swimming pools come equipped with all sorts of fancy filters to keep out foreign bodies, but what about the neighbors who drop in for a swim?

The Federal Government's plan to immunize every American against swine influenza illustrates the dilemma officials face in making risk-benefit decisions about public health matters at a time when the state News of the economy Analysis stresses cost-effective analyses and when preventive medicine is emphasized.
WASHINGTON, July 23 The Senate Finance Committee decided today to remove from the pending tax bill 14 provisions that affect only one or two companies, each and to modify five other provisions.

YONKERS, July 23--Several Westchester County women have been struck in the neck, chest and shoulders by sharp steel darts shot through their lighted windows late at night by a sniper lurking outside garden-apartment buildings.
MOSCOW, July 23 (UPI) The Soviet Union has launched two more unmanned earth satellites in its Cosmos series, Tass, the Soviet press agency, said today.

In unusually stern warning letters to the five New Yorkbased commodity futures exchanges, the Government's Commodity Futures Trading Commission warned them that they must improve their selfregulatory practices or else. The alternative would be monetary penalties, the end of designation as a contract market, or other disciplinary action.
A group of American commercial banks is on the verge of approving a new loan of $150 to $200 million to the hard-pressed Government of Peru.

One woman was killed and 23 other passengers suffered injuries and shock when a Greyhound bus overturned on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway yesterday afternoon near Herkimer, N.Y., in the Mohawk Valley area.

An expert witness testified in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday that a pipeline leak during drilling off New Jersey could spill a million gallons of oil into the Atlantic before it was detected.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 23 The United Nations issued a provisional agenda today for the 31st regular session of its General Assembly, due to open here on Sept. 21.

John G. Heimann, the New York State Superintendent of Banks, will leave his position within two months to accept a higher-ranking job in the administration of Governor Carey, according to informed sources in the banking community.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 20--When Time-Life Books Inc, packs up and leaves New York this fall, taking desks, filing cabinets and some 320 jobs, the shift from Rockefeller Center to the red brick, restored-Colonial ambience of this northern Virginia city of 110,000 is going to leave some of the migrants in cultural shock.

SYRACUSE, July 23--Jon K. Holcombe, the Onondaga County District Attorney, has been charged with a felony count of first-degree attempted sexual abuse involving a woman who until recently was a secretary in the trial unit of his office.

MONTREAL, July 23 Angela Voigt, an East German telephone mechanic who has seldom been consistent in the long jump, picked the right day to be consistent. She jumped 22 feet inch today and won the Olympic gold medal for women.

UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., July 23 (UPI) North Korea today rejected a proposal by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger for a four-power conference on Korea, describing it as an attempt to "perpetuate the status quo" and keep American troops in the South.

At the request of defense counsel and with the consent of the prosecution, a Criminal Court judge yesterday sealed papers filed on behalf of Arnold E. Kagan, a financier and builder who has been subpoenaed to produce corporate records.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) A House subcommittee chairman said today that the Ford Administration wiretapped more than the Nixon Administration did. But the Justice Department replied that he had misinterpreted its records and that the number of taps had actually declined.
Double faults of flood and drought had tennis players raising a racket recently at the Central Park courts.

The Beame administration is considering an increase in the hotel-occupancy tax as part of an intricate attempt to float the financial backing needed for reviving the Manhattan convention center project.

The high tide at Jones Beach last night brought in gobs of grease, plastic floatables and drift cards that were dropped nine days ago at the sewage-sludge dump 12 miles off New York City.

Familiar and threatening shock waves are pulsing through the 25 prisons of the New York State correctional system. Benjamin C. Ward, State Correctional Services Commissioner, says that the system is in "a period of crisis." Attica, the ultimate symbol of prison violence, now seems perpetually on the verge of a new conflagration.

Staten Island civic leaders said yesterday that they would seek grand jury and judicial inquiries into what they called a conspiracy by politicians and promoters to install an amusement park in the wooded southwestern corner of the borough.

MONTREAL, July 23 There were no world records in Olympic swimming today, only because there was no Olympic swimming. Five days of competition are over, and the last events will be held tomorrow and Sunday. Then, of course, more world records will be broken.

LISBON, July 23 Portugal's new Prime Minister, Mario Soares, and his Government took office today, their principal mission to restore national confidence after two years of political instability and lack of direction.

NEWARK, July 23 Ceremonial ground-breakings marked the start here today of two public housing projects, valued at $8.7 million, that are designed to bring more housing within reach of low- and moderate-income families in Newark's predominantly black Central Ward.

WASHINGTON Industrial nations, including our own, nowadays rely heavily on monetary policy to promote expansion of production and employment, to limit any decline that may occur in overall economic activity, or to blunt the forces of inflation.
BRIG, Switzerland, July 23 (AP) The Riviera Express jumped the tracks and overturned as it came out of the Simplon Tunnel at high speed early today, killing six persons and injuring 34.

MIAMI, July 23 (UPI) The Inter American Press Association today condemned a UNESCO conference on communication policies as an attempt to promote control and manipulation of news. The conference, the first of its kind, ended yesterday in San Jose, Costa Rica.
ALBANY, July 23 The State Commission of Correction, a "watchdog" agency, said today it was "extremely concerned about the serious situation that exists in the state prison system."

MONTREAL, July 23 Del Unser, traded by the Mets with Wayne Garrett last Tuesday when Manager Joe Frazier said the club was cleaning out "the dead wood," faced his former teamates for the first time tonight in a Montreal uniform and hit an 11th-innings home run that gave the Expos a 3-2 victory.
WASHINGTON, July 23 A wildcat strike by coal miners that began last week in West Virginia spread across the Appalachian coal fields today, bringing the number of strikers to 25,000.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) There have been some "intermediate level" contacts between Jimmy Carter's campaign staff and the staff of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops to outline certain issues the church is interested in, sources at the bishops' conference said today.

WEST POINT, July 23 A group of cadets at the United States Military Academy, standing in the shadow of the Academy, held a news conference today and told of being forced to testify against themselves and of being retried in cases where they had already been acquitted.

CHICAGO, July 23 (UPI) Nearly 13,000 librarians ended their centennial conference today after hearing a warning from Daniel Boorstin, Librarian of Congress, that the nation was on the brink of "turning out the lights on its libraries."

New York City officials are bitterly contesting a bill, now awaiting Governor Carey's signature or veto, that would give the State Department of Environmental Conservation control over water releases from upstate reservoirs owned by the city.

MONTREAL, July 23 The already tight security at the Olympic Village was reinforced today after two incidents that ruffled the Canadian police, who have been going to extreme measures to prevent the kind of terrorism that cost the lives of 11 Israeli athletes in Munich in 1972.
LONDON, July 23 (UPI) An early morning fire today in the engine room of the Queens Elizabeth 2 forced the 65,000-ton liner to turn back to Southampton, England. The ship was on its way to New York.
MOSCOW, July 23 (UPI) The one-month deadline for a Soviet court to hear a defamation suit lodged by the Moscow correspondent of Newsweek Magazine passed today without a trial date being set.
MIAMI, July 23 Former President and Mrs. Richard M. Nixon today sold their second residence in the Key Biscayne compound, apparently their last property in Florida.

The Chase Manhattan Bank announced plans yesterday for the takeover of its corporate transfer agency activities by the Bradford National Corporation, a data processing concern that does back office work for several other banks.
Texaco Inc. announced higher earnings for the second quarter and first half of 1976, while the Amerada Hess Corporation reported a drop in profits for both periods.

For almost two decades, no problem in Bonn-Washington relations has been more persistent or corrosive than the series of prolonged biannual negotiations for payments by West Germany to offset the expenditures of the 200,000 American troops stationed there.

PLAINS, Ga., July 23 Jimmy Carter, whose sleepy Southwest Georgia hometown of 683 persons has been overrun by hundreds of tourists each day since he became the Democratic Presidential nominee, has discovered that his candidacy has created another problem for some local residents.

YONKERS, July 23 Several Westchester County women have been struck in the neck, chest and shoulders by sharp steel darts shot through their lighted windows late at night by a sniper lurking outside garden-apartment buildings.
DETROIT, July 23 Auto companies still held down by inventory problems in some lines, reported today a 12.9 percent increase in new-car sales over a year ago in the period from July 11 to 20.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 23--Following is the text of remarks made today by Laurence H. Silberman, United States Ambassador to Yugoslavia, on the release of Laszlo Toth, an American citizen who had been jailed in that country. The remarks were transcribed by The New York Times.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 23 The durability of the military regimes that dominate South America has reduced leftist influence on the continent to its lowest ebb in decades.
WINDSOR, Ontario, July 23 (AP) Jack Nicklaus shot his second consecutive 67 today and took the lead after 36 holes of the 67th Canadian open golf championship with a six-under-par 134.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) Federal District Judge June L. Green today ordered the Federal Bureal of Investigation to search the files of its 59 field offices for any information on Julius and Ethel Rosenberg and report back to her within 21 days.

The B.F. Goodrich Company said yesterday its four top executives, including its chairman, president, and two executive vice presidents, had been illegally reimbursed for a total of $12,500 in domestic political contributions between 1969 and 1973.

PARIS, July 23 (Reuters) Paul Morand, novelist, diplomat and member of the Academie Francaise, died here today. He was 88 years old.
