By GORDON S. WHITE Jr. Women are eligible to enter the United States Golf Association's open championship tournament by starting in the qualifying round, the way most men begin. But men are not eligible to participate in the U.S. G.A.'s women's open championship, because the rules of that tournament specify women golfers only.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 26 A deputy attorney general joined a battery of Atlantic City lawyers in Superior Court here today to defend the constitutionality of a casino gambling referendum that will appear on the general election ballot in November for the second time in three years.

In one of the biggest surprises of the Olympic Games at Montreal, the defending champion Soviet Union men's basketball team was beaten, 89-84, yesterday by Yugoslavia. The victory put the Yugoslavs into tonight's final against the United States and prevented a gold-medal rematch between the United States and Soviet teams. The Americans advanced by beating Canada, 95-77.

The new conventional wisdom in the field of health policy stresses prevention and the early detection of disease. Two recent developments, however, suggest that the issues involved are more complicated than generally assumed.
William I. Cohen, a lawyer and Small Claims Court judge who had long been active in Manhattan Republican politics, died Sunday at his home, 45 Sutton Place South. He was 72 years old.

Leaders of the Co-op City strike against increased carrying charges yesterday lugged $20 million in withheld payments to State Supreme Court in the Bronx and handed it over to themselves, since they now are the board of directors for the giant housing project.
Mayor Beame has asked a panel of experts, including three forensic pathologists, to evaluate the professional qualifications of Dr. Dominick J. Di Maio for the post of Chief Medical Examiner.

MIAMI, July 26 (AP) As a lighthouse crew in the Dry Tortugas fought to save some of 30 beached pilot whales today, experts were puzzling over who, after four years without such beachings, three groups of deep water mammal have stranded themselves ashore in two weeks.

With one out of every 10 people in the labor force out of a job, the tension is often high and the frustrations deep on both sides of the counter at the unemployment-insurance claims office on the Upper West Side.

BONN, July 26 (AP) A Government commission on monopolies has expressed concern over the growth of economic concentration through business mergers in West Germany, which has the strongest economy in Europe.

WASHINGTON, July 26 Senator Richard S. Schweiker said today that he had accepted Ronald Reagan's invitation to be his running mate if Mr. Reagan won the Republican Presidential nomination because he thought that as a team they could unify the party.

PRESQUE ISLE, Me., July 26 (UPI) The head of the new Commodity Futures Trading Commission assured potato farmers today that people who caused a massive default of May Maine potato futures contracts would receive more than a reprimand.

WASHINGTON, July 26 Americans for Democratic action, that weathervane of liberal voting in Congress, last year found the voting record of Senator Rich ard Schultz Schweiker so acceptable it rated him 89. This was only six points be low the score the A.D.A. gave Senator Walter F. Mondale, Jimmy Carter's VicePresidential candidate, and a score that would have done a liberal Democrat proud.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (UPI) Jimmy Carter's 29-yearold nephew, imprisoned for two armed robberies, says that his family disowned him when his uncle began to close in on the Democratic Presidential nomination. The San Francisco Chronicle said in a copyrighted article today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 26 (UPI) United States Embassy officials said today that Yugoslavia arrested a former American army captain two years ago and sentenced him to five years in prison for espionage.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 26 (AP) Harvard University said today that it had returned to the Mexican Government valuable Maya jade artifacts taken from a funeral well at Chichen Itza in Yucatan from 1904 to 1909.

WASHINGTON, July 26 Justice Department lawyers investigating the Central Intelligence Agency's 20-year program of opening mail between the United States and Communist countries have recommended against the criminal prosecution of agency officials involved in the project, a Government official familiar with the investigation said today.

LOS ANGELES, July 26 Ronald Reagan broke with tradition today and named Senator Richard S. Schweiker of Pennsylvania as the man who will be his running mate if the Californian wins the Republican nomination for President.

MONTREAL, July 26 Proceeding with what its manager called an "esoteric" game plan designed for East European opponents America's young Olympic boxing team put three more men into the quarterfinals today.
SANIBEL ISLAND, Fla., July 26 (AP) Dr. John C. Slater, whose research led to the development of radar in World War II, died after a heart attack last night at his home here. He was 75 years old.

The New York Times Company yesterday reported second-quarter consolidated net income of $6.2 million, or 54 cents a share, an increase of 35.5 percent over the $4.6 million, or 42 cents a share, reported in the second quarter of 1975.
PASADENA, Calif., July 26 Viking 1 instruments have reported that Mars has an atmosphere that project scientists believe is "encouraging to the search for life but by no means conclusive."

A 48-year-old woman who operates a Chinese restaurant in Asbury Park, N.J., received a 15-year prison sentence yesterday for conspiring to smuggle 88 pounds of heroin into the United States from Hong Kong.
CAIRO, July 26 Gaber Abdelkader, a seller of cloth for turbans, surveyed his plain and fancy bolts of Egyptian cotton with a proud but melancholy eye.
James W. Crayhon, a retired press aide of Exxon Corporation, died Sunday at Rosary Hill Home, Hawthorne, N.Y. He was 74 years old and a resident of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

Arthur D. Rooney Jr., who retired in 1970 as a supervising New York State bank examiner, died Saturday in Nassau County Medical Center. He was 74 years old and lived at 143 Floral Parkway, Floral Park, L.I.

WASHINGTON, July 26 The labor cost for each unit of output in the manufacturing sector of the economy was lower in the second quarter of this year than a year earlier despite the rise in wages, the Labor Department reported today.

LOS ANGELES, July 26 Ronald Reagan broke with tradition today and named Senator Richard S. Schweiker of Pennsylvania as the man who will be his running mate if the Californian wins the Republican nomination for President.

MONTREAL, July 26 Alone in the rain, with a 16foot fiberglass vaulting pole in his wet hands, Dave Roberts, a 25-year-old medical student from Florida, took the biggest gamble of the Olympic Games tonight and lost.

The chances that constitutional amendments on court reorganization will be passed this year were dimmed yesterday when leaders of the Legislature announced that they would not bother to reconvene the Legislature in Albany this week to act on any of Governor Carey's vetoes.

MONTREAL, July 26 Don Quarrie, a Jamaican who lives and trains in Los Angeles, won the Olympic 200-meter dash gold medal today, a prize that eluded him four years ago. Americans took the two other medals as 20year-old Millard Hampton of San Jose, Calif., finished second and 17-year-old Dwayne Evans of Phoenix, Ariz., third.
ROME, July 26 For the first time in the history of the Italian Republic, the Communist Party tonight won chairmanships of committees in Parliament.

Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin's detailed findings of "serious managerial incompetence" in the administration of municipal parks concessions are striking, but hardly surprising. In a city that has rarely distinguished itself for managerial excellence, the patronage-ridden Parks Department has long been an especially notorious example of gross mismanagement.

JOHANNESBURG, July 26 Schools in Soweto closed again today after most of the township's 250,000 students stayed away, as they have on each of the three days since the schools reopened last week. Most other townships reported normal or near-normal attendance.
Soy Numero Uno is a healthy horse again. Bill Borders, the assistant trainer, says so. Patrick Day, who has been riding him says so.

CHARLESTON, W.Va., July 26 (AP) Striking coal miners shut down West Virginia's rich coal industry today to protest the use of Federal restraining orders and fines against union members in labor disputes. Meantime, the strike spread into neighboring Ohio.

WASHINGTON, July 26 The House Ethics Committee formally recommended today that Representative Robert L. F. Sikes, Democrat of Florida, be reprimanded on two of three complaints alleging that he used his office for personal gain.
There might have been a time around the turn of this decade when black agencies got business from national advertisers that was a form of conscience money.

DETROIT, July 26 The Chrysler Corporation today reported second-quarter earnings of $155.1 million, its best three months ever and a strong turnaround from a $58.7 million loss in the second quarter last year.

The Uniformed Firefighters Association's awards for 1975 to reporters and photographers for coverage of fires and other stories related to New York City's firemen were presented yesterday by its president, Michael J. Maye, at a luncheon at the Downtown Athletic Club.
WASHINGTON, July 26 Ronald Reagan's bold runningmate gamble stunned the Republican Party today and seemed bound to alter the pre- carious balance of...
ROME, July 26 For the first time in the history of the Italian Republic, the Communist Party tonight won chairmanships of committees in Parliament.
BIEL, Switzerland, July 24 Bent Larsen of Denmark took over the lead with 6 points after nine rounds of the Interzonal Tournament for world championship aspirants here in the Kongresshaus.

WASHINGTON, July 26 Ronald Reagan's bold runningmate gamble stunned the Republican Party today and seemed bound to alter the pre carious balance of a fiercely competitive contest for the party's Presidential nom inatian. But only the events of the next several days will determine if the California's designation of Senator Richard S. Schweiker of Pennsylvania to be his running mate was a stroke of tactical brilliance or a devastatingly bad mistake.

In one of the biggest surprises of the Olympic Games at Montreal, the defending champion Soviet Union men's basketball team was beaten, 89-84, yesterday by Yugoslavia. The victory put the Yugoslavs into tonight's final and prevented a gold-medal rematch between the United States and Soviet teams. The best the Russians can win is a bronze medal.
The two-year fight of Calvin Williams, a former State assemblyman, to stay out of jail ended yesterday when a judge refused to lift his six-month sentence on perjury charges.

Want to learn how to transform the bathroom into a tropical paradise of plants? Or perhaps how to take advantage of such disposable vases as green peppers or hollowed-out melons? And to smile while you're learning?
TORONTO, July 26 (Reuters) The widow of Sir Frederick Banting, who discovered insulin, died today of a brain tumor. Sh was 64.
ROME, July 26 (AP) Three gunmen raided the accounting office of the Labor Ministry today and made off with a $550,000 payroll. There was no policeman around to stop them.
The Itel Corporation announced yesterday in San Francisco that it had agreed in principle to acquire AutEx Inc., of Wellesley, Mass. in a stock trade valued at about $13.8 million.

Monica Kathryne Timmons, an analyst with the credit department at C. Tennant Sons Company of New York, international traders in nonferrous metals, concentrates and ores, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Clyde Cummins, an account representative for the banking division of the United States Trust Company of New York.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 26 Along Bangkok's garish Petchaburi and Patpong Roads, huge neon-lit go-go bars, nightclubs and massage parlors used to echo to Midwestern trangs, Southern drawls and Bronx nasalizing. Now it is Thai voices that are heard, and the customers, once crowded out by free-spending Americans, are enjoying bargain-basement prices in the wake of the United States military withdrawal.

A school for working adults seeking a high school equivalency diploma faces an uncertain future because of the city's financial straits. Ironically, the school doesn't cost the city anything, since the teachers donate their services.
Governor Carey made an unscheduled visit to the Elmira Correctional Facility here today, his first inspection of a state prison since he took office 19 months ago.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 26 Heavy fighting continued in various parts of Lebanon today in disregard of the cease-fire agreement the warring factions were reported to have reached Saturday.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) Relations between the United States and Canada are becoming increasingly strained, and there is little hope for improvment, a new research study, concluded today.

WASHINGTON, July 26 The House Ethics Committee formally recommended today that Representative Robert L. F. Sikes, Democrat of Florida, be reprimanded on two of three complaints alleging that he used his office for personal gain.

LOS ANGELES, July 26 [UPI] Following is the text of Ronald Reagan's announcement today that he would select Senator Richard S. Schweiker, Republican of Pennsylvania, as his running mate if Mr. Reagan wins the Republican Presidential nomination:

FRANKLIN, Vt. A Border Patrol agent, Sterling Smith, his heavy silver and turquoise expansion watchband and cowboy boots marking him as a man of the Southwest, stood by the bright orange metal gate at the Canadian border, scanning the unfamiliar, densely wooded landscape.

LOS ANGELES, July 26 Patricia Hearst, still looking pale and gaunt, won a six month delay in her state trial today with her lawyer predicting that even by the new trial date, Jan. 10, he would not be able to find jurors who had never heard of her bank robbery conviction in San Francisco.

MONTREAL, July 26 (UPI) Win or lose, the United States' women's basketball team was going to have a party this afternoon. The way things worked out it was a big celebration because the Americans defeated Czechoslovakia, 83-67 and won a silver medal in the first women's competition held at the Olympic Games.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) The body of the executed mercenary Daniel Gearhart arrived home today in a plain wooden box bearing his name and shipping instructions to a funeral home in suburban Silver Spring, Md.

Rico Carty has become a much-traveled player since he broke into the major leagues with the Milwaukee Braves in 1963. Since then, he has tested the batting background in such places as Atlanta, Arlington, Texas; Oakland, Calif.; Cordoba, Mexico, and, more recently, Municipal Stadium in Cleveland.

CAIRO, July 26 The Egyptian Government has recently been sending modest, unannounced shipments of military supplies to the PalestinianLebanese leftist side in Lebanon, well-placed informants sympathetic to the Government reported this week.
TRENTON, July 26 Last February, Governor Byrne said in a statement from his office: "There continues to be some confusion over the Governor's salary."

Richard Clare Partridge, a retired major general, who served as chief of staff of the VII Army Corps in World War II, died of a heart attack Friday near his home in New London, Conn., at the age of 77.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 27 Former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka was arrested this morning for alleged involvement in the multi-million-dollar Lockheed Aircraft bribery scandal.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., July 26 (AP) George Souders, a former Indianapolis 500 auto race winner, was found dead in his apartment here today. He was 75 years old. Death was attributed to natural causes.

FLEISCHMANNS, N.Y. In the last 30 years, more than 100 hotels, motels, boarding houses, camps and private homes in this area have burned to the ground under suspicious circumstances. At least 20 of the fires have occurred in the last five years.

Chain stores throughout the country registered a sales gain of 9.6 percent in June over the 1975 month, according to figures compiled by Chain Store Age magazine. The June results showed some improvement over May's volume, which was only 7 percent ahead of the year-earlier month, but were down considerably from high percentage gains achieved in the first four months of the year.
Soybeans closed down the permissible 20-cent daily limit on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, reversing Friday's trend.

When Michael Altschuler decided to explain what Gothic architecture was, he did not talk about pointed arches and stained-glass windows. Instead, he arranged six students in two rows of three, and asked them to join their hands high in the air across the center.
The Montreal Olympic Games on ABC have been eclipsing all other summertime programming in the national ratings, drawing 45 to 50 percent of the viewing audience most evenings.

KINGS POINT, L.I., July 26 (UPI) The United States Merchant Marine Academy, announced today that it would not press sexual-misconduct charges against Cadet Nancy Donnelly, who resigned after being found in bed, with her fianc but who was later reinstated after charges of sex discrimination were raised.
MONTREAL, July 26 There will be a grudge game for the Olympic gold medal in basketball tomorrow night, but it will not be a United States-Soviet Union final.

The assistant sanitation supervisor for Hempstead, L.I., admitted yesterday that he had told sanitation employees that to get raises or promotions they would have to donate 1 percent of their pay to the Nassau County Republican Party. There was no indication of how many employees may have been involved.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., July 26 (UPI) A gypsy caravan has been fleecing its way across the country for two years, frustrating efforts of authorities to deport them because no other country will take them, United States Border Patrol officials said today.

PARIS, July 26 (AP) The French franc plunged to a 29month low today, closing at 4.94 to the dollar, down from 4.926 Friday a slide of 8 percent since the beginning of the year and 4 percent in recent weeks.

"Kingdom of Earth" is at least the fourth title and incarnation of the Tennessee Williams play that began life, briefly, on Broadway in 1968 as "The Seven Descents of Myrtle." Last year it appeared, under its present title, at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J. Now. in revival Off Off Broadway at the I.R.T. Theater, it turns out to be a fascinating little Gothic tale, a comedy with menace.

NEWARK, July 26 The Ironbound Recreation Center, a monument to $6 million in poor planning and the success of vandalism in New Jersey's largest city, may yet become a source of revenue for the financially strapped urban center if a plan to turn it into the site of weekly midget auto races comes to fruition.
WASHINGTON, July 26 Senator Mike Mansfield, the majority leader, said today that the Senate might not have time to vote this year on a bill to break up 18 large oil companies.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 26-Jimmy Wright of Fenway won medalist honors by two strokes in the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association championship today, carding a 33, 34 67 on the 6,403-yard Siwanoy Country Club course here, where par is 36, 35 71.

The earnings posture of the oil industry in the first half of 1976 was clarified yesterday as a number of the major companies announced higher profits for both the second quarter and the first six months of the year.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) The Justice Department is seeking damages from the American Ship Building Company for alleged inclusion of illegal political contributions in claims for Government payments on a ship-building contract.
FORT BENTON, Mont. It was close to midnight. Only the inebriated antics of a few young farmers down by the levee on the Missouri River disturbed the quiet of the little town.

MIAMI, July 28 (AP) As a lighthouse crew in the Dry Tortugas fought to save some of 30 beached pilot whales today, experts were puzzling over who, after four years without such beachings, three groups of deep water mammal have stranded themselves ashore in two weeks.

NEW BRUNSWICK, July 26 The State Department of Transportation and community environment groups clashed today at a public hearing on the proposed construction of a highway bridge over the Raritan River here as part of a project to develop State Route 18 into a major east-west freeway.

SAN FRANCISCO July 26 Richard A. Schoenfeld's attorney said today that his client would plead not guilty to 43 charges of kidnapping and robbery in connection with the abduction earlier this month of 26 children and their school bus driver near Chowchilla in San Joaquin Valley.

KINGS POINT, L.I., July 26 (UPI) The United States Merchant Marine Academy announced today that it would not press sexual-misconduct charges against Cadet Nancy Donnelly, who resigned after being found in bed with her fiance but who was later reinstated after charges of sex discrimination were raised.

WASHINGTON, July 26 Claude C. Wild Jr. the former Gulf Oil Corporation lobbyist who over a period of 13 years received more than $4 million from the company's overseas affiliates for distribution to political campaigns in this country, went on trial here today for making a $5,000 contribution to Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii.
HARTFORD, July 26 (AP) A 13-year-old plan to encourage preservation of open spaces, farmland and forests has worked, but needs help, a state report says.

MONTREAL, July 25 Susan Morgan clomped through the Olympic Village last night in an enormous pair of Dutch wooden shoes, bright blue Rumanian sweat socks, a red rowing club shirt from the Soviet Union and a pair of Polish rowing trousers that looked like short long johns.
A pilot was killed last night when his small aircraft plunged to the front yard of a Syosset, L.I., home after striking a seaplane carrying five passengers from Fire Island to Manhattan.

FLANAGAN, Ill., July 19 If President Ford is still concerned about using the word "detente" in dealing with the Soviet Union, he could draw some comfort today from the fact that Geria Ulianov does not use that term either. Indeed, Mr. Ulianov does not even recognize it.

In the true tradition of the old Westerns, Ronnie Reagan with feather in his cap, eyes squinting, guns a-blazin' swoops down on the enemy camp on his black stallion, snatches a hostage right out of the hands of his sleeping guardians, and, crossing a neighboring Ford, triumphantly rides off through the vastnesses of Penn's Woods into the western sunset. Fadeout.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) The Justice Department formally expressed today its opposition to the formation of the National Securities Clearing Corporation, saying the merger of three major clearing agencies into one would violate antitrust laws.
BALTIMORE, July 26 Now that they are in second place, the Baltimore Orioles are taking the Eastern Division race seriously.

Anna Marie Bartnett, who taught in the New Rochelle schools for 48 years and became its supervisor of language arts, died Sunday in New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center. She was 69 years old and lived at 30 Perth Avenue, New Rochelle.
A pilot was killed last night when his small aircraft plunged to the front yard of a Syosset, L.I., home after striking a seaplane carrying five passengers from Fire Island to Manhattan.
PASADENA, Calif., July 26 Viking 1 instruments have reported that Mars has an atmosphere that project scientists believe is "encouraging to the search for life but by no means conclusive."
The original Tin Pan Alley, famed street of songs where many of America's popular tunes were created, lived again yesterday if only for a half-hour.

Prices eased slightly in slow trading in the credit markets yesterday as dealers awaited two critical developments set for this week in Washington. In the corporate sector, bond prices slipped by 1/8 or point in a number of issues. A cut in the prime rate to 7 percent from 7 percent by First National Bank of Chicago failed to provide any lift for the market.
A man with a gun was overpowered and disarmed last night as he began to point a loaded automatic handgun at Bulent Ecevit, the former Prime Minister of Turkey, in the lobby of the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, July 26 Justice Department lawyers investigating the Central Intelligence Agency's 20-year program of opening mail between the United States and Communist countries have recommended against the criminal prosecution of agency officials involved in the project, a Government official familiar with the investigation said today.

BONN, July 26 In West Germany, the candidate with the teeth is Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, and though his smile is as broad as Jimmy Carter's, his edge over his conservative opponent looks much narrower now.

HATTERAS, N.C. Blazing down from a cloudless sky, the sun had raised the temperature to over 90 degrees by the time we set forth with Ken Lauer, fishing guide, from Teach's Lair Marina for an afternoon of cobia fishing on Pamlico Sound.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 26 In his outlandish shoulder pads, Richard Todd gave the appearance today of a football player wearing a zoot suit.
TRENTON, July 26 In the throes of the state's fiscal crisis last year, Governor Byrne decided to forgo a $5,000 raise. It was only a gesture, but it undercut the badgering of political opponents.

Steel production for the week ended July 24 posted a gain of 0.6 percent and thus ended three consecutive weeks of declines, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The nation's steel mills poured 2.6 million tons in the most recent week, which meant that their production capability utilization was 85.6 percent.

PLAINS, Ga., July 26 Jimmy Carter, the Democratic Presidential nominee, and his running mate, Senate Walter F. Mondale, began a series of national policy briefings today with a session on defense involving eight experts ranging from scholars to former top Pentagon officials.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) Jimmy Connors relentlessly ground out a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Raul Ramirez of Mexico and captured the $125,000 Washington Star tennis tournament tonight.

A 33-year-old man who allegedly sublet his Upper East Side studio apartment to 33 people last January and then ran off with their $17,000 in deposits on the day they all arrived to move in has been arrested and charged with grand larceny.

Leaders of the Co-op City strike against increased carrying charges yesterday lugged $20 million in withheld payments to State Supreme Court in the Bronx and handed it over to themselves, since they now are the board of directors for the giant housing project.
PHILADELPHIA, July 26 The Mets, who just came from Montreal, caught the Olympic spirit. They played like amateurs tonight.
Texas Instruments, the leading producer of semiconductor products, reported yesterday a doubling in second-quarter sales and earnings from the depressed year-earlier level.
One of the most successful clubs in the New York metropolitan area will move to bigger quarters later this week.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) Representative Robert N. Giaimo, Democrat of Connecticut, testifying at public hearings today, denied under oath any knowledge about how a secret House Intelligence Committee report was leaked to the press. He did not believe the report was a classified document, he added.

Mayor Beame yesterday ordered the consolidation of three midtown development offices into a single new Midtown Action Office and created a separate umbrella agency to take over the work of the development offices in upper and lower Manhattan, downtown Brooklyn and Jamaica, Queens.

PARIS, July 26 Pierre Cardin showed some dresses with one pants leg, JeanLouis Scherrer presented outdoor gear for the upper-class woodsman, and all the Americans in town turned out for the Christian Dior show after lunching at the Relais Plaza. The week-long Paris fall couture sweepstakes were off and running and the winner of the first day's race, by many lengths, was Christian Dior.
MIAMI, July 26 (AP) Prime Minister Fidel Castro said today that Cuban troops and arms would remain in Angola to protect the West African nation from any future invaision and help its development.

TOKYO, July 26 Many Japanese are reliving the period of the American occupation of their nation these days with the continuing release of hitherto secret postwar documents that shed some light on the sometimes shaky relationships between conqueror and conquered.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 27 Former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka was arrested this morning for alleged involvement in the multi-million-dollar Lockheed Aircraft bribery scandal.

SING ALONG WITH RINA Most Italian festivals here emphasize food. Tonight there is one that emphasizes song. The Italian Actors Union is sponsoring "Canti d'Italia," a variety show featuring Italian comedy and songs.

This has been a thrilling and historic month in the saga of man's exploration of space. Since the instrument package dropped onto Mars from the Viking 1 spacecraft made its successful landing on July 20, a torrent of pictures and scientific data has been coming back to earth. As a result, more has been learned about Mars these past few days than in all previous history.

WASHINGTON, July 26 Law enforcement officers were unable today to explain what motivated a 30-year-old taxi driver who was fatally shot last night after he scaled a White House fence carrying a threefoot length of pipe.

LONDON, July 26 Nearly every segment of British politics and industry has reacted skeptically to the Labor Government's decision last week to cut public spending and raise business taxes despite rising unemployment.

James D. Hanlon, a lawyer for the Tidal Marine International Corporation, received a five-year prison sentence yesterday for his participation in a fraudulent scheme that allegedly obtained bank loans of more than $60 million.
To expand its $8 million business in art reproductions and books, the Metropolitan Museum of Art will construct a five-story art publications center in space within the museum.

She was smiling at him, and he was looking at the piano, and when he started to speak he sounded like Henry A. Kissinger. Still, with the smile, the big bow tie and the spotlight's reflection off his glasses he was gemutlich, a middle-aged Teutonic cherub. This was Albert Hague performing.

Fritz Efaw was jailed in Oklahoma City yesterday, following his arraignment for draft evasion and ordered to stand trial the week of Aug. 12 on a charge the United States attorney had moved to dismiss. Eleven days earlier, Mr. Efaw, who returned from England voluntarily as an alternate delegate of overseas Democrats, had been placed in nomination for Vice President at the convention here so he could speak in favor of a general amnesty.

The First National Bank of Chicago, one of the nation's largest commercial lending institutions, announced a quarter-point reduction in its prime lending rate yesterday, signaling the first general decline in the cost of business credit since January.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) The Federal Government finished the fiscal year 1976 with a budget deficit of $65.6 billion, which was $10.4 billion below earlier estimates, the Government said today.

SUMMIT The Summit Child-Care Center, a second home for 102 children of working families, say its environment is designed to stimulate fun, curiosity and creativity. The center's planners seem to have achieved their goals.
NAIROBI, Kenya, July 26 President Idi Amin of Uganda, acknowledging that his country is suffering a severe shortage of gasoline, has resumed his war of words against neighboring Kenya.

MADRID, July 26 (UPI) Thousands of auto workers crowded around King Juan Carlos I at their plant today, shouting demands for a political amnesty and the rehiring of colleagues dismissed for joining in an illegal strike.

The United Hospital Fund of New York has named DeWitt Peterkin Jr. as chairman of its 1976 citywide campaign to raise money for its 52 voluntary, nonprofit member hospitals. Mr. Peterkin is vice chairman of the board of J. P. Morgan Company and of its subsidiary, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) Federal public health officials told Congress today that overuse and abuse of the Medicare and Medicaid programs were a much greater problem than outright fraud.

A school for working adults seeking a high school equivalency diploma faces an uncertain future because of the city's financial straits. Ironically, the school doesn't cost the city anything since the teachers donate their services.

When he was back in his native France working for his familys' chain of piece-goods stores, William E. Bouchara saw a smart entrepreneur putting up bus-stop shelters with advertising panels and said to himself, "How stupid am I not to have thought of that."
LOGGERHEAD KEY, Fla., July 27 (UPI) Rescue workers hauled 29 beached whales off this remote island into deep water today in hopes the school would abandon its suicide attempts and swim away.

LOS ANGELES, July 27 William and Emily Harris angered over a series of rulings by their trial judge and knowing that Patricia Hearst could be called to testify against them suddenly rested their case today without calling a witness.

TOKYO, July 27 Amid mounting political turmoil, Prime Minister Takeo Miki vowed today to pursue a thoroughgoing investigation of the Lockheed Aircraft bribery scandal following the arrest this morning of his predecessor and fellow party member, former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka.
In professional investing circles, it is almost universally assumed that stocks are superior to bonds as an investment medium.

The United States regained the gold medal in Olympic basketball last night, defeating Yugoslavia, 95-74. In 1972 the United States suffered its only defeat in 40 years of Olympic basketball when the Soviet Union won a controversial final, 51-50. The Russians lost to Yugoslavia in Mondays semifinal.

Whether George Blanda will play for the Oakland Raiders this season is largely out of the hands of the 48year-old place-kicker-reserve quarterback who is eager to start his 27th season in professional football.

The Soviet airline Aeroflot was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday for offering illegal rebates of approximately 50 percent on tickets for trans-Atlantic flights between Paris and Washington.
The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest industrial enterprise, announced yesterday a slight drop in net income for the second quarter but an increase in profts for the 1976 first half.
Charging that the city had unfairly shortened library hours, dozens of upper West Side residents started a sit-in last night at the Columbia branch of the New York Public Library.
PLAINS, Ga., July 27--Herman E. Talmadge, the tight-lipped Democratic senior Senator from Georgia, once an outspoken segregationist, may have put his finger on it.
Sarah Greenberg, a 65-yearold blind woman who has been robbed five times in her little newspaper-stationery store on Morningside Heights, has been robbed again, this time at home.
BUENOS AIRES, July 27 Argentina's military Government has severely crippled, if not yet destroyed, the leftwing guerrilla movement here through a policy of repression without quarter.
CHICAGO, July 27 (UPI) A toy designer at Marvin Glass and Associates killed three of the concern's employees and himself today and wounded two other persons, the police said.

CHOWCHILLA, Calif., July 27 The nightmare and miracle of kidnapping and escape were relived with trepidation and curiosity here last night by local residents who flocked to the fairground auditorum to watch a rerun of television coverage of the events of two weeks ago.

ROME, July 27 (Reuters) The leaders of Italy's Christian Democratic Party tonight authorized Prime Min ister-designate Giulia Andreotti to forma minority Government dependent on the goodwill of the Communist Party.
For nine months of the year Joe Clinton teaches school history in Huntington, L. I., and for three months he is a lifeguard lieutenant at Jones Beach. He wishes it were the other way around.

Ramsey Clark, one of five candidates for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate from New York, yesterday proposed a "net worth tax" on properties held by the rich that he predicted would bring in more than $11 billion to the Federal treasury.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) If Senator Richard S. Schweiker does not become Ronald Reagan's Vice President he has another offer.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 27 Bertram R. Firestone's Honest Pleasure returned to the races today at Monmouth Park after laying off since the Preakness, but the ...
Nils Lofgren and Rick Derringer, two rock guitarists, introduced their new bands to New York at the Schaefer Festival on Monday. Mr. Derringer is the old-timer of the two in terms of experience.

BALTIMORE, July 27 Are the Yankees panicking? Making as many errors as hits (four) and held scoreless until the ninth inning, they fell before Jim Palmer and the Baltimore Orioles tonight, 4-1. It was the second straight defeat here. They scored a total of only two runs in the two games.

JOHANNESBURG, July 27 The security police in the Transkei have arrested nine members of the opposition Democratic Party, effectively stifling opposition to the territory's acceptance of independence from the South African Government.
LOUISVILLE, July 27 (AP) Two young Americans scored impressive victories today in the first round of the $125,000 Louisville International tennis tournament.
AMSTERDAM, July 27 Viktor Korchnoi, a Soviet grandmaster and the world's No. 2rated chess player, asked today for political asylum in the Netherlands.
PEKING, Wednesday, July 28--A powerful earthquake shook the Chinese cites of Peking, Tientsin and Tangshan early this morning.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 27 The United States Navy today evacuated 308 Americans and other foreigners from the Moslem section of Beirut. A United States Embassy official described the evacuation as probably the last from Lebanon.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27--Recovering admirably from their amateurish performance 24 hours earlier, the Mets defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 4-1, tonight and slashed their division deficit behind the first place Phils to 16 games.

MONTREAL, July 26 The ancient Greeks held the body beautiful in high esteem, yet a curious Puritan ethic prevailed at Olympia. Because athletes in the Olympic Games wore only the uniform they were born in, women were barred as spectators and if one of the sisterhood was caught peeking she was dropped off the nearest cliff.

MONTREAL, July 27 (AP) Klaus Dibiasi of Italy, in his final performance in international diving, fought off the challenge of a young American, Greg Louganis, tonight and won the 10-meter platform competition for his third consecutive Olympic title in the event.

WASHINGTON, July 27 John B. Connally endorsed today President Ford's candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination as other conservatives in the party rebelled against Ronald Reagan's designation of a liberal to be his prospective running mate.
Stocks declined once again on the American Stock Exchange in slow trading yesterday, with the market value index closing at 104.19, off 0.38.
LEEDS, England, July 27 (Reuters) The West Indies clinched the cricket series against England by winning the fourth test today by 55 runs for an unbeatable 2-0 lead with one match to play.
PLAINS, Ga., July 27 A group of nine economists briefed Jimmy Carter and his running mate, Senator Walter F. Mondale, on economic issues today.
TOKYO, July 23 A Japanese grocery store chain, which pioneered a computerized supermarket here, has learned at least two valuable lessons from its unsuccessful venture:

MONTREAL, July 27 The Olympic Games were harassed by domestic dispute today when 2,000 taxicab drivers snarled traffic in downtown Montreal. But an international dispute was averted when the United States indefinitely postponed a trip by women gymnasts to South Africa, the nation whose racial policies embroiled the Olympics last week.

DETROIT, July 27 (AP) Bill Beagan, the commissioner of the International Hockey League, was asked today by the United States House of Representatives to appear before its select committee on professional sports Thursday in Washington.

LOS ANGELES July 27 Ronald Reagan's chief campaign strategist today defended the selection of Senator Richard S. Schweiker of Pennsylvania as the Californian's running mate as a "tough" decision necessary to broaden Mr. Reagan's appeal to win both the Republican nomination and the November election.

Joseph Grubach, deputy district director of the United States Customs Service in Detroit, died Friday as a result of injuries received in an automobile accident there. He was 69 years old and a resident of Detroit.
It's maddening being the only one who knows what's wrong with New York.

BAYREUTH, West Germany, July 27--Tonight Wagner's "Siegfried" was the opera subjected to the ministrations of Patrice Chereau, and the young French director had a wonderful time in the first two acts.

OAKLAND, Calif. Washington's attention is permanently fixed, it seems, only on half the world-primarily on the Soviet Union and on our traditional European allies. Toward Asia its attention seems sporadic. Intermittently in the recent past there have been sudden and distinct policy shifts, the most profound of which the Japanese have labeled "shocks."

Ronald Reagan's choice of a liberal Republican running mate, Senator Richard S. Schweiker of Pennsylvania, has apparently not strengthened his already weak hand in New York, one of the most liberal states in the nation.
A move by the Federal Reserve to inject temporary reserves into the banking system resulted in a slight price improvement yesterday in most sectors of the credit market.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 27 Dora IV won overall honors in the 333mile Chicago-to-Mackinac race for the third straight year this week and her skipper, Lynn Williams, says he's ready to retire.

PARIS, July 27 The economic watchdog of the Western industrialized nations says their recovery is proceeding too slowly to make much of a dent in unemployment, but it warns that any faster growth would accelerate inflation and start a new boom-and-bust cycle.
Yesterday, all of John Lennon's troubles seemed so far away and now it looks as though he's here to stay.

MOSCOW, July 27 (AP) The Soviet press agency Tass today reported the death of Abram M. Room, who became a film director shortly after the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution, gained his greatest fame for a 1945 film, "The Invasion," and was still actively working in recent years. He was 82 years old.
Jim Barr, the only pitcher on the San Francisco staff with a winning record, held the champion Reds to seven hits as the Giants walloped Cincinnati, 9-4, in Riverfront Stadium last night.

In the latest installment in the banks' continuing attempt to block proposed changes in accounting rules, the head of New York City's largest bank said yesterday that the changes could block an effort by the Municipal Assistance Corporation to stretch out its debt repayments.
The Phoenix House Foundation has bought the Riverside Plaza Hotel on the West Side for $1.3 million and plans to convert it into its largest residential drug-rehabilitation facility in Manhqttan.

Gabor Szabo's quartet and the Richard Davis trio complement each other so perfectly that one wonders whether their booking at the Bottom Line this week was a matter of chance or of intelligent forethought. In any event, the two groups finish their run tonight, and both are worth hearing.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 27 (AP) The president of the United Mine Workers urged coal miners to return to work today as their wildcat strike spread from West Virginia into at least four other states.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I.--Before she enplaned for Mexico a short while ago, we had a hastily scribbled postcard from our friend, the English-born authority on Mexican cooking. Diana Kennedy:

SWEETGRASS, Mont. On the waving wheat plains along the Montana-Canada line sit sister towns in which the border is not just a fact of life, but the major business of both-Sweetgrass, Mont., population 150, and Coutts, Alberta, population 450.

ANCORA, July 27 The New Jersey psychiatric hospital here has two chief executives. One, who was dismissed by Ann Klein, the State's Commissioner of Institutions and Agencies, obtained a court order staying the action with the support of the hospital's trustees. The other chief executive received an appointment on an acting basis.

The Passaic County, N.J., Prosecutor said yesterday that he might submit the 10-year-old murder case against Rubin (Hurricane) Carter to a new grand jury, but he remained committed to retrying the former boxer and John Artis on triple-homicide charges.
MONTREAL, July 27 (UPI) A local group calling itself the Ukrainian Olympic Committee staged a protest tonight in the Olympic Stadium during a soccer match between the Soviet Union and East Germany.
Harriett A. Ames, a financial backer of "Brigadoon," "Guys and Dolls" and other Broadway theatrical productions, died yesterday in her home at 885 Park Avenue. She was 62 years old.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 27 There are 14 defensive linemen on the New York Giants' roster and only six or seven will survive training camp. But sometimes it looks as if Jay Fry is determined that no one will survive his training methods.
Macy's New York has confirmed reports that 15 of its 16 stores, including the Herald Square store, would begin Sunday operations sometime between Aug. 29 and Sept. 19. Page 47.
Mayor Beame moved in court yesterday to try to stop a sixmonth-old investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into past and present New York City fiscal practices.

Although Sailors Snug Harbor is one of the three leading landholders in Manhattan, the trustees who administer its shelter for retired seamen on Staten Island say they are not earning enough to keep the home afloat.

SAN LEANDRO, Calif., July 27 (AP) The nationwide hunt for the kidnappers of 26 Chowchilla school children and their bus driver shifted to the Northwest after reports had been confirmed that one of two suspects sought had been seen in Washington and Idaho, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.

Making his only visit since 1970 and his first since assuming office last year, Prime Minister J. Malcolm Fraser of Australia was welcomed by President Ford at the White House yesterday amid pledges of their nation's mutual al-... legiance. Heat and humidity affected some of the 1,000 guests invited to the lawn ceremony and Nancy Kissinger left midway through it. A White House nurse said the wife of the Secretary of State felt "light-headed."

Recenty 25 students at the Marick Cooking School in New York City conducted a comparison tasting of four California white wines and four French white burgundies all made from the chardonnay grape. The tasting was similar in some ways to one held a few weeks earlier in Paris and reported on here.
Indications of a slight tightening in the Federal Reserve Board's monetary policy sent the stock market lower yesterday in heavier trading.

The producers of two Broadway productions, "The Magic Show" and "The Night That Made America Famous," were ordered yesterday to offer to return up to $700,000 to investors in the shows because the producers had failed to file appropriate financial information with the state.
WASHINGTON, July 27 The Federal Power Commission today almost tripled the amount producers can charge for interstate natural gas in a move expected to cost consumers up to $1.5 billion a year.

The following appraisal of the play of Viktor Korchnoi, the Soviet grandmaster who asked for political asylum in the Netherlands, was written by Robert Byrne, chess columnist of The New York Times, who is playing in the Interzonal Tournament in Biel, Switzerland.

Macy's New York, the metropolitan area's largest retailer, confirmed yesterday published reports that 15 of 16 of its stores would begin Sunday operations sometime between Aug. 29 and Sept. 19. The concern's Herald Square store, the largest retail store in the country, will be among those opening its doors on Sunday.

TRENTON, July 27 The Tocks Island Dam controversy, which was reprised in the last few days in hearings be fore a Senate subcommittee in Washington, is fanning a new dispute between Philadelphia and New Jersey officials over the state's right to divert up to 100 million gallons of water daily from the Delaware River.

STRIP JOINT Three teams from high schools in the United States, Mexico and Canada will compete today at Rockefeller Center to see which can put together a fully stripped automobile engine the quickest.

PASADENA, Calif., July 27 Another Viking spacecraft, now approaching Mars, fired its rocket tonight to change course slightly in preparation for orbiting the planet Aug. 7 and joining Viking 1 in its historic Martian explorations.

WASHINGTON, July 27 The Justice Department's civil rights division has begun an investigation into a July 7 burglary of the Socialist Workers Party's offices in Denver that was reportedly carried out by an informer assigned to spy on the party by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 27 Five American citizens are being held in Yugoslav prisons, two for political offenses, one for war crimes, one for murder and one for narcotics offenses, American consular officials said today.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., July 27 Most of the outstanding amateur golfers in the New York metropolitan area staged their annual driving, putting, sandblasting, drinking and eating gathering today on the stately grounds of the Baltusrol Golf Club. It was a particularly fine outing of fun and games for the Westchester contingent, which came out ahead of the New Jersey and Long Island teams and won the Stoddard Cup.
There is a new maxim circulating among a growing number of college students: study now, but why pay later?

Budget cuts are threatening to impair the ability of the High School of Performing Arts "to provide trained professionals in the New York cultural scene," according to Irving Orfuss, the school's deputy principal.

PINAR DEL RIO, Cuba, July 27 (Reuters) Prime Minister Fidel Castro says Cuba will continue to provide Angola with military support but that the former Portuguese African colony needs technical help more than military assistance.

The National Institutes of Health said yesterday that they would scrutinize the American Museum of Natural History's federally financed study of the sex lives of cats, which animal rights groups in New York City have called cruel and inhumane.
MONTREAL, July 27 The long road back from failure ended in a gold medal for the United States Olympic men's basketball team tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 27 John B. Connally endorsed today President Ford's candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination as other conservatives in the party rebelled against Ronald Reagan's designation of a liberal to be his prospective running mate.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 27 Jimmy Wright of Fenway won both his matches today in advancing to the quarterfinal round of the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association championship at Siwanoy Country Club.

Mary Ballou Handy Reynolds of Richmond, widow of Lieut. Gov. J. Sargeant Reynolds of Virginia, was married yesterday afternoon to Michael Ballentine of Washington, a fund-raiser there for Ford's Theater and other cultural enterprises.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 27 The United States Navy today evacuated 308 Americans and other foreigners from the Moslem section of Beirut. A United States Embassy official described the evacuation as probably the last from Lebanon.

The New Haven Nighthawks of the American Hockey League will serve this season as the primary farm club for the New York Rangers of the National League, the Rangers announced yesterday. The Nighthawks replace the financially troubled Providence Reds, whose five-year agreement with the Rangers was completed last season.
NAIROBI, July 27 (AP) The secretary general of the Organization of African Unity Eteki Mboumoua, will attempt to mediate the feud between Kenya and Uganda, it was announced today.

The Conference Board said yesterday that the help-wanted advertising index in June rose to its highest level in more than a year and a half. At 96, (1967=100) the index rose two points above the May level and five points above April. It stands at 15 points above June of 1975.
PEKING, Wednesday, July 28 A powerful earthquake shook Peking before dawn today, cracking walls, smashing windows and sending thousands of people rushing into the streets.

WASHINGTON, July 27 A Federal judge decided today that Claude C. Wild Jr., the former Gulf Oil Corporation lobbyist, could not be punished for making an illegal campaign contribution to Senator Daniel K. Inouye because the threeyear statute of limitations ran out before the Government indicted him.
UTICA, N.Y. The young man edged and elbowed his way into the Mayor's office on the second floor of the Utica City Hall.

The United States regained the gold medal in Olympic basketball last night, defeating Yugoslavia, 95-74. In 1972 the United States suffered its only defeat in 40 years of Olympic basketball when the Soviet Union won a controversial final, 51-50. The Russians lost to Yugoslavia in Mondays semifinal.

TOKYO, July 27 Amid mounting political turmoil, Prime Minister Takeo Miki vowed today to pursue a thoroughgoing investigation of the Lockheed Aircraft bribery scandal following the arrest this morning of his predecessor and fellow party member, former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) A record pace of oil imports pushed the nation's trade accounts back into deficit in June after a one-month surplus, the Government reported today.

PARIS The Greco-Turkish crisis is again heating up just two years after the neighboring states, whose ancient quarrels dominate national emotions far more than their theoretical alliance in NATO, came to the verge of war over Turkey's military landing in Cyprus.

The Consolidated Edison Company reported yesterday a 1.7 percent rise in net income for the second quarter on a 5.6 percent increase in revenues. Unit sales of electricity, gas and steam trailed the yearearlier level.
WASHINGTON, July 27 The Federal Power Commission today almost tripled the amount producers can charge for interstate natural gas in a mova expected to cost consumers up to $1.5 billion a year.

A chorus of 20 well-known New Yorkers, including Bess Myerson, Rocky Graziano, Tammy Grimes, Robert Merrill and Ruby Dee, and led by Skitch Henderson, gathered yesterday to record a song called "Mad About Manhattan." The proceeds will go to the Citizens Committee for New York City.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 27 Millbrook's Moon Shadow, handled by Nancy Prant, scored two victories to move into the lead for the large pony hunter championship today at the Orange County horse show.

WASHINGTON, July 27 Working through a young aide to Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Rockwell International nearly succeeded recently in writing new language into a Senate committee report protecting its controversial Condor missile program.

Accidents, in the sense of mishearing a bid or some such misfortune, are rare in world championships. But their incidence has slightly increased in the last two years with the introduction of bidding screens.

New York City has a new national tennis champion, an exciting young player following the path of Vitas Gerulaitis. He is Johnny McEnroe, 17 years old, from Douglaston, Queens, who recently won the United States junior clay-court title, as Gerulaitis did four years ago.

A 51 year old Manhattan dentist was arrested yesterday after detectives watched by means of a hidden camera as he allegedly molested an undercover woman investigator as she sat unconscious in the dental chair under an anesthetic.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 27 The Administrator of the New York City Environmental Protection Administration said today that the city would have to shut down part of its water supply and sewage system if it was forced to stop discharging raw sewage into New York Harbor.

William Ward Rayner, vice president, secretary and general counsel of the Macmillan Inc., publishing and other enterprises, fell to his death yesterday morning at the Berkshire Hotel, Madison Avenue and 52d Street.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) A settlement was reached today in the week-long California cannery strike that had endangered many of the state's crops.

Traveling across Asia by train in the course of gathering material for "The Great Railway Bazaar," the travel book that transformed him last year from a promising young novelist into a famous best-selling author Paul Theroux visited Saigon, Vietnam, and saw a tall, bearded man in pajamas running across a railroad track.

HACKENSACK, July 27 Deterring welfare fraud is out of the question if those convicted of it continue to receive suspended sentences or fail make court-ordered restitution, Joseph C. Woodcock Jr., Bergen County Prosecutor, said today. Serious deficiencies in county welfare administration contribute to and encourage frauds, he said.

The arrest of Japan's former Prime Minister, Kakuei Tanaka, is the most dramatic indication yet of the heights to which the rot of corporate bribery may have spread in world trade. No wonder the ruling Liberal Democrats of Japan were so nervous about the unfolding disclosures of Lockheed Aircraft's multimillion-dollar payoffs, a nervousness shared by United States Government investigators who presumably were aware of a possible Tanaka link to the web of corruption.
WASHINGTON, July 27 American concerns that boycott Israel or use bribery as a foreign-sales tool stand to lose millions of dollars in tax benefits under a provision approved by the Senate.
MIAMI BEACH, July 27 Six and a half years after it opened in Tokyo and after playing on three continents, the musical "Gone With the Wind" is still trying to reach Broadway.

Theodore Kiendl, a prominent trial and appellate lawyer in New York State and Federal courts for half a century, died Monday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y., after a short illness. He was 86 years old.

The Union Pacific Corporation, the holding company that operates the Union Pacific Railroad, as well as petroleum, mineral, coal and land development interests, reported yesterday a strong earnings rebound in the second quarter from the depressed year-earlier level.

The producers of two Broadway productions, "The Magic Show" and "The Night That Made America Famous," were ordered yesterday to offer to return up to $700,000 to investors in the shows because the producers had failed to file appropriate financial information with the state.

LOS ANGELES, July 27 William and Emily Harris angered over a series of rulings by their trial judge and knowing that Patricia Hearst could be called to testify against them suddenly rested their case today without calling a witness.

A chorus of 20 well-known New Yorkers, including Bess Myerson, Rocky Graziano, Tammy Grimes, Robert Merrill and Ruby Dee, and led by Skitch Henderson, gathered yesterday to record a song called "Mad About Manhattan." The proceeds will go to the Citizens Committee for New York City.

MONTREAL, July 27 Say goodbye to the world records of 9 seconds for the 100-yard dash by Ivory Crockett and Houston McTear and 9.9 for the 100-meter dash by Steve Williams (five times) and many others. They are world records no more.
WASHINGTON, June 27 The Federal Reserve has decided on no change in its target for growth of the nation's narrowly defined money supply, known as M-1, for the year ahead, it was disclosed today.
AMSTERDAM, July 27 Viktor Korchnoi, a Soviet grandmaster and the world's No. 2rated chess player, asked today for political asylum in the Netherlands.

MONTREAL, July 27 Leo used an uppercut, Chuck a southpaw's jab and Howard a combination of guile and dynamite. Then Sugar Ray finished off the evening with a razzle-dazzle display that brought shouts of "Ali" from an Olympic boxing crowd of 6,500.
Pork belly futures-drifted lower yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting heavy supplies in storage and slack demand. Bellies are the raw material for bacon.

Four former top officials of the Stirling Homex Corporation and a lawyer who worked for the company were charged in a Federal indictment yesterday with a stock fraud scheme that allegedly cost investors $40 million.

More than 100 faculty members at the Borough of Manhattan Community College staged a sit-in in the president's office yesterday to protest his plan to dismiss 103 teachers and sharply reduce the number of liberal arts courses offered.

TRENTON, July 27 The bill signed by President Ford yesterday to appropriate $1.6 billion for problems of coastal localities has some connection to offshore oil drilling, but is not the all-encompassing bill that the state administration wants Congress to pass to protect states from damage caused by oil companies drilling in the ocean.

WASHINGTON, July 27 The wide grin is still there but it disappears a bit more quickly these days. The big square body is still trim and athletic but some of the spring is gone and it occasionally sags a little from fatigue.

Some dogs, like some people, have very little luck. A mongrel that acquired the name "Bum" since it arrived last Thursday at the rear door of the Queens County Courthouse seemed to be in good fortune until yesterday.

Some hope that the whale might yet be saved from extermination has at last been raised by action of the International Whaling Commission at its recent session. While the American proposal for a 10-year moratorium on killing of whales was again turned down, the commission actually has succeeded in reducing the overall quota by about 40 percent from a year ago-now down to 26,000 for all species of whale in all oceans.
TOKYO, July 27 There were three signs on the wall of a Niigata elementary school half a century ago.
After financing a $27 million program to design a bus of the future, the Government yesterday decided to mandate only a single specification developed in five years of testing nine prototype buses.

The boarded Royal Manhattan Hotel on Eighth Avenue at 44th Street reopened the other day, not for guests but for a liquidation sale. When the furniture, kitchen equipment and other paraphernalia of the hotel's sunnier days as a theater district tourist center are sold, the locks will go on again.
WASHINGTON, July 27--American concerns that boycott Israel or use bribery as a foreign-sales tool stand to lose millions of dollars in tax benefits under a provision approved by the Senate.

WASHINGTON It has been pointed out that a few members of Congress spent 18 days of their lives developing recommendations for Congressional reform. I applaud them, but I would like to point out that 10 other members of this House gave nine months of their lives looking at the atrocities of the United States intelligence community, and the reaction of this body was not as profound.
A tentative contract agreement was reached late last night between management and union representatives for bus drivers who had threatened a strike in New Haven, Hartford and Stamford, Conn.

The directors of the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday raised the company's quarterly dividend payment by 50 cents, from $1.75 to $2.25 a share.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 27 Zambia urged the Security Council today to condemn South Africa as having carried out aggression this month, causing the death of 24 persons and infuries to 45.
SACRAMENTO, Calif. Pete Ranzany, 147 pounds, Sacramento, knocked out Keith Averette, 148, Akron, Ohio, 2 rounds.

ALBANY, July 27 Governor Carey played tourist yesterday. It was a package tour of the Southern Tier, a major region of the state he had somehow never visited during his 19 months in office, and the tour was designed not so much to give the tourist his money's worth as to show the locals that they were getting their money's worth out of him.

WASHINGTON, July 27 Feminists in the Republican Party are nagry at the treatment they believe women are getting from their party and they fear that many of the best women workers will simply sit out the campaign if steps are not taken to improve things.
WHITE PLAINS, July 27 These days, WFAS-Radio, which bills itself as "the spirit of Westchester," is devoted to Frank Sinatra, Tom Jones and "the Mysterious Darter."
ALBANY, July 27 Governor Carey signed into law today a package of bills designed to ease the freeing of abandoned children for adoption.

MONTREAL, July 27 In some circles, it might sound corny: "The family that prays together stays together." To the young members of America's family-style Olympic boxing team, the old spiritual slogan makes sense. Before each day's competition at Maurice Richard Arena, they get together and pray in their apartment at Olympic Village.

MADRID, July 27 (AP)--The Spanish Government and the Vatican have agreed on a revision of the 1953 Concordat governing relations between Spain and the Roman Catholic Church, the Government announced today.

Patients with complaints about allegedly incompetent or unethical physicians should take them directly to the New York State Board of Professional Medical Conduct and not depend on the local county medical society for help, the Consumer Help Center says.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) United States officials in Beirut made direct contact with the Palestine Liberation Organization in June for the first time and some liaison will be continued even though the evacuation of Americans who want to leave Lebanon has been completed, the State Department said today.

So incensed was James F. Greco of the Bronx last fall over the scandal surrounding the New York State lottery that he demanded a refund for his 50-cent ticket on the Oct. 23, 1975, Double-Up drawing. The lottery was subsequently suspended by Governor Carey while the scandal was being investigated. Mr. Greco's efforts to obtain a refund got nowhere.

The Beame administration announced yesterday that tightened revenue productionincluding higher pistol permit fees and tougher enforcement of traffic summonses on rentalcar drivers would take care of nearly half of the $50 million in fresh budget cuts scheduled to be imposed next month.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 27 (UPI) A group of 96 defendants pleaded not guilty today to charges of taking part in a Libyan-backed coup attempt against President Gaafar al-Nimeiry early this month.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 27 (UPI) United States District Judge Donald Alsop dismissed today Federal tax charges against the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company stemming from a secret corporate fund.

WASHINGTON July 27 (AP) President Ford said today he would nominate Donald I. Baker to become the Government's chief lawyer in charge of prosecuting antitrust cases, including price fixing and illegal business monopolies.
PARIS, July 27 Peasants, glorious peasants, are prowling the runways once again. Emanuel Ungaro is a believer, and his peasants hardly look as if they spend their days grubbing in the fields.
LISBON, July 27--Portugal's military authorities warned today that they would not tolerate clandestine political activities in the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (Reuters) The Justice Department filed a motion today to settle an antitrust suit against 21 major American publishing houses which charged that they had conspired to divide world markets for the sale of English language books.

A 66-cent rise for a 0.9 per cent increase was reported yesterday in the cost of the city's 41-item market basket for a family of four during the week ended last Friday. It was the second such increase to have occurred during July.
Thirty-five persons were injured when an automobile and a New York City-bound Greyhound bus collided near Columbia, according to the state police.

LOS ANGELES, July 27 Ronald Reagan's chief campaign strategist today defended the selection of Senator Richard S. Schweiker of Pennsylvania as the Californian's running mate as a "tough" decision necessary to broaden Mr. Reagan's appeal to win both the Republican nomination and the November election.

PITTSBURGH, July 27 The United States Steel Corporation today reported a 7 percent second-quarter earnings decline to $119.6 millin, or $1.47 a share, from $128.6 million, or $1.58 a share, in the 1975 quarter.

WISCASSET, Me., July 27 Madeline Burrage, a gemologist whose work in gold and silver and precious and semiprecious stones brought her widespread recognition, died in the Camden Community Hospital yesterday. She was 84 years old.

NAIROBI, Kenya, July 27--Kenya said today that Uganda must meet seven conditions if it wishes to "normalize" relations, including the removal of troops along the border, a cessation of threats to invade and an end to the killing of Kenyans in Uganda.

LONDON, July 28 The "tourist-sodden summer months," in the words of a newspaper letter writer, have befallen drought-parched London. The city is experiencing the biggest tourist boom in its history. Even the Americans, who for two years have shunned foreign travel, are trickling back.

MONTREAL, July 28 French-speaking pilots and airtraffic controllers are suing the Government to test the constitutionality of a new rule forbidding the use of French in conversations between pilots and control towers except at six small Quebec Province airports.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 28 Gene Borek of Sunningdale and Roy Pace of Wee Burn gained the final of the $6,300 Westchester Professional Golfers' Association championship at Siwanoy Country Club today.

RUTHERFORD, July 28 The best of the Olympic spirit without the team competitions was colorfully evident all over Memorial Field today as 672 children from Bergen, Passaic and Hudson Counties took part in the third annual Playground Day.

Dr. Robert E. Kamen, examining physician for the State of New York Workmen's Compensation Board, died yesterday morning in Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. Dr. Kamen who was 60 years old, lived at 165 East 66th Street, and in Brewster, N.Y.

PASADENA, Calif., July 28 The search for life in the soil of Mars began today when Viking 1 reached out with its robot arm, scooped up some finegrained dirt and poured it into the spacecraft's automated biological laboratories.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) The Justice Department unsealed data about a five-yearold secret but the substance of the data was common knowledge all along.

Josephine Markin Lazarus of Ossining, N.Y., a director of the Checker Taxi Company of Chicago and an interior decorator, died Tuesday of leukemia in Phelps Memorial Hospital, North Tarryton, N.Y. She was 58 years old.

LOS ANGELES, July 28 William and Emily Harris lost a fight today for a mistrial on possible jury tampering, even though the prosecution and defense agreed that one of the jurors might have smuggled a 1974 newspaper on Patricia Hearst's kidnapping into the heavily guarded jury room 10 days ago.
Stocks of distillate oil in the Unied States increased last week as the nation's refineries began to build up supplies for the coming winter.

TRENTON, July 28 As a prelude to hearings on a bill to restore the death penalty in New Jersey, state prison officials today displayed the death house and the long-idle electric chair at the state prison here to an entourage of reporters.

FRESNO, Calif., July 28 (UPI) A brief was filed in Fresno County Superior Court yesterday arguing that four Fresno Bee newsmen facing indeterminate jail sentences for refusing to divulge a news source should receive sentences of no more than five days each.
SEVESO, Italy, July 28 (AP) Authorities evacuated 20 more persons today and extended by several miles the zone regarded as dangerously polluted by a cloud of chemicals from a Swiss-owned plant.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 28 (AP) A secondary school for blacks near Johannesburg was severely damaged by fire today, one day after black students clashed with the police in riot-troubled Soweto township.

Grain traders wondered yesterday if at last stability had come to the soybean, wheat and corn markets after their recent price decline. Soybeans for September delivery closed at $6.31, up 5 cents a bushel; September wheat ended at $3.49 , about unchanged, and September corn gained of a cent to close at $2.81 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Philip H. Hoff, a former Governor of Vermont, yesterday was named president of the Coalition to Save New York, an organization of leading banking, insurance, real estate and labor leaders in the city.
LEVITTOWN, L.I., July 28 The Island Trees School Board voted tonight to continue to ban nine of 11 books that had been removed because they had been considered objectionable.

A group of physicians on the house staff of Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx is striking the hospital to protest disciplinary actions taken against seven residents and two faculty members of the hospital who allegedly refused to work during the recent hospital employees' strike.
Wild pitches and hit batsmen are not uncommon for knuckleballers. Atlanta's Phil Niekro has led the National League in both categories at one time or another.

PASADENA, Calif, July 28 The search for life in the soil of Mars began today when Viking 1 reached out with its robot arm, scooped up some finegrained dirt and poured it into the spacecraft's automated biological laboratories.

LONDON, July 28 The Italian loan caper, as it could be called, has seemingly aroused only mild interest in an America preoccupied by politics, But on this side of the Atlantic there has been sharp reaction to the report of an informal agreement by United States, West German, British and French, leaders to withhold further loans to Italy if Communists have any Cabinet posts in the new Italian Government.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (Reuters) There are major shortages and deficiencies in combat equipment stored in Europe for use by United States troops, according to a report today by Senator Hubert H. Humphrey.

TOKYO For the first time in a generation, an electoral struggle is taking place in the United States, at the same time that an ideological power, struggle is going on in China. Each struggle will affect the other.

The New York Racing Association began collecting a bigger share of the parimutuel takeout at Aqueduct yesterday. Governor Carey made it possible in Albany earlier in the day when he signed into law a sweeping measure that is designed to extricate the N.Y.R.A. from a cash crisis.

Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein said yesterday that he had "deduced" that a builder's campaign contribution had influenced Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin and other members of the Board of Estimates to "conspire to defraud the public" in approving a proposal for a Staten Island amusement park last week.
HACKENSACK, N.J., July 28 (AP) Smiles may be the same all over the world, but the dental techniques used to keep those teeth gleaming vary.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) A government employee's union has formally protested to Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld about assignment of Kansas National Guard units to duty during the Republican National Convention at Kansas City, Mo.
The Belmore Hotel on Lexington Avenue, which the police say is a haunt for prostitutes, may close down as a result of a ruling yesterday by a State Supreme Court judge in Manhattan.

Governor Carey and the State Parks and Recreation Commissioner, Orin Lehman, announced yesterday the awarding of more than $2 million in grants, provided equally by the Federal Government and New York City, for upgrading parks and school playgrounds in the city.
It's a long, long time from April to October, but the starts are dwindling down to a precious few for Tom Seaver.

WASHINGTON, July 28 American doctors are stealing more than $300 million a year from Medicare by padding bills, falsifying claims and participating in kickback schemes, Senator Frank E. Moss, chairman of the Senate subcommittee on Long Term Care, charged today.
The United States Pavilion of the 1964-'65 World's Fair will soon be felled by the wrecker's ball unless its last defenders can save the plundered hull and refurbish it for a new life.
