Special to The New York Times BIEL, Switzerland, July 27 Bent Larsen of Denmark increased his lead by achieving 8 points after 11 rounds of the Interzonal Tournament for world championship aspirants here in the Kongresshaus.

Gen. Bernard W. Rogers was appointed by President Ford yesterday to be Army Chief of Staff. Gen. Frederick C. Weyand, the present chief, is retiring after two years in September, when he will be 60 years old.
Bearish economic news drove the stock market lower yesterday in slightly heavier trading.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) The economy in June registered its smallest expansion in seven months, according to a Government report of key enomic trends published today.

DETROIT, July 28 The General Motors Corporation reported today the second highest quarterly earnings in American business history $909 million, or $3.16 a share for the three months that ended June 30.
The American military withdrawal from Thailand, completed last week, reflects a necessary adjustment by both countries to the realities of Asia in the wake of the Vietnam War.

OAKLAND, Calif., July 28 (AP) Blue Moon Odom and Francisco Barrios combined to pitch the major league's second no-hitter of the season, hurling the Chicago White Sox to a 2-1 decision over the Oakland A's tonight. The two pitchers walked 11 men.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) The United States liaison office in Peking reported today that all Americans known to be in China survived the severe earthquake that rocked the PekingTientsin area, the White House announced.
PRAGUE, July 28 (AP) A Czechoslovak airliner carrying 76 people crashed into a recreation lake today while on a landing approach at Bratislava, near Austria's eastern border.
WASHINGTON, July 28 The Treasury announced today a three-part offering to pay off $4.5 billion of maturing securities and raise up to $4.5 billion in new cash.

A judge has ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation to turn over its file concerning an F.B.I. informer who reportedly carried out a burglary on July 7 at the offices of the Socialist Workers Party in Denver.
In other labor disputes across the nation, there were the following developments yesterday:
WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) A Federal court ordered the Federal Power Commission today to delay for the time being the tripled natural gas rates the F.P.C. had announced yesterday.

TRENTON, July 28 Governor Byrne announced plans today to get as much as possible of the $309.5 million in Federal capital construction funds that New Jersey is entitled to under the $3.95 billion Public Works legislation approved by Congress last Thursday over President Ford's veto.
The United States Pavilion of the 1964-65 World's Fair will soon be felled by the wrecker's ball unless its last defenders can save the plundered hull and refurbish it for a new life.

SALAMANCA, N.Y., July 28 (UPI) The first pact between the State of New York and a sovereign Indian nation since the early 1800's was signed today on the Allegany Indian Reservation in Cattaraugus County.

WASHINGTON, July 28 An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation has testified under oath that he participated in "between 50 and 90" burglaries of the Socialist Workers Party headquarters in New York, according to a deposition made public today.

DETROIT, July 28 (AP) One witness took the Fifth Amendment and two others sought unsuccessfully to avoid testifying today before a Federal grand jury investigating the disappearance of James R. Hoffa.

BUENOS AIRES, July 28 Argentina is opening nine productive oil areas for development by private companies in the first stage of a new policy to increase oil output with the use of international capital and technology.

ARMONK, N.Y., July 28 Tom Patri was so far ahead of Tom Dee after eight holes of their final match for the 59th Metropolitan Golf Association junior championship today that surely a missed putt here or a bad chip there would have little bearing on the outcome.
MOBILE, Ala., July 28 (AP) A newspaper photographer made pictures and television cameras rolled today during a murder trial for the first time in an Alabama courtroom.
NORTHPORT, L.I., July 28 The new movie "Life guard" was at the local theater here today, but down at the town beach a lifeguard story of a different nature was developing.

PLAINS, Ga., July 28 (AP) The Democratic Presidential nominee, Jimmy Carter, received a full-scale intelligence briefing today from George Bush, the Director of Central Intelligence. Mr. Bush described the session as being designed to prevent Mr. Carter from making "the wrong mistake.
Whatever the legal merits to his argument, Mayor Beame is not helping the city by challenging a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into New York's fiscal practices over years past.

The Philadelphia 76ers of the National Basketball Association finally have come up with the big center the club has been seeking since the days of Wilt Chamberlain. He is Caldwell Jones. The 6foot-11-inch center, who signed a contract with the club yesterday, said, "I have to play my way into the lineup. People expect a lot of most centers. In the middle, you have to have someone to get it started."

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) The House Banking Committee has received a "flood of complaints" from elderly persons unhappy with a new program of depositing Social Security payments directly into bank accounts, Representative Henry S. Reuss said today.

Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew has taken over the presidency of a non profit educational foundation that advocates a build-up of American nuclear arms, is critical of America's policy of detente with the Soviet Union and expresses sympathy for Palestinian refugees in the Middle East.

ROME, July 28 The Italian Communist Party today reacted cautiously to a decision by the Christian Democratic Party last night to form a government that would be dependent on Communist help in Parliament.
TOKYO, July 28 The first full day of prison life for former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka began, as it does for all prisoners in Japan, with a 20-cent breakfast at 7 A.M.

PARIS, July 28 Yves Saint Laurent presented a fall couture collection today that will change the course of fashion around the world. JUNIEH, Lebanon, July 27 This little coastal town, the "capital" of Kasrawan, the region where Maronite Christians would set up their own state if Lebanon were partitioned, reflects all the contradictions of Lebanon's civil war.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 28 The first official report on the rush-hour train crash at the New Canaan station two weeks ago attributes at least part of the cause to the station's primitive signal system and recommends that it be upgraded or an emergency basis.
YONKERS, July 28 Nevele Thunder and Soothsayer, the nation's outstanding 3-yearold trotters, drew the No. 1 and No. 2 post positions, respectively, today for Saturday night's $200,000 Yonkers Trot.

Three-year prison terms and $5,000 fines were imposed yesterday by a New Jersey Federal judge against two former company executives after they pleaded guilty last month to filing a fraudulent Federal income tax return in 1970 for Villager Industries Inc., an apparel producer.

TOKYO, July 28 (UPI) Gough Whitlam, former Prime Minister of Australia, said today that his hotel in Tientsin had "literally split down the middle" during the Chinese earthquake yesterday and that furniture in his room had toppled over on him and his wife.

SAN LEANDRO, Calif., July 28 (UPI) A car belonging to James Schoenfeld, one of two fugitive suspects in the Chowchilla school bus hijacking, was found today at Cosur D'Alene, Idaho, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.
Robert A. Aubin, a retired Rutgers University English professor, died Tuesday at his Metuchen, N.J.,home. He was 76 years old.

Jerome Robbins's "Les Noces" is a kind of freak of art. The Stravinsky score was first staged by Bronislava Nijinska in 1923, and she revived it for the Royal Ballet in London in 1966. It is a stunning and fantastic ballet, one of those few but pungent works that Nijinska has left to posterity.

ELIZABETH One of the drabbest stretches of highway in North Jersey has been spruced up. It won't win a beauty contest, "but it's a darn sight easier on the eyes," a motorist who has been using the road for 11 years said recently during a lull in traffic.
Giorgio Chinaglia, the man New York obtained to convert Pele's passes into goals, scored three times last night, leading the Cosmos to a 4-0 triumph over the Dallas Tornado.

Edward Louis Deuss, a former journalist and retired State Department employee, did Friday at the Jefferson Memorial Hospital in Charlestown, W. Va. He was 79 years old and lived in Great Falls, Va.

The Mobil Corporation and the Standard Oil Company of California announced yesterday moderate earnings advances for the second quarter and the first half of 1976.

AUGUSTA, Me., July 28 Lloyd J. Jewett, president of the University of Maine's Augusta campus, died yesterday in the Augusta General Hospital after a heart attack. Mr. Jewett, who was stricken Sunday in his home at Manchester, was 42 years old.

In the first indictment involving abuse of the five-yearold Federal Crime Insurance Program, a Brooklyn bus driver and a public-insurance adjuster were charged by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday with fraud and bribery.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) Commerce Secretary Elliot L. Richardson said today that another Arab oil embargo, similar to the one imposed late in 1973, could force the United States into a "major military struggle."

Brooklyn College is closing its downtown campus near Borough Hall and transferring the approximately 1,500 students and faculty members to the main Flatbush campus, the college president, John W. Kneller announced yesterday.

The average American wage earner is likely to buy more than one house in his lifetime and will probably buy more than two. It is important therefore to know the tax consequences of such a transaction, so that the potential gain can be the maximum.

An opinion poll by the Roper Organization has found that members of the public, by a wide margin, would prefer having television coverage of political conventions carried by one network at a time, on a rotated basis, rather than by all three networks at the same time.

A Quarter-point reduction in the prime lending rate of commercial banks began spreading through the country yesterday, as several banks followed the cut announced Monday by the First National Bank of Chicago.

In Yves Boisset's film, "Rape of Innocence," justice, mercy, decency, fair play and a young woman are raped, but not innocence. LONDON, July 28 Victor Feather, who as general secretary of the Trade Unions Congress led Britain's labor union movement from 1969 to 1973, died in a hospital here today after a stroke. He was 68 years old.

State and Federal officials in charge of New York City's controversial free summer lunch program for needy children appeared yesterday to have stepped away from their earlier position of requiring sponsors to be completely in compliance with regulations or face a cutoff of funds next Monday.

LOUISVILLE, July 28 (AP) Buster Mottram of Britain scored a 7-5, 7-6 upset victory over Roscoe Tanner tonight in the $125,000 Louisville International tennis tournament.
PARIS, July 28 President Valery Giscard d'Estaing has made a major change in the French administrative hierarchy by naming a top diplomat, Jean Francois-Poncet, as chief presidential coordinator.

PLAINS, Ga. July 28 When Senator Walter F. Mondale arrived here late last Saturday night, he was greeted at the old depot by Jimmy Carter, who told the crowd of tourists and townspeople that "I've never had the slightest doubt that I made the right choice." That was only nine days after he had announced Mr. Mondale as his choice for running mate.

A bid for a 90 percent increase in medical malpractice insurance rates for physicians and surgeons was rejected yesterday by the New York State Insurance Superintendent, Thomas A. Harnett. However, he said he would approve a 20 percent increase effective last July 1 if requested formally.

"S-1," written by Amiri Baraka, is not just political theater but theater as politics. The new play, which opened last weekend at the Afro American Studio and is running this weekend at the Washington Square Church, is itself a political act both an indictment and an incitement.

In another low-volume day, stocks on the American Stock Exchange drifted lower yesterday, with the market value index closing at 103.73, off 0.46.

MANILA, July 28 (AP) A couple cannot get a marriage license in the Philippines until they show they have received instruction in family planning and responsible parenthood, the Government's Commission on Population has announced.

TEL AVIV The last three years have witnessed increased support for Palestinian independence among the Western nations. The slogan "No peace without Palestinian statehood" is widely accepted, and examples of Palestinian extremism are dismissed as exceptional. An examination of the role of extremism in Palestinian political behavior, however, leads one to the opposite conclusion that there will be no peace if the Palestinians succeed in establishing a state.

MONTREAL, July 28 Guy Drut of France, a hero here in French-speaking Quebec, won the 110-meter high hurdles today, and earned the gold medal that eluded him in 1972. Willie Davenport of Baton Rouge, in his fourth high hurdles final in four Olympics, gained the bronze medal for third place.

Twenty-nine city and state employees were arrested yesterday in the Bronx and 13 more are being sought by the police, all accused of illegally collecting a total of about $250,000 in welfare payments over a three-year period while employed.

The Grand National Team Championship, which began at club level eight months ago, reaches its climax in Salt Lake City during the next three days. The champions of eight zones will battle in knockout matches to determine the national winners, who will qualify for playoff matches to select the 1977 international team.
MARSEILLES, France, July 28 (Reuters) A 22-year-old man was executed by guillotine today for the kidnapping and murder of an 8-year-old girl.
WASHINGTON, July 28 The Treasury Department is considering issuing a new smaller $1 coin primarily for use in vending machines.

Mayor Beame's Management Advisory Board reported yesterday that at least $5 million could be saved "in the shortrun" by overhauling and consolidating the city's data processing operations.

ALBANY, July 28 Governor Carey today signed into law a controversial bill giving the state the power to control the release of water from 20 upstate reservoirs owned by New York City.

Goldin were not cooperating with the Securities and Exchange Commission and vowed that they would testify despite a concurrent action challenging the commission's right to investigate the New York City government.

BOSTON, July 30 One swing of Carlos May's bat undid a lot of Yankee "downs" and Red Sox "ups" tonight at misty Fenway Park. New York's designated hitter rapped a three-run homer off Luis Tiant in the eighth inning to turn an impending fourth straight Yankee defeat into a 6-4 triumph.

A wrist roll, a flash of a brother trying to get his gun in a grave between his knees. Tired, tired of this, though I comfort taxes, and my blue shirtsleeves are storied steadied? up with pinching rubber bands. Prostitution that's acceptable. Who? So driven whores in breathing through their nostrils often rumble. Manfried sleeps.

TRENTON, July 30 New Jersey's beaches were declared in "very good" condition with no evidence of dead algae, dead fish or troublesome "red tide" to interfere with bathing over the weekend.

About 100 tenants took over the management office of Cathedral Parkway Towers yesterday morning in support of a series of demands that include the rehiring of a blackowned management firm whose contract was not renewed.

ALBANY, July 30 Governor Carey announced today that he had signed into law a bill allowing motorists to make right turns on a red light at intersections outside New York City, except where a sign specifically forbids such turn on red.

Computer-controlled electronic telephone exchange technology, used in hundreds of United States cities and suburbs, is scheduled to begin moving into rural sections of the Bell System today. In the next 18 months, a total of 60 rural areas are scheduled to have Bell electronic exchanges installed.

Stanley Dancer will be trying for his seventh victory in the $200,204 Yonkers Trot tonight at Yonkers Raceway. The 49-year-old Dancer, who won the event for the first time in 1959 with Diller Hanover, will be in the sulky behind Nevele Thunder.

CAIRO, July 30 The number of Soviet military technicians and advisers in Egypt, once well into the thousands, has shrunk to roughly 100 and may reach zero by the end of the year, well-placed sources sympathetic to Egypt's President, Anwar el-Sadat, reported this week.

The integrity of this country's wetlands is under acute attack in a Connecticut lawsuit. If permission is denied, it asks $78 million, which it claims to be the potential value of the property.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Letitia Woods, Profesor of American history and civilization at George Washington University and an authority on the history of Washington's black community, died of cancer yesterday at her home here. She was 60 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 In a major step toward the longsought goal of standardizing weapons among the Atlantic allies, the American and West German Armies have agreed on a common gun and engine for their new main battle tanks.

In a visit filled with emotion, Mayor Beame and the wives of four injured police officers went to Harlem yesterday to thank residents for the help they gave the men burned and nearly blinded by buckets of lye and ammonia thrown in their faces last Saturday.

John (The Count) Montefusco of the San Francisco Giants is not quite as flamboyant as Detroit's Mark (The Bird) Fidrych who cleans the mound on his hands and knees and also talks to the ball as he prepares to pitch.

LOVELAND, Colo., Aug. 4 Sometimes, the first few days after a flood are worse than the disaster itself. Today was one of anguish for Mike Watson, of foreboding for Dencey Lloyd, relief for Robert E. Lindsay, and grief for others.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 4 A disclosure that Israeli Army liaison officers have been meeting with rebel Lebanese Moslems allied to the Palestine Liberation Organization has stirred controversy here.

John C. Savage, 44 years old, who quit Norman, Craig Kummel-New York in 1970 as an executive vice president, is returning there as president. Thomas K. Myers, also 44, moves up to chairman, having been president for three years.

The nation's top aluminum producer, the Aluminum Company of America, has raised the domestic price of unalloyed aluminum by 4 cents a pound, to 48 cents, effective with orders placed today. WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) The House gave President Ford his 10th veto setback to day by overriding his action to kill legislation on reform of coal leasing.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4 The California Supreme Court issued a stay today of a Fresno Superior Court judge's order that would have jailed indefinitely four newsmen on The Fresno Bee who have refused to disclose their sources for a 1975 article about municipal corruption.
CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., Aug. 4 "Hello, I'm Dr. Stephen Thacker with the Health Department, and I am part of the medical team investigating this weird disease."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 A bill designed to end the impasse over insurance protection for flu vaccine manufacturers has passed a health subcommittee of the House of Representatives and goes tomorrow to the full House Commerce Committee.

JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 4 The police opened fire at least twice today when students from the black suburb of Soweto attempted to break through a security cordon barring them from Johannesburg, where they planned to protest the detention of students arrested during rioting seven weeks ago.

Inmates at the Queens House of Detention have made $47,292 in unauthorized calls throughout the United States and to Puerto Rico and Canada over a recent nine-month period, according to an audit by New York City's Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin.

Three suspects an 18-yearold woman the police described as a part-time discotheque dancer and two unemployed half brothers were arrested yesterday on charges of murdering two men whose bodies were found July 27 in Central Park.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 4 The crowded commuter train that crashed here last month was traveling at up to more than twice the posted speed limit at the time of impact, technical experts testified here today at public investigative hearings into the accident.

ST. DAVIDS, Pa., Aug. 4 The Pennsylvania Crime Commission said today that organized-crime figures were moving from New Jersey to Pennsylvania for illegal gambling operations because investigative procedures were tougher in New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) Despite what he called some shortcomings, President Ford signed today a bill that he said was a step toward assuring adequate housing for all Americans.
Shares on the American Stock Exchange moved up yesterday for a second session, and the market value index closed at 103.87, up 0.15.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 Dwight Stones got his dry runway at Franklin Field tonight, and he flew to a world record of 7 feet 7 inches in the high jump during the Bicentennial Meet of Champions.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 4 A military investigation of academic "subversion" has led to the arrest of 17 professors and a major purge at the national university at Bahfa Blanca.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 4 The state oil companies of Indonesia and Malaysia, backed by their governments' threats of nationalization, have begun to apply heavy pressure on international oil companies.

VALHALLA, N.Y., Aug. 4 A critically burned plane-crash victim, a doctor and a nurse were flown from Westchester County Airport to a Rochester hospital today in a donated airplane acquired through the efforts of hospital personnel, county residents and an aircraft company.

The annual midsummer exhibition game between the Giants and the Jets will be played on Monday night at Yankee Stadium, but there does not seem to be the interest in the event as in the past. The Jets, the host team, reported yesterday there were still about 14,000 seats unsold for the game, all at $9 each.

The annual Family of Man Human Relations Award of the Council of Churches of New York City will be presented to Justice Thurgood Marshall of the United States Supreme Court, it was announced yesterday.

BIEL, Switzerland, Aug. 4 (AP) Mikhael Tal of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, defeated the Colombian international master Oscar Rojas Castro on Wednesday, taking the lead in the Biel interzonal chess tournament from Bent Larsen, the Danish grandmaster.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) The House, on a vote of 193 to 192, reversed today an earlier vote and passed a bill providing Government aid so private industry could start producing enriched uranium as an additional energy source.
OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 4 The disqualification of the 6-5 Copano in the $23,000 first division enlivened the Eatontown Handicap on the grass at Monmouth Park to- day.
The Coca-Cola Company reported yesterday profit gains of 15.6 percent for the second quarter and 18.5 percent for the first half.
MOSCOW, Aug. 4 (Reuters) A Kremlin commentator today rejected Western suggestions that Moscow was stepping up the pace of its strategic missile development.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 In a major step toward the longsought goal of standardizing weapons among the Atlantic allies, the American and West German Armies have agreed on a common gun and engine for their new main battle tanks.

NEWARK, Aug. 4 (UPI) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has held the first in a series of hearings to get suggestions from disabled persons who will be affected by a Federal law barring discrimination against the handicapped.

CAIRO, Aug. 4 Eighty-one people were executed at dawn today in the Sudan after being convicted of charges that they had participated in an unsuccessful attempt to overthrow President Gaafar alNimeiry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) The Federal Government should give more leverage to communities threatened with abandonment by owners of professional sports teams, a Buffalo city attorney told a House committee today.

NEWARK, Aug. 4 (UPI) A Jersey City bank sued the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation today, charging the F.D.I.C. was negligent because it did not discover that its former bank president misapplied more than $1.75 million in bank money.

LONDON, Aug. 4 Lord Thomson of Fleet, a Canadian who built a vast and influential publishing empire crowned by The Times of London and The Sunday Times, died this morning at Wellington Hospital. He was 82 years old.

DETROIT, Aug. 4 Donald W. Riegle Jr., a Democratic Representative from Flint, will face Marvin L. Esch, a Republican Congressman from Ann Arbor, in Michigan's November senatorial election for the seat vacated by Senator Philip A. Hart, who is retiring.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) The State Department said today that the Soviet Union and its East European allies had taken "some concrete steps" to implement the Helsinki accord but that there was little change in policies on hu man rights.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 4 A 20-year-old Oceanside, L.I., High School graduate who obtained a job as a printer for the school district because he had done so well in his printing classes will be arraigned in Federal Court in Brooklyn tomorrow on a charge of manufacturing counterfeit money, a Secret Service official said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 The Government has failed to head off discrimination and misuse of revenue-sharing funds because it has relied on the states and localities to police themselves, the General Accounting Office said today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Aug. 4 Thirtyseven men, ranging in age from the middle 20's to late 60's peered at scores of trees and shrubs, scrutinized weeds and insects and submitted to a three-hour written examination today in an effort to become "certified tree experst" in New Jersey.

BOONTON, Aug. 5--A lot of people were ready to let the 1904 Erie Lackawanna Railway station here be torn down and turned into a parking lot. Joseph Marcello was not. Through his efforts, it has been turned into an unusual shopping mall instead.

The half-mile near the East River from Turtle Bay to Sutton Place--from the upper 40's to the Queensboro Bridge at 59th Street--still looks as much of Manhattan's Upper East Side once did. It is a stretch still characterized by a pleasant mix of brownstones, small shops and medium-size apartment buildings--another kind of city from that of the arrogant white-brick apartment houses that tower over First, Second and Third Avenues in the 60's, 70's and 80's.

ALBANY, Aug. 5--After a long night and day of partisan squabbling the State Legislature passed a bill tonight that requires the state to assume all costs of county and city courts on a graduated basis over the next four years. Governor Carey signed the bill into law almost immediately.

Henry Kaufman, general partner of Salomon Brothers, declared yesterday that the current economic recovery in the United States had a long way to go before it began to wane. "The recovery," he told a meeting of the School for Bank Administration at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, Wis., "will not terminate in 1978 as some have concluded."

JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 5-- Policemen fired over the heads of demonstrators in Soweto today, halting a new attempt by students to march out of the township for a protest in front of police headquarters in Johannesburg.

ENDICOTT, N.Y., Aug. 5 (AP)--Buddy Allin, who won $40,000 and his first golf tournament in two years at Sutton, Mass., last Sunday, shot a course-record, eightunder-par 63 today and took the first-round lead in the B.C. open.

Prices of sugar futures declined sharply on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday, following a report about better-than-expected yields for French sugar beets. The October delivery closed at 11.84 cents a pound, down from 12.30 cents.

VIENNA, Aug. 5 (AP)--The finance ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries met today to discuss aid to developing countries against a background of controversy with Western industrialized nations over how much aid should be given.

When the New York Philharmonic comes to the end of its concert in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx tomorrow night, there will be a fireworks display. This has become traditional with the first program in the orchestra's annual summer parks concerts, which opened this week. Normally, the fireworks coincide with the final pages of Tchaikovsky's "1812" Overture, but this year they are being set off to the last strains of Rossini's "William Tell" Overture.

BONN, Aug. 5 (Reuters)-- East German border guards today shot and killed an Italian truck driver near the West German border, the East German press agency A.D.N. said in a report monitored here.

The nation's basic money supply declined sharply in the latest statement week and business loans at leading New York City banks moved up in one of their rare increases so far this year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5--The Federal government's chief epidemiologist told a Senate hearing today that the number of new cases of the mysterious flu-like disease that has killed 23 persons in Pennsylvania was "diminishing rapidly" and that the ailment did not seem to be contagious.
Walter L. Schlager Jr., former president and general manager of the Long Island Rail Road, died Wednesday of cancer at his home in Plandome, L.I. He was 58 years old.

A bagel is not a bialy, just in case some of you thought that. Bagels are round, have holes, are slightly shiny and are not easily digestible except with lox. Bialys are also round, baked, a bit chewy, dusty with flour, pushed down--but not through--the center, seasoned with onions or garlic, and are even less digestible when eaten with cream cheese. But so what. So many good things are.

Disappointed at not having been able to get a power frontcourt man, the Knicks picked up Randy Denton, a 6-foot 10-inch center, in yesterday's dispersal draft of American Basketball Association players.

M. Donald Grant of the Mets and August A. Busch Jr. of the St. Louis Cardinals, disturbed by recent baseball developments, have arranged a private meeting of National League club owners in Phoenix, Ariz., next Wednesday. Its purpose will be to scrutinize the work of certain officials and to discuss, in the words of one owner, "what we've been doing wrong."

PARTICIPANTS: About 18,000 nonprofessional hospital workers, members of Local 420, American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, are on strike against New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs the 16 municipal hospitals. Most of the employees are nurses' aides and dietary and janitorial workers.
Investigators who are unraveling a network of ownerships of day-care centers in New York City have found a growing list of names that appeared in similar studies of the nursing-home industry.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 5-- A citizens task force that feels it is unfair that some Long Island residents have to travel up to 100 miles to get to the Federal District Court of jurisdiction, renewed a drive today to establish separate Federal court facilities on the Island.
DOVER, Aug. 5--The intrasion of petrochemical pollutants into wells that provide drinking water here may be spreading, Mayor Robert W. Brune said today.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Aug. 5 (UPI)--South and North Korean soldiers exchanged gunfire today along the eastern sector of their 151-mile truce front No casualties were reported.
The Giants conceded yesterday that Carl Summerell, their young quarterback who performed well in his first start last Sunday, had left the club without permission.

When it comes to being the most discussed TV feature, "Mary Hartman. Mary Hartman" may be in for some competition in the fall if Sensational Sidney and Fabulous Frances take to the TV airwaves as planned.

In a contest where even a single delegate is important, Ronald Reagan picked up six delegates in New York and New Jersey yesterday in his first foray into the Northeast with his liberal Republican running mate, Senator Richard S. Schweiker.

The Federal Departmen of Labor announced yesterday that it intended to begin proceedings to bar Uniroyal, one of the biggest tire and rubber concerns, from holding existing or future Federal contracts on the ground that the company had failed to provide equal employment opportunities for female and minority works. The action was brought under an Executive order that banned employment discrimination by Federal contractors.

The General Dynamics Corporation, the diversified aerospace producer, reported yesterday a record second-quarter profit with an increase of 12.4 percent. Half-year earnings also reached a new high-reflecting the increased business in its varied fields, such as shipbuilding, space, electronics and natural resources.
A car thief took four young companions on a wild joy ride through the reaches of Brooklyn's Marine Park yesterday afternoon, but discovered that a 967 Plymouth cannot outmaneuver a police helicopter.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) --The names of 200 suspected narcotics dealers have been turned over to the Internal Revenue Service for special audits under a major new Federal drive against illegal drug traffickers, Commissioner Donald C. Alexander said today.

She couldn't go shopping, she couldn't plant a garden, she couldn't play Bingo with her women friends.

TO CHOOSE an unpredictable partner is one of the antidotes to the bore dom that so often seems to set in between the sexes. This is not as unpopular a choice as one would imagine: many of us prefer anxiety to boredom. It is a more contemporary feeling.

ANDY WARHOL, the pop artist, film maker, author and man-about-Manhat- tan, is now going into publishing. An agreement was concluded between Mr. Warhol and Grosset Dunlap whereby they will jointly publish books under the imprint Andy Warhol Books/ Grosset Dunlap. Mr. Warhol will have a hand in writing and designing some of the books, which Grosset Dunlap will then produce and distribute.

ALBANY, Aug. 5--As a practical matter, New York State has two vastly different court systems, each with its own administrative practices, employee salary structures, priorities and work loads.

Mr. Howe, who is appealing a conviction on a misdemeanor charge of soliciting sex for pay from two police decoy prostitutes, said he would reject the request.

PARIS, Aug. 5--The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today that financial conditions were favorable for a new business investment "boom" in the United States, which should help power continuation of significant output and employment growth over the next 12 months.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia --Malaysia is pressing a variety of price stabilization schemes for commodities that are its principal sources of national income and the foundation of the nation's future development.

NASHVILLE, Aug. 5--James R. Sasser, a former Tennessee Democratic chairman, won his party's nomination for the United States Senate today and a chance to run against Senator Bill Brock, the Republican incumbent, in November.

GREENVALE, L.I., Aug. 5 (AP)--At least eight professors at Long Island University's C.W. Post Center have been told they are under a university investigation of participating in a scheme that allegedly gave faculty members credit for courses they never took, sources close to the investigation have told The Associated Press.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 5 --Jay Blumenfeld, often a runner-up in recent area golf tournaments, said today, "Plainfield's the roughest course in New Jersey. In fact, it's got to be one of the best courses in the world."

The portrait of Doug Henning, the magician, that hangs in his dressing room at the Cort Theater was done by a 10-year-old who had seen Mr. Henning in "The Magic Show." It is not the kind of portrait many performers would find flattering. Mr. Henning's mouth is open, his eyes are wide. He looks dumbfounded. He looks amazed.

When the triumphs and abrasions of the Montreal Olympics are forgotten, the picture that will stay longest in memory is that of a muscular character who has just eaten up a storm pausing on his way out of the mess hall in Olympic Village to stuff a shoulder bag with apples, pears, bananas, oranges, grapes, plums, apricots, figs and peaches. As many as 14 athletes might be stacked.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 5--Brake tests along the grease-covered stretch of track here where a crowded commuter train crashed on July 13 produced 34 skids in 10 tries, the fact-finding hearing here was told today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5--The White House said today that President Ford would announce his choice of a running mate in the traditional way, waiting until he had been nominated for President at the Republican National Convention.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 5--It rained today at County Stadium. On and off, like the tap on a beer keg at the local pub. The lights were turned on early, though they hardly penetrated the gloom hovering beneath the low-hanging clouds and fog.
The Inmont Corporation said yesterday that its subsidiaries in unidentified foreign countries had made questionable payments totaling approximately $7 million from Jan. 1, 1971 to date.

Commissioners, agency executives and other city officials were told yesterday they have to get along without that extra telephone at their conference table or that shiny telephone console at their secretary's desk.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 5-- The Reagan-Schweiker team made little apparent headway yesterday in its visit here to try to reassure conservative delegates to the Republican National Convention.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Pa., Aug. 5--In Fairview Cemetery today, an elderly caretaker tamped the dark earth of a new grave.

COLLINSVILLE, Ill.--In an area cluttered by gasoline stations, discount stores and fast food restaurants, the dominant feature on the landscape here is an ancient man-made mound of earth that rises over 100 feet from its massive base of 14 acres.
A New York City criminal lawyer was arrested yesterday outside a Manhattan Criminal Court on charges of shaking down an indigent defendant for $1,000.
TRENTON, Aug. 5--A grand jury handed up three indictments today in connection with its investigation of public corruption in Passaic County.

TRENTON, Aug. 5 The people who investigate local violations of the state's Consumer Fraud Act may still speak softly, but from now on they will carry a big stick--the power to subpoena and impose fines on unscrupulous merchants.
LONDON, Aug. 4--The telephone: it is an instrument of priceless variety.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5--A class action suit was filed in Superior Court here today Charging the Baker/Beech-Nut Corporation, Canajoharie, N. Y., a manufacturer of commercial baby foods, with "false advertising."

A car thief took four young companions on a wild joy ride through the reaches of Brooklyn's Marine Park yesterday afternoon, but discovered that a 1967 Plymouth cannot outmaneuver a police helicopter.

ATLANTA, Aug. 5--As they have every day since Sunday, couriers arrived in Atlanta today carrying ice-packed samples of human tissues, clues to the mysterious outbreak of illness in Pennsylvania that has killed 23 persons so far.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5--John Roselli, the organized crime figure who last year acknowledged his role in the Central Intelligence Agency's plots against the life of Prime Minister Fidel Castro of Cuba, has disappeared from his home in the Miami area.

LISBON, Aug. 5--Alvaro Cunhal, the Portuguese Communist leader, said in Parliament today that the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Mario Soares and its program "do not correspond to the needs of the present situation."
TOKYO, Aug. 5--In the latest legal decision in Japan's longest-running controversy, a High Court panel of judges ruled today that this country's maintenance of military forces is legal.
The taxi driver had had enough of Billie Jean King's backseat driving. "Look, I don't teach you how to play tennis," he yelled at his passenger, "so don't teach me how to drive a cab!"
Donald M. Klock,former president of the Duffy-Mott Company, was indicted yesterday on charges of fraudulently obtaining $400,000 from the company and failing to report it on his income tax returns.

A major overhaul of the apparatus for determining national policy in science and technology at the highest level is to take place after the expected Senate confirmation today of Dr. H. Guyford Stever as director of the new Office of Sciience and Technology Policy.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 5 (UPI)-- The dollar scored a big gain in Paris today and closed higher on most other European money markets except in Milan. In Frankfurt, it dipped to a threemonth low and then rallied higher at the close.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., (AP) Aug. 5--Jimmy Connors, shrewdly mixing his shots, advanced to the quarterfinals of the $100,000 Volvo tennis tournament today with a 7-6, 6-0 victory over Argentina's Ricardo Cano.
LONDON, Aug. 5 (Reuters) --The clock in the tower above Parliament rattled, banged and stopped early today.

Breck Parkman McAllister, a member of the Wall Street firm of Donovan Leisure Newton Irvine from 1943 to 1974, died Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 1088 Park Avenue.

DETROIT, Aug. 5--The Chrysler Corporation's board of directors today declared a quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share and company officials said the action showed that the company expected to continue its comeback from record 1975 losses.

Phyllis Recchia, who works on the marketing staff of the General Motors Corporation in New York, was given $3,000 by her company not too long ago. The reason was that she had come up with an idea for eliminating the reproduction of certain reports that G.M. figured would save it about $9,000 a year.

The contending forces--librarians, educators, public broadcasters and publishers and authors--are finally compromising their differences and the first major revision of the 1909 copyright law seems possible this year. The Senate has already approved its version; now the House Judiciary Committee ought to pass the measure before the Republican convention begins. Otherwise, the archaic law could become ensnared in party politics.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 5-- Influenza virus "is probably not" the cause of an outbreak of a mysterious flu-like illness that has now claimed its 23d victim among Pennsylvania American Legion conventioneers, Gov. Milton J. Shapp said here today.

New transportation rates that would affect nearly 400,000 public and private school students and save New York City more than $18 million are being considered by the Board of Education, officials confirmed last night.

CAIRO, Aug. 5--Seventeen persons accused of having taken part in the July coup attempt against President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan were executed by firing squad at dawn today, the Sudanese Government announced. Yesterday, 81 were executed and 210 persons are still on trial.

It is quiet, so quiet that each bird peep and insect chirp resounds in the silence. It is as remote as so many New Yorkers believe Staten Island to be. It is on a steep hill, where if you could see through the leafy trees, you would look south for a vista of Lower New York Harbor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5--The Senate approved tonight some changes in the estate tax laws that would reduce the tax owed by almost all estates and provide some special tax relief to those who inherit farm property.

MOSCOW, Aug. 5 (Reuters) --Mikhail K. Lukonin, a poet, has died less than three months after he was elected first secretary of the Moscow branch of the Union of Writers, the Tass press agency reported today.

The Bowery scene has spread. In the late hours vagrants now can be found singly and in twos and threes in the triangles on Broadway from Herald Square to 72d Street, along the southern edge of Central Park, in the side streets off Times Square, around the fountained plazas of the Avenue of the Americas, along Lexington Avenue above 42d Street, in the small parks of the Lower East Side and in Trinity Place.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5--The Justice Department's internal inspection team is investigating a reported financial relationship between John P. Mohr, a former top official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and a Virginia real estate developer accused of defrauding the Small Business Administration, according to department sources.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 5--Jon Matlack survived both the shock of Willie Stargell's grand-slam home run and the shock of seeing the Mets get 17 hits in one game, to record his first victory in a month, 7-4, against the Pirates at Three Rivers Stadium tonight.

ALBANY, Aug. 5--Last night, in the closed-door Democratic caucus, Manfred Ohrenstein, the State Senate's minority leader, asked 20 or so of his colleagues if they favored the court reorganization package hammered out earlier in the day by Governor Carey and legislative leaders.

Defense lawyers in the case of the 1972 Harlem mosque shooting said yesterday that the presiding judge's order prohibiting them from discussing the case with the press was unconstitutional and they asked him to vacate it.

PASSAIC, Aug. 5--Karol Cardinal Wojtyla of Poland placed a red and white wreath on the door of a room in St. Mary's Hospital this morning. In that room, a Polish archbishop who had fought a ban on Roman Catholicsm in the Soviet Union, died 50 years ago while visiting the United States.

TRENTON, Aug. 5--New Jersey's personal income tax law, approved by the Legislature last month and signed by the Governor, remained inoperative today after the Assembly failed to approve a plan for rebate of property taxes to tenants that would have activated the income tax.

The Bowery scene has spread. In the late hours vagrants now can be found singly and in twos and threes in the triangles on Broadway from Herald Square to 72d Street, along the southern edge of Central Park, in the side streets off Times Square, around the fountained plazas of the Avenue of the Americas, along Lexington Avenue above 42d Street, in the small parks of the Lower East Side and in Trinity Place.

ALEXANDER CALDER is a lot of people's favorite American; and every one of those people will want to be around in October, when Calder will be in town for the opening of his retrospective exhibition at the Whitney Museum. Even to shake Calder by the hand is to think better of the world.

Any executive who is contemplating, or has been through, a corporate identity program should enjoy a Corporate Identity Manual created by Fulton Partners for the nonexistent David's Lemonade stand. Although it seems to be a delightful spoof, it is actually intended as an educational tool in the use of logotypes and marks.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 5 --The Spingold knockout team championship continued here this afternoon at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals with 32 teams surviving from an original entry of 118. Five of these consist substantially of New York experts, and all of them have good prospects of advancing.

Sonny Terry and Brownie McGhee, who are performing at the Other End this weekend, practically invented the folk blues circuit in the 1950's. They are the hardiest perennials still playing in the city's folk clubs, and they have become so familiar that they are often taken for granted.
PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 5-- About 14 percent of the atoms in the red Martian soil being studied by the Viking I lander's inorganic chemistry instrument are iron, a scientist announced here today.

PARIS, Aug. 5--The world is moving into a new phase of oilprice politics. Once again, as during the final months of 1973 when prices quadrupled, market power is shifting dramatically to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

Volume dwindled and so did the market value index on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, after two sessions of higher prices. The volume was 1.5 million shares, compared with 1.8 million the previous day, and the market value index ended at 103.59, off 0.28.

One of the most powerful trustees of the largest pension fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters is resigning after taking the Fifth Amendment before Labor Department investigators, wellplaced sources said yesterday.

Until recently, weekend sightseers have been able to explore New York City by land, sea and air--by bus, boat and helicopter. But only recently, when the Transit Authority began its "Nostalgia Special," has there been a subterranean excursion into a subway museum, through the depths of three boroughs and over the waters of Jamaica Bay.

Abe Hirschfeld, the businessman who is one of five contenders for the Democratic Senate nomination, said yesterday that housing construction in New York City was hampered by government "bureaucracy" and urged public officials to "let the builders go ahead and build."
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 5--An American Roman Catholic priest has been arrested in Cordoba Province, in central Argentina, apparently for political reasons, according to the United States Embassy here.

Franklin Simon, the 65-store women's apparel specialty chain based in New York, is being offered for sale by its parent company, the City Stores Company, which has suffered continuing losses since 1972, authoritative trade sources indicated yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 5-- Hopes for an immediate ceasefire in Lebanon, which had sprung up overnight, were dashed today when Interior Minister Camille Chamoun, one of the main right wing Christian leaders, accused Iraq of having sent troops into Beirut to fight on the side of the Palestinians.
Doug DeCinces(pronounced De-Sinsay) lists among his hobbies golf, photography, refinishing antiques and breeding German shepherds.
The New York and American Stock Exchanges took further steps toward dual listing of stocks.

James Parker has been a janitor at the Bronx Municipal Hospital for 21 years and is not really worried that he will be laid off. Audrey Thompson, on the other hand, has been a nurse's aide there for only a little more than two years--and received word of her layoff last week.

The stock market dropped in much slower trading yesterday after two consecutive sessions of advances. At the close, the widely-watched Dow Jones industrial average was off 5.60 points at 986.68, its low for the day.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 5 (UPI)--A long-range Soviet military plane apparently has crashed off the coast of New foundland, Canada's maritime command announced today.

Sex and sensationalism-- with strong touches of bigotry--were major ingredients of New York City newspapers of the early and middle 19th century, as shown in a newly opened exhibition of old newspapers at the Queens College library.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 5 (UPI)--A gang of heavily armed desert bandits stormed a tourist hotel near the Kenyan-Ethiopian border, killing five persons and taking a Frenchman hostage, Kenyan officials said today.
Better than any other document I know, Clancy Sigal's "Going Away" (1962) identified, embodied and re-created the postwar American radical experience.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (Reuters)--The United States has initialed agreements with Israel and Egypt to provide each with two nuclear reactors, the State Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) --Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, President Ford's choice as Army Chief of Staff, promised Congress today that he would take "appropriate action" against any Army officers harassing the defense of West Point military cadets accused of violating the cadet honor code.

THE Nikolais Dance Theater is having a very happy season at the Beacon Theater. WASHINGTON, Aug. 5-- Government nuclear facilities are unable to account for well over two tons of plutonium and uranium that could be fashioned into scores of atomic bombs, according to several Federal officials who have read a classified report by the General Accounting Office.

ALTHOUGH Rudi van Dantzig's ballat "Monument for a Dead Boy" has been seen many times in New York with various American companies, it was given for the first time locally Wednesday night by the National ballet of Canada at the Metropolitan Opera House.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) --The Federal Election Commission certified today $566,561,87 in matching funds for five Presidential candidates who competed in the final round of spring primaries.

Despite a popular conception of New York City and environs as little more than a wasteland of cement and suburbia, the metropolitan area has a surprisingly lush and varied sprinkling of public gardens that offer relief from both city streets and summer heat.

One world record a week may not satisfy Dwight Stones now.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 5-- The Ford Administration has undertaken an intelligence review to determine whether the Soviet Union violated the spirit of the new treaty on underground nuclear tests by detonating two devices last month that may each have exceeded the 150-kiloton limit.
The Medical Society of the State of New York asked a Federal judge yesterday to declare unconstitutional provisions of a new state law that limit elective surgery for Medicaid patients.

RAVI SHANKAR will begin playing a raga very early tomorrow morning inside the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in a dusk-to-dawn program of Indian music. As he brushes the strings of his sitar, producing the shimmering resonance so characteristic of his music, he will be celebrating an auspicious occasion, the 20th anniversary of his performances of Indian music in the United States.

Dr. Allan Murray Cartter, a former chancellor of New York University and one of the nation's authorities on academic manpower, died Wednesday of cancer at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 54 years old.

August is a month in which many New Yorkers "go to the country" for their yearly ration of fresh air, exercise and privacy. But the country is also coming to New York this weekend, including several versions of country music not always available here.

YONKERS, Aug. 5--About 50 parents blocked the entrance to their neighborhood elementary school this morning and prevented workmen from removing desks and equipment from the building, which has been scheduled for closing.

With luck, the Turkish, research ship Sismik I will complete its seismic studies in the Aegean Sea without provoking a military confrontation between Greece and Turkey. An informal understanding has evidently been reached by the two governments, under pressure from their NATO allies, that will allow the vessel to carry out modest explorations even in disputed waters without precipitating the clash both sides have been threatening ever since the Sismik's voyage was projected.

Inflation has not left the flower garden unscathed. Delphiniums, those regal midsummer favorites, often sell for $2 a plant these days. The same is true for Astilbe, sedums and even rudbeckia, the common black-eyed Susan of our summer meadows. Yet, if grown from seed, these same plants can be had for pennies each.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Aug. 6 Steve Riddick, Charles Foster, and Dave Roberts won individual gold medals today one week too late.
A New York State Supreme Court justice who this week limited press coverage of a murder trial has puzzled his colleagues on the bench and lawyers who regularly practice in criminal courts.

ABC and NBC have said they will televise a series of four debates between the Democratic and Republican candidates for President and Vice President, which the League of Women Voters will arrange this fall if the candidates agree to participate.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 Norman Ray Lewis, a striking member of the International Longshoremen and Warehousemen's Union, was struck and killed by a truck and trailer while picketing this morning at the Handyman of California warehouse in Tracy, 70 miles from here, according to the Tracy police.

PARIS Madrid's Government has indicated to Santiago Carrillo, secretary general of the Spanish Communist Party, that it will very shortly decide whether he will be allowed to return openly and legally to Spain. He applied here this week for a Spanish passport. He was most courteously received by the Ambassador, although he and his party are still banned as illegal, but it was intimated a decision will probably be taken at a cabinet meeting Tuesday.

JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 6 Police riot squads opened fire in Soweto today to disperse crowds of youths who roamed the black township attacking cars, buses and trains in a continuing effort to keep black workers from their jobs in Johannesburg.

A group of 40 gypsies, some crying, some praying and some talking emotionally, stood outside the emergency room at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center early yesterday while surgeons performed an emergency operation on a 5-yearold boy who had suffered a skull fracture in an auto accident.

Alvan C. Hadley, who used the name Hap in his career as a newspaper cartoonist and theatrical artist, died in New York City on Tuesday. He was 81 years old.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 6 The International Committee of the Red Cross broke off its evacuation of the wounded from the Tell Zaatar Palestinian camp today after some of the wounded had been shot from rightist Christian positions.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) A World War II B-25 bomber, converted for civilian use, caught fire today after takeoff and crashed into three houses, killing two persons and injuring three others, the authorities said.

Some black sponsors of the Summer Food Service for Needye Children charged yesterday that they were being unfairly penalized because of abuses by others. They asked a voice in next year's policy decisions regarding the program.

TRENTON, Aug. 6 Attendance at New Jersey's 23 state parks is running 10 percent behind last year, and state officials are wondering whether the weather or higher admission fees are to blame.

Shirley Schlanger Abrahamson, who was graduated from Hunter High School and in 1953 from New York University, was named yesterday as the first woman Justice of the Wisconsin Supreme Court. The appointment was announced by Gov. Patrick J.Lucey.

A missing witness in the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter triplemurder case voluntarily appeared at the Passaic County, N.J., Prosecutor's office in Paterson yesterday, and a warrant for his arrest was quickly dropped.

The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development approved a $102.2 million grant to New York City yesterday under the 1974 Community Development Act.

A Federal judge has ruled that Nehring Brothers, a major real-estate management company in New York City, raised apartment rents in violation of Federal regulations and must give refunds with interest to the overcharged tenants or pay a penalty of three times the amount to the Government.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 6 David S.Fine, 24 years old, a confessed participant in a University of Wisconsin classroom bombing in 1970 in Madison was sentenced to seven years' imprisonment today by United States District Court Judge Myron L.Gordon.

HIS DAY Every dog has it and tomorrow will mark "Canine Cleanup Carnival," a free outdoor action seminar in Central Park at which pets and owners will undergo a four-hour how-to program that should prove both instructive and invigorating.
FORT LEE, Va., Aug. 6 (AP) An Army man who had admitted he fired the shots that killed a fellow soldier here May 6 was found guilty of felony murder by his military judge today.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y. In a wooden bin on the Olympic Arena lawn, large chunks of snow were melting in the warm sun.

Mary Josephine Shelly, a former Bennington College administrator who took charge of the Navy's education for women in World War II and commanded the Women in the Air Force in the Korean War, died yesterday at New York Hospital. She was 74 years old and resided at 10 Mitchell Place.

CAMDEN, Aug. 6 (UPI) A New Jersey Superior Court judge told a physician today that he could not give his patients injections until he changed his procedures to guard against infecting people with serum hepatitis.

The Nikolais Dance Theater continues on its genuinely merry way at the Beacon Theater through Aug.15. For some reason the performances have a new vigor. The old works seem refreshed and the new ones have a sense of originality, rather than recycled past ideas.

TRENTON, Aug. 6 New York State, which expected a $22 million windfall from enactment of New Jersey's personal-income tax because of a provision repealing commuter taxes on New York State residents who work in New Jersey, will not get the extra money after all.

LONDON, Aug. 6 (AP) The West German mark edged upward against the dollar today on European currency exchanges, while the Belgian and French francs weakened.

CHILLICOTHE, Mo., Aug. 6 (AP) Representative Jerry Litton, killed in a plane crash the night he won the Democratic senatorial nomination, was buried today after services attended by Congressional leaders, state officials and hundreds of friends.

Ronald McDonald, the red-wigged clown who represents a certain hamburger chain, visited the West Side Branch of the Y.M.C.A. yesterday and taught 60 youngsters the art of clowning around.

VIENNA, Aug. 6 (AP) Finance ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries pledged today "to take the necessary measures soon" to provide $800 million in assistance to developing countries.

NEW BRUNSWICK, AUG. 6 As 300 chamber music devotees of all ages concluded a week of study and performance at Douglass College here today it was hard to believe this was not the most popular of all music.

BONN, Aug. 8 A series of shootings by East German border guards and a chill in West German-Soviet relations have suddenly thrust the "Eastern policies" of Chancellor Helmut 'Schmidt and his predecessor Willy Brandt into the center of the election campaign here.

Three years ago, just about the time that Firemaster was inadvertently substituted for Nutrimaster in dairy feed, they bought their own 860-acre, farm here with 250 head of good Holstein milking and breeding stock.
LISBON, Aug. 11 The Socialist Governments program for political and economic recovery was approved tonight by the National Assembly.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11 (UPI) The California Court of Appeal has reinstated an explosives charge against Wendy Yoshimura, 33 years old, companion-in-hiding of Patricia Hearst, which had been dismissed as too vague.

The partner of a policeman fatally shot at a Harlem mosque in 1972 took the stand at the murder ,trial of Lewis 17X Dupree yesterday and testified that he saw Mr. Dupree beat the officer with his fists.

Joe Williams is singing in happy circumstances at Hopper's, Avenue of the Americas at 11th Street, where he is being reunited this week and next with his former piano accompanist, the impeccable Ellis Larkins, with the additional backing of Bob Cranshaw on bass and David Lee on drums.

Drivers with speeding convictions or other moving violations on their records will be charged double or triple the regular fee to renew their licenses, beginning next month, the State Department of Motor Vehicles announced yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 11 Right-wing Christian forces kept up military pressure today against the Palestinian camp of Tell Zaatar, on the outskirts of Beirut. A right-wing radio station reported that the Christian forces had advanced into the camp "to help civilians who wanted to leave to reach safety." It said the camp was totally besieged.
JUNIEH, Lebanon, Aug. 8 The Christians and Moslems of Lebanon have begun in effect to partition the country by setting up state administrations in their respective territories.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 11 The four-week wildcat strike of most of the nation's 150,000 union coal miners appeared to be running down today. As leaders of the United Mine Workers union finally began to regain control, there was widespread rank-and-file commitments to return to work no later than this weekend.
It would appear that what was poison to Fidel Castro has become prime filet for Washington Heights.
Lou Strong, a former president of the Professional Golfers' Association, died of cancer yesterday at West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 64 years old.
ROME, Aug. 11 Prime Minister Giullo Andreotti today obtained a vote of confidence for his new Government in the Chamber of Deputies, thus overcoming the final obstacle to its being able to function.

The Suffolk County Executive, John V.N. Klein, yesterday formally asked for Federal designation of the county as a disaster area because of estimated agricultural damage of more than $10 million resulting from Hurricane Belle.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 Chinese officials say they are ready "at any time to talk with representatives of Taipei, and to trade with Taiwan," according to a report by the Senate minority leader, Hugh Scott, based on his recent conversations with leaders in China.

Officials of the United States Open tennis tournament, meeting yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, remained undecided on the eligibility of Dr. Renee Richards to compete in the women's division of the event, which begins Sept. 1.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 President Ford's campaign strategists are debating whether the President ought to debate Jimmy Carter.
MONTCLAIR, Aug. 11 A Montclair actor was charged today with the murder of a former girlfriend in his apartment on Sunday.

MADRID, Aug 11 (Reuters) Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez of Spain has conferred with the head of the nation's main Socialist group in the first such meeting since the 1936-39 civil war, Socialist sources said today.
Hurricane Belle, like most other high winds, left in its wake not only a cat's cradle of twisted utility lines but also a snarl of tax and insurance questions as well.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 11 Pro-Palestinian guerrillas exploded grenades and fired submachine guns through a line of passengers waiting to board a Tel Aviv-bound Israeli jetliner tonight but were thwarted by the police in an apparent attempt to attack the aircraft.
THE HAGUE, Aug. 11 (UPI) Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger called today for new talks to end Lebanon's civil war, with United States participation if necessary.

Rumors about the possible resignation of Roderick M. Hills as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission have arisen in the aftermath of the nomination by President Ford last month of Patrick Delaney, a man Mr. Hills opposed, to fill a commission vacancy.

The Shell Oil Company raised its wholesale gasoline prices yesterday by 1 cent a gallon in all areas east of the Rocky Mountains. The company also increased its prices nationwide on aviation gasoline by one cent a gallon and on its jet fuel by 0.6 cent a gallon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) The Congressional Budget Office director, Alice M. Rivlin, said today that unemployment would not fall below 6 percent within the next 18 months, despite potential fiscal policy changes.

Joseph Mulholland, a college dean making his first try for political office, will be on the ballot in the Democratic primary in the 25th Assembly District as a result of a ruling yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice in Queens.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 A team of analysts at the Agriculture Department said today they were leaving their projection on total grain production in the Soviet Union unchanged at 195 million tons despite improved crop conditions in the Soviet new-lands areas.

Crude oil imports into the United States dipped to 4.85 million barrels a day in the latest week from the record level of 6.29 million barrels a day in the preceeding week, statistics issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute showed.
It would appear that what was poison to Fidel Castro has become prime filet for Washington Heights.

The yield on new Bell System bonds dropped to 8.25 percent yesterday the lowest for such bonds in 2 years as the Illinois Bell Telephone Company sold a $175 million issue of 40-year securities to an underwriting syndicate headed by First Boston Corporation.

As much as $18 million in overpayments for Medicaid patients may have gone to private nonprofit clinics here last year, according to a preliminary audit released yesterday by the New York City Health Department.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 11 Health officials investigating the mysterious outbreak that has killed 27 people in Pennsylvania began a series of tests to learn if a 50-year-old man who died suddenly on the street here toddy was the 28th victim.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) Republicans will nominate Representative John J. Rhodes of Arizona as speaker of the House of Representatives at their national convention next week. The purpose is to draw attention to Congressional races in November.

NEWARK, Aug. 11 While many people flock to the beaches and swimming clubs to soak up the sun, another form of sun worship is taking place on the roof of Colton Hall at the New Jersey Institute of Technology.
The stock market reversed Tuesday's advance yesterday and, after early gains, moved steadily lower to close at its lowest level of the session.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11 The Soviet press agency Tass today characterized as a "hostile, slanderous campaign" recent allegations in the United States that the Soviet Union might have violated the spirit of a treaty on underground nuclear tests by detonating two devices last month possibly exceeding the 150-kiloton limit.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 In a 1,400-word, editorial, the United Steelworkers Union newspaper has accused Victor G. Reuther, brother of the late leader of the United Automobile Workers, Walter Reuther, for meddling in the internal affairs of the steel union.

Every August, many of the nation's major toymakers trumpet their advertising plans for the pre-Christmas selling season. And since the bulk of all tyo sales occur in the September-December period, advertising of these products is naturally also at peak levels during these months.

How do you achieve a warm, enclosed feeling in a room and at the same time maintain a sense of space? Milo Baughman, a furniture designer, thinks he has an answer in the new line he has designed for Thayer Coggin.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 The national program against flu, more than two months behind schedule, will require inoculation of more than a million people daily after it begins at the end of September, according to a leader in the project.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 11 Representative Henry Helstoski agreed today to a new Democratic primary election in the Ninth Congressional District, which he has represented for six terms. The East Rutherford Democrat's narrow victory in the June 8 primary has been contested by his opponent, Assemblyman Byron M. Baer of Englewood, on charges of voting irregularities and possible fraud.
PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 11, (UPI) Viking scientist re ported further evidence today for an exchange of water vapor between the Martian atmosphere and the surface.

ATLANTA, Aug. 11 (AP) Georgia's primary election yesterday is bringing about a replay of two close 1974 Congressional races and runoffs on Aug. 31 in three districts in which longtime Representatives are retiring.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 11 (AP) The leader of one of Mexico's most active guerrilla groups was killed today in an attack on the sister of President-elect Jose Lopez Portillo, the police reported.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 11 The Israeli EI Al passenger plane that was attacked by terrorists in Istanbul landed safely at Ben Gurion Airport tonight with 82 passengers aboard.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 President Ford will fly to the Republican National Convention on Sunday, arriving in Kanas City early, his spokesman said today, "to do all he can to promote party unity."
CAPE TOWN, Aug. 11 At least 15 blacks were killed and 50 injured late today, the police said, in racial disturbances that erupted in the black town around Cape Town.
A Manhattan stockbroker called one of his more important customers yesterday morning and delivered this message: "Telephone just hit 60."

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 11 The outgoing Republican National Committee, as a farewell gift to President Ford, approved unanimously today a revised set of party rules, including one rule designed to help Mr. Ford defeat Ronald Reagan for the Presidential nomination next week.

Topiltzen (Piggy) Martinez and his younger brother, Alphonso, didn't have their best day yesterday at the Pepsi Cola/NBA Hotshot Competition at Annunciation Playground, 135th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, but so far they still hold the highest scores in their age categories at the park.

James Galanos is in a class by himself. He presents his collection late, after many other designers' clothes have reached the stores and in a manner most of them wouldn't attempt in these days of show-biz fashion displays.
ALBANY, Aug. 11 (UPI) State officials abandoned hope today of breaking up a "black market" in babies in New York City and Illinois because witnesses will not testify.
KANSAS CITY Every successful politician knows that you concentrate in the areas of your opponent's weakweaknesses, not his strengths.

PARIS, Aug. 11 (Reuters) Vietnam is permitting members of Vietnamese communities abroad to visit their families in the area that was formerly South Vietnam for the first time since the transfer of power there more than a year ago, informed sources said today.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 11 (AP) Mike Oransky of Miami upset top-seeded Francisco Gonzales of Puerto Rico, 7-6, 6-1, to advance to the quarterfinal round of the United States Tennis Association's 21 and under tournament today. Gonzeles recently won the United States amateur clay-court title.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 11 (AP) Thirty-five beds that were removed from New Brunswick firehouses by order of Mayor Richard J. Mulligan must be returned to their places by order of the courts.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 11 The first team ever of United States professional hockey players has assembled here.

Georgie Golde Kistner, a community leader in Wellesley, Mass., died at her home Tuesday. She was 55 years old.
COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Aug. 11 (AP) A conference of foreign ministers of nonaligned countries began here today with a veiled attack by the host country, Sri Lanka, on the United States and Britain.

HIGGANUM, CONN., AUG. 11 "You want to eat, and you can't eat. You want a cup of coffee, you can't have it," said Helen Mannetho, who lives with her husband, Henry, in retirement in this rustic town in the steep, rocky hills by the Connecticut River. She was among thousands of residents in Connecticut today who were still without electricity because of the hurricane.

The Rev. George G. Morrow, pastor emeritus of St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Church in Woodside, Queens, died Monday at Ozanam Hall of Queens Nursing Home in Bayside. He was 77 years old and a resident of the home.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 11 The Mississippi delegation to the Republican National Convention, the largest uncommitted bloc left, was reported today to be preparing to abandon the unit rule under which it has been operating.

A Federal district judge in Oklahoma City dismissed yesterday draft evasion charges against Fritz Efaw, who was to have gone on trial there today. He was nominated for Vice President so he could speak on universal amnesty.

Fortunately for sane defense policy, the Senate has fought a successful delaying action over the billion-dollar decision to start production of the B-1 bomber deferring the issue at least until after the Republican National Convention and possibly longer.

Sugar futures prices on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange closed higher yesterday, bolstered by a rumor, later denied, that the Soviet Union might have bought a substantial amount of sugar through a London dealer.

Clifford L. Myers, a former fund-raiser and public relations executive, died Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 267 West 89th Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 Responding to criticism of his agency's domestic intelligence operations, Clarence M. Kelley announced today the most extensive internal reorganization of the Federal Bureau of Investigation since the beginning of World War II.
